(c)  Possession unlawful. It shall be a violation of this section for any person to knowingly possess a product containing a synthetic cannabinoid, stimulant or psychedelic/hallucinogen. 
(d)  Use unlawful. It shall be a violation of this section for any person to be under the influence of a synthetic cannabinoid, stimulant or psychedelic/hallucinogen. 
(e)  Penalty. In addition to any other relief granted by the courts or the administrative law judge, any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine per section 1-8, general penalty, of this Code 
(Ord. No. 18-O-0016, § 1, 5-7-2018)  
Secs. 11-95—11-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - CONCERNING FIRE, SANITATION AND HEALTH 
 
Sec. 11-101. - Open burning. 
Open burning is restricted as specified per the fire prevention code as adopted and amended in section 4-11. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. IX, 5-17-65; Ord. No. 2340, § 2, 10-15-90; Ord. No. 2488, § 2, 10-7-91; Ord. No. 05-O-0001, § 1(Exh. A), 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 15-O-0017, § 7, 7-6-2015) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-O-0017, § 7, adopted July 6, 2015, shall be in full force and effect on Aug. 1, 2015.  
Sec. 11-102. - Fireworks. 
(a)  The term "fireworks" shall mean and include any explosive composition, or any substance or combination of substances, or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect of a temporary exhibitional nature by explosion, combustion, deflagration or detonation and shall include blank cartridges, toy cannons in which explosives are used, the type of balloons which require fire underneath to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, bombs or other fireworks of like construction and any fireworks containing any explosive compound; or any tablets or other device containing any explosive substance, or containing combustible substances producing visual effects. The term "fireworks" shall not include snake or glow worm pellets; smoke devices; sparklers; trick noisemakers known as "party poppers," "snappers," "trick matches," "cigarette loads," "booby traps" and "auto burglar alarms"; toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper or plastic caps containing twenty-five hundredths grains or less of explosive compound are used, provided they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion; and any toy pistol paper or plastic caps which contain less than twenty-five hundredths grains of explosive mixture; the same and use of which shall be permitted at all times. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, offer for sale, expose for sale, sale at retail or use or explode any fireworks within the city unless permission has been granted by the city council or its designee. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. IX, § 2, 5-17-65; Ord. No. 1777, § 1, 12-17-84; Ord. No. 06-O-0042, § 2, 5-1-2006)  
Sec. 11-103. - Ashes, rubbish, offal or garbage. 
(a)  No person shall allow to accumulate on property owned by him or under his control, any ashes, rubbish, offal or garbage, whereby the same would be a hazard to public health or safety. 
(b)  No person shall deposit any ashes, rubbish, offal or garbage upon any property of another without first obtaining the consent so to do from the owner or the person in whose control said property has been placed by the owner. 
(c)  No person shall deposit any ashes, rubbish or offal or garbage upon any public street, alley or way. 
(d)  No person shall burn any offal or garbage within the city limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. IX, § 3, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-104. - Buildings, factories and businesses. 
(a)  No person shall erect, continue or use any building or other place for living in, or the exercise of, any trade, hobby, employment or manufacture which by producing noxious exhalation is offensive or dangerous to the health of individuals or the public. 
(b)  No person shall erect, continue or use any building or other place for living in, or the exercise of any trade, hobby, employment or manufacture which by its physical condition is offensive or dangerous to any individual or to the public. 
(c)  No person shall operate any business, the operation of which is so unwholesome as to endanger any individual or the public. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. IX, § 4, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-105. - Water and wells. 
No person shall render unwholesome or make or injure any stream, lake, pond, well, river, spring, public or private water supply contaminating or placing therein any of the following: 
(1)  Animal carcass. 
(2)  Offal, filth or garbage. 
(3)  Any substance tending to render the same impure or unwholesome. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. IX, § 5, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-106. - Transportation of radioactive materials. 
Movement of any radioactive material under any condition shall not be allowed on the streets or alleys of the City of West Chicago except when, and as authorized by the applicable federal or state authority having jurisdiction over the subject material. 
(Ord. No. 2202, § 1, 9-20-89; Ord. No. 2405, §§ 1, 2, 4-1-91)  
Secs. 11-107—11-115. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 9. - AFFECTING STREETS, ALLEYS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS 
 
Sec. 11-116. - Prohibited acts. 
No person shall do any of the following to any road, street, alley, sidewalk, public easement or public way of the city: 
(1)  Place or cause to be placed any obstruction thereon. 
(2)  Deposit or allow to be deposited thereon, any dirt, mud, garbage, offal, refuse or other material of any kind or nature. 
(3)  Allow any tree or shrub to overhang. 
(4)  Place or cause to be placed, any flag, banner, sign, rope, string, cable, wire, bunting or display of any kind or nature or description over, upon or along. 
(5)  Perform an act, display or amusement thereon without first obtaining the consent of the council. 
(6)  Place, allow or cause to be placed any awning that overhangs unless said overhang is at least seven and one-half (7½) feet above said public way. 
(7)  Sell, attempt to sell or cause to be sold, any item without first having obtained the consent of the council to hold said street sale. 
(8)  Damage. 
(9)  Cut into or through, without first having obtained the consent of the council. 
(10)  Spit upon. 
(11)  To annoy or cause injury to any person on any street or sidewalk or other public place by placing any obstruction upon or across the same or by jeering at or deriding, with intent to annoy and cause discomfort or inconvenience to any person in the lawful and orderly pursuit of his business or pleasure in a street or public place. 
(12)  To crowd, jostle, scold, insult, threaten, assault, beat, strike, kick, injure or annoy or disturb any person in any street or public place or to injure, tear, destroy, spit on or soil the wearing apparel of any person in any such place. 
(13)  Loiter or to lounge about any door or entrance of any church, hall or other room or building used for public assemblies after being ordered away by any person in charge of such hall, room or building. 
(14)  Willfully and unnecessarily hinder, obstruct or delay or willfully and unnecessarily attempt to delay, hinder or obstruct any other person in lawfully walking upon or traveling along or upon any public sidewalk, street or other public way in this municipality. 
(15)  Sell, attempt to sell, or cause to be sold any food and/or beverage from a cart, nonmotorized trailer or motor vehicle, except in compliance with section 9-82 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. X, § 1, 5-17-65; Ord. No. 1064, § 2, 10-5-70; Ord. No. 2969, § 10, 5-6-96)  
Secs. 11-117—11-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 10. - CONCERNING GUNS AND WEAPONS 
 
Sec. 11-131. - Discharge—Guns. 
(a)  No person shall discharge any gun of any kind or nature or description within the city. 
(b)  The above shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Peace officers in their official duties. 
(2)  Persons using, in accordance with all rules and regulations, the range in the city park. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XI, § 2, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-132. - Same—Air guns, air pistols, etc. 
(a)  No person shall be permitted to fire or discharge upon the public streets, walks and ways or upon the property of another without his, its or their express permission so to do, within the city any air gun, air pistol, spring gun or spring pistol or device which is intended to propel or project a bullet, pellet, arrow or similar projectile. 
(b)  Every air gun, air pistol, spring gun or spring pistol or other device described in subsection (a), when used or operated contrary to the provisions of this section by any person is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and is subject to seizure and confiscation by any police officer and shall be disposed of as the police department shall direct. 
Upon the seizure of any device because of its use contrary to the provisions of this section, the police officer making such seizure shall forthwith cause a complaint to be filed, before a court of competent jurisdiction and a summons to be issued requiring the owner or person in possession of said property to appear in court and show cause why the device seized should not be forfeited to the city. In case of any failure to serve such summons upon the owner of such seized property or person in possession of the same at the time of seizure thereof, notice of the proceedings before the court, shall be given as required by the statutes of the state, in cases of attachment. Upon the return of the summons, duly served or upon posting or publication of notice made as hereinbefore provided, the court shall proceed to determine the question of the illegality of the use of the seized property and upon judgment being entered to the effect that the property was illegally used, an order shall be entered providing for the forfeiture of said seized property to the city. Such confiscation or forfeiture shall not preclude or mitigate prosecution and assessment of penalties. 
All costs of publication or posting of notice as required herein shall be paid by the city. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XI, § 3, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-133. - Unlawful use. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of unlawful use of weapons when he knowingly: 
(1)  Sells, manufactures, purchases, possesses or carries any bludgeon, blackjack, slingshot, sandclub, sandbag, shotgun with a barrel less than eighteen (18) inches in length, metal knuckles or any knife; commonly referred to as a switchblade knife, which has a blade that opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in the handle of the knife; or 
(2)  Carries or possesses with intent to use the same unlawfully against another, a dagger, dirk, billy, dangerous knife, razor, stiletto or any other dangerous or deadly weapon or instrument of like character; or 
(3)  Carries on or about his person or in any vehicle a tear gas gun, projector or bomb or any object containing noxious liquid gas or substance; or 
(4)  Carries concealed in any vehicle or concealed on or about his person except when on his land or in his own abode or fixed places of business any pistol, revolver or other firearm; or 
(5)  Sets a spring gun; or 
(6)  Possesses any device or attachment of any kind designed, used or intended for use in silencing the report of any firearm; or 
(7)  Sells, manufactures, purchases, possesses or carries any weapon from which more than eight (8) shots or bullets may be discharged by a single function of the firing device. 
(b)  Subsection (a) shall not apply to: 
(1)  Peace officers or any person summoned by any such officers to assist in making arrests or preserving the peace while he is actually engaged in assisting such officer. 
(2)  Watchmen while actually engaged in the performance of their duties of their employment. 
(3)  Members of any club or organization organized for the purpose of practicing shooting at targets upon established target ranges, whether public or private, while such members are using their firearms on such target ranges. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XI, § 4, 5-17-65)  
Secs. 11-134—11-145. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 11. - AFFECTING THE ADMINISTRATION OF CITY GOVERNMENT 
 
Sec. 11-146. - Resisting or obstructing a peace officer. 
No person shall knowingly resist or obstruct the performance of a police officer, knowing that he is a police officer, from any authorized act within his official capacity. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 1, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-147. - Resisting or obstructing service of process. 
No person shall resist or obstruct the authorized service of process by any police officer. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 2, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-148. - Obstructing justice. 
A person obstructs justice when, with the intent to prevent the apprehension or obstruct the prosection for a violation of any provision of this Code or other city ordinance, commits any of the following acts: 
(1)  Destroys, alters, conceals or disguises physical evidence, plants false evidence, furnishes false information; or 
(2)  Induces a witness having knowledge material to the subject at issue to leave the city or to conceal himself so that he will not be available to testify; or 
(3)  Possessing knowledge material to the subject issue he attempts to avoid testifying by concealing himself or leaving the city. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 3, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-149. - Escape. 
No person shall help any prisoner of the city to escape from any confinement imposed by any ordinance of the city or statute of the state. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 4, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-150. - Aiding an officer. 
No person upon command shall refuse or knowingly fail reasonably to aid a person known by him to be a peace officer of the city to do the following: 
(1)  Apprehend a person whom the officer is authorized to apprehend. 
(2)  Prevent the commission by another of any offense. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 5, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-151. - Compounding a crime. 
No person shall receive or offer to another any consideration for a promise not to prosecute or aid in the prosecution of any violator of any provision of this Code or other city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 6, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-152. - False statements. 
(a)  No person shall, under oath or affirmation in any city proceeding or in a trial involving a provision of this Code or other city ordinance where such oath or affirmation is required, make a false statement, material to the issue or point in question which he does not believe to be true. 
(b)  No person shall procure or induce another to violate subsection (a). 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 7, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-153. - Impersonation of city official. 
No person shall falsely represent himself to be an officer, including police officer, fireman nor an attorney for this city. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 8, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-154. - False documents. 
No person shall issue or deliver any document which he knows falsely purports to be or simulates any civil or criminal process of the city. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 9, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-155. - Destruction of public notice. 
No person shall knowingly and without lawful authority, alter, destroy, deface, remove or conceal any public notice of the city according to the law during the time for which the notice was to remain posted. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 10, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-156. - Bribery. 
A person commits bribery when: 
(1)  With intent to influence the performance of any act related to the employment or function of any public officer or public employee of the city he promises or tenders to that person any property or personal advantage which he is not authorized by law to accept; or 
(2)  He receives, retains or agrees to accept any property or personal advantage which he is not authorized by law to accept knowing that such property or personal advantage was promised or tendered with intent to cause him to influence the performance of any act related to the employment or function of any public officer or public employee of the city. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 11, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-157. - Failure to report a bribe. 
No public officer or public employee shall fail to report forthwith to the city attorney any bribe offer. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 12, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-158. - Misconduct. 
A public officer or employee of the city commits misconduct when in his official capacity, he commits any of the following acts: 
(1)  Intentionally or recklessly fails to perform a mandatory duty as required by law; or 
(2)  Knowingly performs an act which he knows he is forbidden by law to perform; or 
(3)  With intent to obtain a personal advantage for himself or another be performs an act in excess of his lawful authority; or 
(4)  Solicits or knowingly accepts for the performance of any act a fee or reward which he knows is not authorized by law. 
(Ord. No. 879, Art. XII, § 13, 5-17-65)  
Sec. 11-159. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 12. - LITTER IN PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PLACES 
 
Sec. 11-160. - Purposes. 
The purposes of this division is to: 
(1)  Define, prevent and abate littering within the city as a nuisance; 
(2)  Promote the public health by preventing and abating the accumulation of litter, garbage, refuse, rubbish, and debris on the public streets, alleys, sidewalks and upon other public and private property; and 
(3)  Prevent and abate the unwanted and possibly destructive placement of litter, including commercial and noncommercial handbills, upon vehicles, the public streets and other public property and upon private property when and where it is not desired by the owner of such private property. 
(Ord. No. 2404, § 1, 4-1-91)  
Sec. 11-161. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise expressly stated or the context clearly indicates a different sense the following terms shall, for the purpose of this division, have the meanings indicated in this section: 
Aircraft is any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or designated for navigation or for flight in the air. The word "aircraft" shall include helicopters, and lighter-than-air dirigibles and balloons. 
Commercial handbill is any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any manner of literature which: 
(1)  Advertises for sale any merchandise; 
(2)  Directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interests thereof by sales; or 
(3)  Directs attention or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind. 
(4)  While containing reading matter other than advertising matter is predominately and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
Container: 
(1)  A reusable container is a receptacle made of plastic, metal, or fiberglass with a capacity not to exceed thirty-two (32) gallons, a loaded weight of no more than thirty-five (35) pounds, a tight-fitting lid, and handles of adequate strength for lifting; 
(2)  A nonreusable container is a bag made of plastic with sufficient wall strength to maintain physical integrity when lifted by the top. 
Garbage is a putrescible animal or vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, serving or consumption of food and including food containers. 
Litter is "garbage," "refuse," "rubbish," "commercial handbills," "noncommercial handbills" and "newspapers," as defined herein and all other waste material of any kind which if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited tends to create a danger to public health, safety, and welfare. 
Newspaper is any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the Post Office Department of the United States, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law; and in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four (4) issues per year, and sold to the public. 
Noncommercial handbill is any printed or written matter, any sample, or any device, dodger, circular leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature not included in the aforesaid definition of a "commercial handbill" or "newspaper." 
Park is a park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other public area in the city, owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
Private premises is any parcel of land, dwelling, house, building, other structure or residential unit designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential, commercial or other purposes whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any vacant lot, yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, step(s), vestibule or mailbox belonging or pertinent to such dwelling, house, building, or other structure. 
Public place is any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys, or other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
Refuse is all putrescible and nonputrescible solid waste, except body waste, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleaning debris, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, solid market, and industrial wastes, in a solid or semiliquid state, and in any combination. 
Rubbish is a nonputrescible solid waste consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass bedding, crockery and similar materials including yard and garden waste. 
Vehicle is every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. 2404, § 1, 4-1-91)  
Sec. 11-162. - Litter prohibited. 
(a)  Litter in public and private places prohibited. No person shall throw or deposit litter or newspapers in any public place within the city except in public trash receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of any park or upon any street or other public place. Where public trash receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park, street or public place by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere, as provided herein. 
(b)  Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. Persons placing litter in public trash receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent such litter from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private premises. 
(c)  Sweeping litter into gutters prohibited. No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city, the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. 
(d)  Duty to keep sidewalks free of litter. Owners, occupants and/or operators of private premises within the city shall keep the sidewalk in front of those private premises free of litter. 
(e)  Litter thrown by persons in vehicles. No person while a driver or a passenger in a vehicle shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the city, or upon private premises. 
(f)  Truck loads causing litter. No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed and/or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley, or other public place. 
(g)  Dropping litter from aircraft. No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the city any litter, handbill or any other object, nor shall any person knowingly authorize another person to throw out, drop or deposit from an aircraft any litter, handbill or other object. 
(h)  Litter in lakes and fountains. No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, lake, stream, river or any other body of water within the city. 
(i)  Litter on private premises. No person shall throw or deposit litter on any private premises within the city, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private premises may maintain private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, other public place or upon any other private premises. 
(j)  Owner to maintain premises free of litter. The owner or person in control of any private premises shall at all times maintain the premises free of accumulated litter provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in private receptacles for collection nor prevent the maintenance of a compost pile for personal use and in an offensive manner, with the compost only consistent of yard clippings and leaves. 
(k)  Litter and vacant lots. No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private premises within the city whether owned by such person or not. 
(Ord. No. 2404, § 1, 4-1-91)  
Sec. 11-163. - Handbills. 
(a)  Throwing or distributing in public places. No person shall place, throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any sidewalk, street or other public place within the city, nor shall any person hand out, distribute, or sell any commercial or noncommercial handbill in any public place, provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful on any sidewalk, street or other public place within the city for any person to hand out or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, any noncommercial handbill to any person willing to voluntarily accept it. 
(b)  Placing on vehicles. No person shall place, throw, or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any vehicle within the city provided, however, it shall not be unlawful in any public place for a person to hand out or distribute without charge to the receiver thereof, any noncommercial handbill to any occupant of a vehicle who is willing to voluntarily accept it. 
(c)  Prohibiting distribution where properly posted. No person shall place, throw, deposit, or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill upon any private premises, after being requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words: "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers Invited," "No Advertisement," or any similar notice, indicating any manner that the occupants of said premises do not desire to be molested or have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any handbills left upon the premises. 
(d)  Distributing at private premises. No person shall place, throw, deposit, or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant, or other person then present in or upon such private premises provided, however, that in the case of private premises which are not posted, as provided in subsection (c), such person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises no to do so, may place or deposit any such handbill in or upon such private premises, if such handbill is so placed or so deposited as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such private premises or onto sidewalks, streets, other public places or to the private premises and except that mailboxes may not be so used to secure any handbill when so prohibited by federal postal laws or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2404, § 1, 4-1-91)  
Sec. 11-164. - Delivery of mail and newspapers. 
(a)  Delivery of mail. The provisions of this division shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States. 
(b)  Delivery of newspapers. The provisions of this division shall not prohibit the delivery of a newspaper, as outlined in section 11-165 private premises or public buildings; provided, however, that the newspaper shall be placed on the private premises or public building to which it is intended to be delivered or on that portion of the public street adjacent thereto and which is not occupied by sidewalk, curb, gutter, drainage facility, ditch or street pavement and shall be placed in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or posted by the elements onto any private premises or public buildings other than where it was placed, or onto the sidewalk, curb, gutter, drainage facility, ditch or street pavement. All newspapers, as defined in section 11-161, placed for delivery on a public place and not removed within twelve (12) hours of their placement shall be removed from the public place by the distributor or publisher of the newspaper, or the agent of either. 
(Ord. No. 2404, § 1, 4-1-91)  
Sec. 11-165. - Responsibility for handbill and newspaper distribution. 
(a)  Any person for whose benefit a commercial or noncommercial handbill, all as defined in section 11-161, is distributed, including any advertiser named in a handbill, or the publisher or the distribution agent of any handbill or newspaper shall be responsible for the proper distribution of the handbill or newspaper. 
(b)  No person shall knowingly authorize or allow another person to distribute a commercial or noncommercial handbill or newspaper, all as defined in section 11-161, in violation of the provisions of this division. 
(c)  Any handbill or newspaper, both as defined in section 11-161, distributed within the city shall be presumed to be distributed in a manner authorized or allowed by the advertisers or publishers named in the handbill or by the publisher named in the newspaper. 
(Ord. No. 2404, § 1, 4-1-91)  
Sec. 11-166. - Posting notices prohibited. 
No person shall post, affix or fasten in any way any notice, poster, or paper or other device, calculated to attract the attention of the public to any lamppost, public utility pole or shade tree in the public right-of-way or upon any public structure or public building, except as may be authorized or required by law. 
(Ord. No. 2404, § 1, 4-1-91)  
Sec. 11-167. - Public notices of city. 
(a)  The provisions of this division shall not prohibit the city's placing of public notices on public places. 
(b)  The provisions of this division shall not prohibit the city's distribution, by itself or by its agents, or posting of public notices, including handbills, concerning public emergencies, public works projects, maintenance of public facilities or the matters concerning public devices, to or on private premises. 
(Ord. No. 2404, § 1, 4-1-91)  
Secs. 11-168—11-170. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 13. - DRUG PARAPHERNALIA CONTROL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-O-0041, § 1, adopted March 5, 2018, amended division 13 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former division 13, §§ 11-170.1—11-170.5, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 07-O-0029, § 1, 4-2-2007. 
 
Sec. 11-170.1. - Definitions. 
As used in this division, unless the context otherwise requires: 
(a)  The term "cannabis" shall have the meaning ascribed to it in Section 3 of the "Cannabis Control Act", 720 ILCS 550/3, as if that definition were incorporated herein. 
(b)  The term "controlled substance" shall have the meaning ascribed to it in Section 102 of the "Illinois Controlled Substances Act", 720 ILCS 570/102, as if that definition were incorporated herein. 
(c)  "Deliver" or "delivery" means the actual, constructive or attempted transfer of possession, with or without consideration, whether or not there is an agency relationship. 
(d)  "Drug paraphernalia" means all equipment, products and materials of any kind which are intended to be used unlawfully in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human body cannabis or a controlled substance in violation of the "Cannabis Control Act" 720 ILCS 550/1 et seq., or the "Illinois Controlled Substances Act" 720 570/100 et seq. It includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Kits intended to be used unlawfully in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing or preparing cannabis or a controlled substance; 
(2)  Isomerization devices intended to be used unlawfully in increasing the potency of any species of plant which is cannabis or a controlled substance; 
(3)  Testing equipment intended to be used unlawfully in a private home for identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of cannabis or controlled substances; 
(4)  Diluents and adulterants intended to be used unlawfully for cutting cannabis or a controlled substance by private persons; 
(5)  Objects intended to be used unlawfully in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis, cocaine, hashish, hashish oil, methamphetamine or other controlled substances, as defined by law, into the human body including, where applicable, the following items: 
a.  Water pipes; 
b.  Carburetion tubes and devices; 
c.  Smoking and carburetion masks; 
d.  Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials; 
e.  Carburetor pipes; 
f.  Electric pipes; 
g.  Air-driven pipes; 
h.  Chillums; 
i.  Bongs; 
j.  Ice pipes or chillers; 
k.  Glass pipes. 
(6)  Any item whose purpose, as announced or described by the seller, is for use in violation of this Act. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-0016, § 1, 5-7-2018)  
Sec. 11-170.2. - Sale or delivery; penalty; public nuisance. 
(a)  No person shall keep for sale, offer for sale, sell, or deliver for any commercial consideration any item of drug paraphernalia. No person eighteen (18) years of age or older shall sell or deliver for any commercial consideration any item of drug paraphernalia to a person under eighteen (18) years of age. 
(b)  No person shall sell or deliver for commercial consideration any item of drug paraphernalia to a woman he knows to be pregnant. 
(c)  Any store, place, or premises from which or in which any item of drug paraphernalia is kept for sale, offered for sale, sold, or delivered for any commercial consideration is declared to be a public nuisance. 
(d)  In addition to any other penalties already provided for by law and this division, a person or store owner convicted of selling drug paraphernalia will automatically have their license to sell tobacco revoked, as required under chapter 9, article XXIV, section 9-686 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-0016, § 1, 5-7-2018)  
Sec. 11-170.3. - Possession of drug paraphernalia. 
(a)  A person who knowingly possesses an item of drug paraphernalia with the intent to use it in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis or a controlled substance into the human body, or in preparing cannabis or a controlled substance for that use, shall be subject to a fine per section 1-8, general penalty, of this Code. This subsection (a) does not apply to a person who is legally authorized to possess hypodermic syringes or needles under the Hypodermic Syringes and Needles Act. 
(b)  In determining intent under subsection (a), the trier of fact may take into consideration the proximity of the cannabis or controlled substances to drug paraphernalia or the presence of cannabis or a controlled substance on the drug paraphernalia. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-0016, § 1, 5-7-2018)  
Sec. 11-170.4. - Exemptions. 
This division shall not apply to the following: 
(a)  Items used in the preparation, compounding, packaging, labeling, or other use of cannabis or a controlled substance as an incident to lawful research, teaching, chemical analysis, use in law enforcement activities and which is not offered for sale. 
(b)  Items historically and customarily used in connection with, the planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, or inhaling of tobacco or any other lawful substance. 
Items exempt under this subsection include, but are not limited to, garden hoes, rakes, sickles, baggies, tobacco pipes, and cigarette-rolling papers. 
(c)  Items which are used for decorative purposes, when such items have been rendered completely inoperable or incapable of being used for any illicit purpose prohibited by this Act. 
(d)  A person who is legally authorized to possess hypodermic syringes or needles under the Hypodermic Syringes and Needles Act. 
In determining whether or not a particular item is exempt under this subsection, the trier of fact should consider, in addition to all other logically relevant factors, the following: 
(1)  The general, usual, customary, and historical use to which the item involved has been put; 
(2)  Expert evidence concerning the ordinary or customary use of the item and the effect of any peculiarity in the design or engineering of the device upon its functioning; 
(3)  Any written instructions accompanying the delivery of the item concerning the purposes or uses to which the item can or may be put; 
(4)  Any oral instructions provided by the seller of the item at the time and place of sale or commercial delivery; 
(5)  Any national or local advertising concerning the design, purpose or use of the item involved, and the entire context in which such advertising occurs; 
(6)  The manner, place and circumstances in which the item was displayed for sale, as well as any item or items displayed for sale or otherwise exhibited upon the premises where the sale was made; 
(7)  Whether the owner or anyone in control of the object is a legitimate supplier of like or related items to the community, such as a licensed distributor or dealer of tobacco products; 
(8)  The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the community. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-0016, § 1, 5-7-2018)  
Sec. 11-170.5. - Legislative intent; inference of legitimacy. 
This Act is intended to be used solely for the suppression of the commercial traffic in and possession of items that, within the context of the sale or offering for sale, or possession, are clearly and beyond a reasonable doubt intended for the illegal and unlawful use of cannabis or controlled substances. To this end all reasonable and common-sense inferences shall be drawn in favor of the legitimacy of any transaction or item. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-0016, § 1, 5-7-2018)  
DIVISION 14. - ANTI-GRAFFITI RESTRICTIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 08-O-0072, § 1, adopted October 6, 2008, enacted provisions intended for use as article II, division 14, sections 11-176, 11-177, 11-177. Inasmuch as article III begins with section 11-171, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been redesignated as sections 11-170.6—11-170.8. 
 
Sec. 11-170.6. - Definitions. 
The following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Aerosol paint container means any aerosol container that is adapted or made for the purpose of applying spray paint or other substances capable of defacing property. 
Broad-tipped marker means any felt-tip indelible marker or similar implement with a flat or angled writing surface that, at its broadest width, is greater than one-fourth (¼) inch, containing ink or other pigmented liquid that is not water soluble. 
Etching equipment means any tool, device or substance that can be used to make permanent marks on any natural or manmade surface. 
Graffiti means any unauthorized inscription, word, figure, painting or other defacement that is written, marked, etched, scratched, sprayed, drawn, painted, or engraved on or otherwise affixed to any surface of public or private property by any graffiti implement, to the extent that the graffiti was not authorized by the owner or occupant of the property, or, despite such authorization, is otherwise deemed a public nuisance by the city. 
Graffiti implement means an aerosol paint container, a broad-tipped marker, gum label, paint stick or graffiti stick, etching equipment, brush or any other device capable of scarring or leaving a visible mark on any natural or manmade surface. 
Paint stick or graffiti stick means any pen, pencil, chalk stick, crayon, brush, marker or other device containing a solid form of ink, paint, chalk, wax, epoxy, or other similar substance capable of being applied to a surface by pressure and leaving a mark of at least one-eighth inch in width. 
(Ord. No. 08-O-0072, § 1, 10-6-2008)  
Sec. 11-170.7. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  Defacement. It shall be unlawful for any person to apply graffiti to any natural or man made surface on any city-owned property or, without the permission of the owner or occupant, on any non-city-owned property. 
(b)  Possession of graffiti implements. 
(1)  By minors at or near school facilities. It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to possess any graffiti implement while on any school property, grounds, facilities, buildings, or structures; upon public property immediately adjacent thereto; or upon private property immediately adjacent to any school property, grounds, facilities, buildings, or structures, without the prior written consent of the owner or occupant of such private property. It shall be a defense to the violation of this section if, at the time the graffiti implements were in the possession of the minor, he or she was attending or traveling to or from classes at a school at which he or she is enrolled and was participating in a class at such school for which possessions of graffiti implements were necessary to meet the formal course requirements for such class. Before arresting and taking into custody any minor for violation of this section on school days during school hours, a police officer shall contact the school for the purpose of ascertaining whether or not he or she was attending classes at a school at which he or she is enrolled and was participating in a class at such school for which possession of the graffiti implements were necessary to meet the formal course requirements for such class. Verification by the school to the police officer that the graffiti implements were necessary to meet the formal course requirements for a class in which the minor is enrolled and attended that day shall preclude charging the minor with a violation of this section. 
(2)  In designated public places. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any graffiti implement while in or upon any public building, park, playground, swimming pool, recreational facility, or other public facility or structure owned or operated by the city, park district, or other governmental entity or while within fifty (50) feet of an underpass, bridge abutment, storm drain, or similar types of infrastructure unless otherwise authorized by the city or park district. However, it shall not be a violation of this section if the graffiti implements are in the possession of a person eighteen (18) years or older in a motor vehicle on a public roadway or are in the possession of person eighteen (18) years or older traveling on any sidewalk, street, or other public right-of-way and just have been purchased and are in their original packaging unopened. 
(3)  Accessibility to graffiti implements; furnishing to minors prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a parent or legal guardian, to sell, exchange, give, loan, or otherwise furnish, or cause or permit to be exchanged, given, loaned, or otherwise furnished, any aerosol paint container, broad-tipped marker, or paint stick or graffiti stick to any person under the age of eighteen (18) years without the written consent of the parents or guardian of the person. 
(Ord. No. 08-O-0072, § 1, 10-6-2008)  
Sec. 11-170.8. - Penalties. 
Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first offense or one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. No. 08-O-0072, § 1, 10-6-2008)  
ARTICLE III. - JAIL 
 
Sec. 11-171. - To be established by council. 
The place in the city established and used as the jail, or any other place which may hereafter be established by the council, for that purpose, is hereby declared to be the city jail. 
(Code 1954, Ch. XXVI, § 1)  
Sec. 11-172. - Chief of police to be keeper. 
The chief of police shall be the keeper of the jail and shall have custody of all persons confined therein and of all property pertaining thereto. 
(Code 1954, Ch. XXVI, § 2)  
Sec. 11-173. - Use. 
The city jail shall be used for the incarceration of all persons arrested for violating any of the laws of the state, the United States or for violating any provision of this Code or other city ordinance, until such person shall be brought before a judicial officer for a hearing or until such person shall be lawfully transferred to some other place of incarceration. 
(Code 1954, Ch. XXVI, § 3)  
Sec. 11-174. - Escape; attempts. 
It shall be unlawful for any prisoner to escape, attempt to escape or for any person to assist a prisoner to escape or attempt to escape, from the city jail. 
(Code 1954, Ch. XXVI, § 5)  
Sec. 11-175. - Communication with prisoners. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to communicate with any prisoner held in the jail, without the permission of the keeper of the jail. 
(Code 1954, Ch. XXVI, § 6)  
ARTICLE IV. - RESERVED 
 
Secs. 11-176—11-200. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 4216, § 2, adopted Aug. 16, 1999, deleted former Art. IV, Dogs, §§ 11-191—11-200 derived from various sections of the 1954 Code, Ch. XXII, and subsequently amended. The user's attention is directed to the Code Comparative Table at the back of this volume for further derivation of such article.  
ARTICLE V. - VEHICLE STORAGE CHARGES 
 
Sec. 11-201. - Vehicle storage charges. 
No vehicle that has been towed, impounded or otherwise lawfully taken into custody by the police department of the city shall be released to the owner, lienholder, or other person entitled to possession until all towing and storage charges have been paid. Storage charges shall accrue at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00)/day, beginning on the fifteenth day following the date upon which the police department sends written notification to the owner, lienholder or other person entitled to possession that the vehicle is available to be released. Said notice shall also inform the owner, lienholder or other person entitled to possession that failure to claim said vehicle will result in the above stated storage charges. 
(Ord. No. 4259, § 5, 12-6-99)  
ARTICLE VI. - TRUANCY 
 
Sec. 11-202. - Purpose. 
The public purpose of this article is to provide for the protection of juveniles from each other and from other persons, for the enforcement of parental control and responsibility for their children, for the protection of the general public, and for the reduction of the incidences of juvenile criminal activities pursuant to the city's power to promote the health, safety and general welfare of its citizens. 
(Ord. No. 02-O-0106, 9-16-2002)  
Sec. 11-203. - Title. 
This article may be cited as the "Truancy Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 02-O-0106, 9-16-2002)  
Sec. 11-204. - Findings. 
The city council makes the following findings: 
(1)  City residents find problems associated with the assembly of youth as a major problem facing the city; and 
(2)  It has been found that truancy is a high indicator of criminal involvement; and 
(3)  The city is confronted by rising juvenile violence, juvenile criminal activity, and an increasing number of high school dropouts; and 
(4)  Juveniles are particularly susceptible by their lack of maturity and experience to participate in unlawful and criminal related activities and to be victims of older perpetrators of crime. 
(Ord. No. 02-O-0106, 9-16-2002)  
Sec. 11-205. - Definitions. 
Guardian means (1) a person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a qualified student; or (2) a public or private agency with whom a qualified student has been placed by a court. 
Parent means a person who is: (1) a natural parent, adoptive parent, or step-parent of a qualified student or (2) at least eighteen (18) years of age and authorized by a parent or guardian to have care and custody of a qualified student. 
Qualified student means a person at the time of the offense who is between the ages of seven (7) and sixteen (16) or is enrolled in any of grades one (1) through twelve (12) and is subject to compulsory attendance pursuant to 105 ILCS 5/26-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 02-O-0106, 9-16-2002)  
Sec. 11-206. - Offenses. 
(a)  A qualified student who is subject to compulsory education or to compulsory continuing/ alternative education is guilty of an offense if he or she is in or upon public streets, public places, places of amusement and eating places, vacant lots or any unsupervised place, including a private residence during the hours when the qualified student's school is in session. A qualified student shall be excused from the compulsory education requirement if said absence is in conjunction with a field trip or program conducted by the student's school, or if the student has been excused with parental or school permission pursuant to their school's policies or regulations, provided said regulations are not more restrictive than state statute. 
(b)  A parent or guardian of a qualified student is guilty of an offense if he or she knowingly permits a qualified student to be in violation of [subsection] (a). 
(Ord. No. 02-O-0106, 9-16-2002)  
Sec. 11-207. - Exemptions. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to apply to home schools established as specified by Illinois home school requirements. 
(Ord. No. 02-O-0106, 9-16-2002)  
Sec. 11-208. - Penalty. 
In addition to any other relief granted by the courts, any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine per section 1-8, general penalty, of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 02-O-0106, 9-16-2002; Ord. No. 07-O-0017, § 7, 4-16-2007)  
Secs. 11-209, 11-210. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - VEHICLE IMMOBILIZATION PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 11-211. - Vehicle immobilization program established. 
The chief of police, or his designee, is authorized to direct and supervise a program of vehicle immobilization as provided for in this article. The program of vehicle immobilization shall provide for immobilizing any eligible vehicle upon the public way, in a public place, or on private property with the consent of the property owner, by placement of a restraint in such a manner as to prevent its operation when there are seven (7) or more outstanding or otherwise unsettled parking violation notices and/or warrants issued for such violations pending against the owner of such motor vehicle. 
For purposes of this article, "public way" means any sidewalk, roadway, alley or other public thoroughfare and any city owned parking lot or other city property. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-0044, § 2, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 11-212. - Vehicles eligible for immobilization. 
A vehicle shall be eligible for immobilization, as provided herein, any time after inclusion of its state registration number or other vehicle identification number on any immobilization list, regardless of whether or not the listed vehicle itself has received a parking violation complaint. A vehicle's state registration number or other vehicle identification number shall be included on an immobilization list only if: 
(1)  The registered owner of the vehicle has accumulated seven (7) or more outstanding or otherwise unsettled parking violation notices from the city or a warrant issued for such violations is pending against the owner of such motor vehicle. 
(2)  At least twenty-four (24) days prior to the city's placing the registration plate number of the vehicle on the vehicle immobilization eligibility list, notice of impending vehicle immobilization has been sent to all registered owners via certified, return receipt requested, at the address of the registered owner recorded with the Secretary of State or, in the case of a vehicle bearing the registration number of a state other than Illinois, at the address of the registered owner recorded in that state's registry of motor vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-0044, § 2, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 11-213. - Notice of vehicle immobilization and pre-immobilization hearing. 
The notice required in subsection 11-212(2) shall state the name and address of all registered owners, the state registration number or vehicle identification number of the vehicle, the nature of the ordinance(s) violated and the numbers and issue dates of the outstanding complaints or citations. The notice shall also advise that a registered owner, or any person who establishes having an interest therein, may request a hearing to challenge the validity of the notice of impending vehicle immobilization by submitting a request for such to the city at the address stated in the notice. Such hearing shall be as provided in section 11-218, except that the request for a hearing shall be submitted within ten (10) days of mailing the notice. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-0044, § 2, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 11-214. - Notice to be affixed to immobilized vehicle. 
Upon immobilization of an eligible vehicle, a notice shall be affixed to the vehicle in a conspicuous place. Such notice shall warn that the vehicle is immobilized and that any attempt to move the vehicle may result in its damage. The notice shall also state that the unauthorized removal of or damage to the immobilizing restraint is a violation of the Illinois Criminal Code. The notice shall also provide information specifying how release of the immobilizing restraint may be had and how a registered owner may obtain a post-immobilization hearing pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-0044, § 2, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 11-215. - Towing of immobilized vehicle. 
Except where the vehicle is otherwise subject to towing, if the immobilizing restraint has not been released pursuant to section 11-216 within twenty-four (24) hours of its placement, the restraint shall be released and the vehicle towed and impounded. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-0044, § 2, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 11-216. - Release of immobilized vehicle. 
Prior to a hearing on the validity of the immobilization as provided in section 11-218, the owner of an immobilized vehicle or other interested person shall be permitted to secure release of the vehicle by: 
(1)  Paying the immobilization and towing and storage fees, if applicable, specified in section 11-219; and 
(2)  Taking one (1) of the following actions: 
a.  Paying all the fines and penalties, if any, on the outstanding complaints for which notice had been sent prior to the date of the immobilization; or 
b.  Completing appearance forms on all outstanding parking violation complaints for which notice had been sent prior to the date of the immobilization and depositing collateral in the amount of fifty (50) percent of the total fines for these outstanding parking violation complaints, or five hundred dollars ($500.00), whichever is less. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-0044, § 2, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 11-217. - Post vehicle immobilization/impoundment notice. 
Within ten (10) days after a vehicle has been impounded, notice of impoundment shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to all registered owners of the vehicle at the address to which the notice specified in subsection 11-212 (2) was mailed. The notice shall state that an owner has the right to a post-immobilization and post-towing hearing as provided in section 11-218, and that if the vehicle is not claimed within thirty (30) days from the date of the notice, the vehicle may be disposed of in accordance with the Illinois Vehicle Code and/or city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-0044, § 2, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 11-218. - Immobilized vehicle hearing. 
An owner of an immobilized vehicle, or any person who establishes having an interest therein, shall have the right to a hearing before the chief of police or his designee to determine whether the immobilization or any subsequent towing was erroneous or whether the vehicle was properly included on an immobilization list, if an owner or such other person files a written demand for a hearing with the chief of police, or his designee, within fourteen (14) days after issuance of the notice specified in section 11-216 or within fourteen (14) days after the immobilization, whichever is later. A hearing shall be conducted within forty-eight (48) hours of receipt of a written demand for a hearing, unless otherwise mutually agreed by the parties. Failure to request or attend a scheduled hearing shall be deemed a waiver of the right to a hearing. In the event of such failure, any amount deposited pursuant to section 11-219 shall be forfeited. A hearing provided in accordance with this article shall not determine the validity of or otherwise adjudicate any citation or notice of parking violations issued relative to the immobilized vehicle but shall only relate to whether the vehicle was properly placed on the immobilization list, immobilized or towed. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-0044, § 2, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 11-219. - Fees and costs. 
The fee for immobilization shall be as prescribed in Appendix G. Additionally, the owner of the vehicle shall be charged reasonable storage and towing fees, should the vehicle be removed to a private storage facility, and shall be charged the costs for the hearing, including but not limited to court reporter's fees, the cost of transcripts or records, attorneys' fees, the cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders, and all other miscellaneous expenses. No fees, costs, or charges shall be assessed in the case of any immobilization listing, immobilization, or tow and storage which has been determined to be erroneous. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-0044, § 2, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 11-O-0007, § 37, 5-16-2011)  
Sec. 11-220. - Unlawful to relocate immobilized vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful to relocate or tow any vehicle restrained by an immobilizing device without the approval of the chief of police or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-0044, § 2, 6-4-2007)  
ARTICLE VIII. - SMOKE FREE ILLINOIS ACT 
 
Sec. 11-221. - Acknowledgment of applicability of the Smoke Free Illinois Act. 
Pursuant to 410 Illinois Compiled Statutes 82/65, the city hereby adopts and incorporates by reference into the Code of Ordinances of the City of West Chicago each and every provision of the Smoke Free Illinois Act as contained in 410 Illinois Compiled Statutes 82/1 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 17-O-0006, § 2, 4-17-2017)  
Sec. 11-222. - Smoking in public places, places of employment, and governmental buildings and vehicles prohibited. 
No person shall smoke or use an e-cigarette in a public place or in any place of employment or within fifteen (15) feet of any entrance to a public place or place of employment. No person may smoke or use an e-cigarette in any vehicle owned, leased, or operated by the state or city. Smoking or using an e-cigarette is prohibited in indoor public places and workplaces unless specifically exempted by Section 35 of the Smoke Free Illinois Act. 
(Ord. No. 17-O-0006, § 2, 4-17-2017)  
Sec. 11-223. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates any portion of this article shall be subject to a fine or fines as set forth in the general penalty section of the City Code. Each day that a violation shall continue shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 17-O-0006, § 2, 4-17-2017)  
Chapter 12 - PARKS AND PLAYGROUNDS[1] 

Footnotes:
