Cross reference— Parks and playgrounds under management and control of department of public works, § 2-209. 
 
Sec. 12-1. - Reed-Keppler Park named. 
The municipal park comprised of all of the property lying between National Street and Glen Oak Cemetery, along the west side of Arbor Avenue and extending westerly to the E. J. & E. right-of-way, henceforth shall be known as Reed-Keppler Park. 
(Ord. No. 600, 2-20-56; Ord. No. 1126, 5-1-72)  
Chapter 13 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Formerly, Section 1 of Ord. No. 2478, adopted Sept. 3, 1991, repealed former Ch. 13, "Police," which contained § 13-1 and derived from Ord. No. 1277, § 1, adopted Aug. 4, 1975. 
 
Sec. 13-1. - Cemetery sexton. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the cemetery sexton, under the general direction of the director of public works, to supervise and direct all activities in the Glen Oak and Oakwood Cemeteries, including, but not limited to sales of gravesites, performing grave openings and closings, grounds maintenance, and preparation and maintenance of records and reports for submittal to the city. 
(b)  The city shall enter into a contract for cemetery sexton services annually, at the beginning of each fiscal calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 06-O-0001, § 6, 2-6-2006)  
Sec. 13-2. - Cemetery fees and charges. 
The sale price of graves and the costs associated with grave excavation in all city-owned and -operated cemeteries shall be as prescribed in Appendix G. 
(Ord. No. 06-O-0001, § 6, 2-6-2006; Ord. No. 06-O-0035, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 07-O-0021, § 1, 3-19-2007; Ord. No. 08-O-0032, § 1, 5-5-2008; Ord. No. 09-O-0026, § 1, 4-6-2009; Ord. No. 11-O-0007, § 38, 5-16-2011)  
Sec. 13-3. - Cemetery rules, regulations and ownership. 
(a)  Ownership of grave sites. The person(s) named in the original deed, or indicated in the city's records, as the owner(s) of any grave site shall be deemed to be the owner(s) of such grave site. In the event that any such owner of any grave site is deceased and interred elsewhere, the city will follow the rules of descent and distribution for the state duly enacted and effective on the date of such owner's death. Where the owner of a particular grave site cannot be determined through an original deed or through the city's records, the determination of ownership shall be made by the sexton, whose decision shall be final. The sexton shall require any claimant to such ownership to substantiate his or her claim, to provide notice to potential adverse claimants by publication and, where practicable, by mail, and to indemnify the city against any costs, claims, losses, demands, damages, expenses and/or liability arising out of such adverse claims, including, without limitation, reasonable attorney's fees and litigation costs. 
(b)  Rules and regulations. 
(1)  Hours of operation. The cemeteries shall be open to the public from dawn until dusk each day. 
(2)  Work within the cemeteries and memorials. All grading, landscape work, memorial installation, memorial repairs or improvement of any kind within the cemeteries shall be performed by the sexton, public works director, their designee, or an approved memorial contractor. No memorial shall be installed on any grave site unless and until full payment for such grave site has been received by the city. Memorials installed on or after April 25, 1996, shall be installed in accordance with the following: 
a.  Requests for memorial installations shall be made in writing to the public works director and shall include the name, address and telephone number of the owner of the grave site; the specific grave site involved; the name(s), address(es) and telephone number(s) of the company supplying the memorial and the memorial contractor, and a sketch plan for the memorial, including the location and all dimensions thereof, sufficient to show compliance with all of the requirements of this subsection (2). 
b.  Each approved memorial contractor shall provide to the sexton evidence of insurance or bonding with respect to its activities, and periodic renewals of same as necessary to demonstrate that such coverage is continuously maintained in full force and effect, in an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). 
c.  All memorial foundation work shall be performed by the sexton, the public works director, or their designee. 
d.  Markers and monuments. 
1.  All markers and monuments shall be made of granite, concrete, or other materials which the sexton or public works director determines to be of equal durability, and may feature plaques, vases or everlasting lights made of bronze, or other materials which the sexton or public works director determines to be of equal durability. Such determinations of durability shall be final and conclusive. 
2.  Single grave sites. One (1) marker shall be permitted at the head of a single grave site. Such marker shall not exceed fourteen (14) inches in width, thirty (30) inches in length, nor twenty-six (26) inches in height, and shall be mounted on a base not to exceed twenty (20) inches in width, forty-two (42) inches in length, or eight (8) inches in height. In the event of a veteran or double interment, one (1) flush mounted marker shall also be permitted at the foot of such grave site, not to exceed twelve (12) inches in width or twenty-four (24) inches in length, mounted on a base not to exceed twenty (20) inches in width or thirty-two (32) inches in length. 
3.  Double grave sites. One (1) marker or monument shall be permitted at the head of a double grave site. Such marker shall not exceed twelve (12) inches in width, forty-two (42) inches in length, or twenty (20) inches in height. Such monument shall not exceed eight (8) inches in width, forty-two (42) inches in length, or twenty-eight (28) inches in height. Such marker or monument shall be mounted on a base not to exceed fourteen (14) inches in width, fifty-four (54) inches in length, or eight (8) inches in height. In addition, one (1) flush mounted marker shall also be permitted at the foot of each individual grave, not to exceed twelve (12) inches in width or twenty-four (24) inches in length, mounted on a base not to exceed twenty (20) inches in width or thirty-two (32) inches in length. 
4.  Triple grave sites. One (1) marker or monument shall be permitted at the head of a triple grave site. Such marker shall not exceed twelve (12) inches in width, forty-two (42) inches in length, or twenty (20) inches in height, and shall be mounted on a base not to exceed eighteen (18) inches in width, fifty-four (54) inches in length or eight (8) inches in height. Such monument shall not exceed eight (8) inches in width, sixty (60) inches in length, or twenty-eight (28) inches, and shall be mounted on a base not to exceed fourteen (14) inches in width, seventy-two (72) inches in length, or eight (8) inches in height. In addition, one (1) flush mounted marker shall also be permitted at the foot of each individual grave, not to exceed twelve (12) inches in width or twenty-four (24) inches in length, mounted on a base not to exceed twenty (20) inches in width or thirty-two (32) inches in length. 
5.  Sites with more than three (3), but fewer than twelve (12), graves. One (1) marker or monument shall be permitted at the head or center of a site with more than three (3), but fewer than twelve (12), graves. Such marker or monument shall not exceed ten (10) inches in width, seventy-two (72) inches in length, or forty (40) inches in height, and shall be mounted on a base not to exceed fourteen (14) inches in width, eighty-four (84) inches in length, or eight (8) inches in height. In addition one (1) flush mounted marker shall also be permitted at the foot of each individual grave, not to exceed twelve (12) inches in width or twenty-four (24) inches in length, mounted on a base not to exceed twenty (20) inches in width or thirty-two (32) inches in length. 
6.  Sites with twelve (12) or more graves. One (1) marker or monument shall be permitted at the center of a site with twelve (12) or more graves. Such marker or monument shall not exceed thirty-six (36) inches in width, eighty-four (84) inches in length, or forty-eight (48) inches in height, and shall be mounted on a base not to exceed forty (40) inches in width, ninety-six (96) inches in length, or eight (8) inches in height. In addition, one (1) marker, not to exceed fourteen (14) inches in width, thirty (30) inches in length, or twenty-six (26) inches in height, mounted on a base not to exceed twenty (20) inches in width, forty-two (42) inches in length or eight (8) inches in height, shall also be permitted at the head of each individual grave. 
7.  Infant section. One (1) flush mounted marker not exceed ten (10) inches in width, or eighteen (18) inches in length, mounted on a base not to exceed eighteen (18) inches in width or twenty-six (26) inches in length, shall be permitted at the head of each grave in the infant section. 
e.  Mausoleums. Mausoleums shall be permitted, provided that: 
1.  All mausoleums shall be constructed of granite, concrete, or other materials which the sexton or public works director determines to be of equal durability, and may feature plaques, vases or everlasting lights made of bronze, or other materials which the sexton or public works director determines to be of equal durability. Such determinations of durability shall be final and conclusive. 
2.  No mausoleums shall exceed six (6) crypts in capacity or twelve (12) feet in height. 
3.  All mausoleums shall be located not less than four (4) feet from any point on the perimeter of the grave site. 
(3)  Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any of the following acts within any cemetery: 
a.  To injure or deface any of the trees, fences, bridges, walks, fireplaces, buildings, shrubs, plants, turfs, grass, lanes, or posts or attach any matter or printed matter or placards thereon. 
b.  To destroy, mutilate or damage in any manner any marker, flag or other grave decoration in the cemetery, or to enter the cemetery grounds with the intention of committing such act or of interfering with any grave. 
c.  To pick, injure or destroy any of the flowers or shrubs or to remove the same. 
d.  To drive any automotive vehicle or ride any horse or operate any other vehicle, including bicycles and snowmobiles, or park any vehicle, except upon the road. 
e.  To drive or operate any vehicle at a speed in excess of ten (10) miles per hour. 
f.  To permit a dog to run at large or to walk any such dog on a leash through or in any cemetery. 
g.  To have, serve, sell, give away or drink any alcoholic beverage. 
(c)  Decorations for gravesites; generally. 
(1)  Decoration regulations exist to protect each grave site owner. Decorations not in conformity with these regulations will be removed by the city and discarded. The city does not warrant or guaranty against the damage, loss or destruction of decorations and all risks associated with the placement of decorations shall remain with the person(s) placing the same. 
(2)  All grading, landscape work, improvement of any kind, care of burial space, planting, trimming, cutting or removal of trees, shrubs, or herbage of any kind, opening and closing of burial spaces, interment and disinterment or removal of bodies, construction of all foundations, and installation of all vases and memorials shall be done only by the sexton, public works director or their designate. 
(3)  Not more than one (1) decoration shall be placed on any grave site at any time. In the case of monument lots, not more than one (1) decoration shall be placed on the lot at any time regardless of the number of individual graves on the lot. 
(4)  Decorations shall remain on the graves only as long as their appearance is presentable, as determined in the sole discretion of the sexton, public works director or designate. Decorations which become unsightly, or withered, shall be removed and discarded. 
(5)  Outlining of graves or memorials in any fashion, including but not limited to, metal frames, stones and/or stripping with sod, is prohibited. 
(6)  Growing of shrubs and/or bushes is prohibited at all times. 
(7)  All forms of decoration not specifically permitted hereunder are prohibited and shall be removed, including but not limited to, jars, bottles, statuary, cans, globes, shells, and other ornaments. 
(d)  Decorations for grave sites; seasonal rules. 
(1)  Growing season. For the purposes of this section, the term growing season shall mean the period each year commencing April 15 and ending October 15. During the growing season, the following grave site decorations are permitted: 
a.  Natural flowers, provided that such flowers are placed in a pin type, or other approved vase. Permanent vases are prohibited. Permanent upright vases installed prior to the adoption of these rules and regulations may continue to be used, but must be lowered to ground level during the nongrowing season. 
b.  Potted plants, provided that such plants are positioned close to the front of the marker, and not more than one (1) six-inch or eight-inch pot is placed at any grave site. 
c.  Boxed plants, provided that such plants are placed in wood or plastic boxes not larger than fifteen (15) inches by eight (8) inches, and not more than one (1) boxed plant is placed at any grave site. 
d.  Flags, provided that flags may be placed not more than three (3) days prior to Memorial Day, Independence Day, and/or Veteran's Day, and are removed not later than the first business day thereafter. 
e.  Hinged veterans emblems, set flush to the ground, provided that such emblem shall be set in the upright position not more than three (3) days prior to Memorial Day, Independence Day, and/or Veteran's Day, and shall be returned to the lowered position not later than the first business day thereafter. 
Boxes and pots shall be placed on the grass and not dug in, and shall be placed in front of, and as close as possible to, the memorial. Boxes and pots may be placed on the marker provided they do not stain the same. Artificial flowers are prohibited during the growing season. 
(2)  Nongrowing season. For the purposes of this section, the term nongrowing season shall mean the period of each year prior to March 1, and/or after November 15. During the nongrowing season artificial flowers, placed in stands, approved vases, pots or boxes in the same manner as provided for natural plants in boxes and pots hereinabove, shall be permitted decorations for grave sites. Further, one (1) artificial wreath shall be permitted at each grave site, provided that such wreath is less than thirty (30) inches in diameter, and is permanently attached to a stand or easel. Evergreen blankets and other winter type decorations are prohibited. 
(3)  Spring and fall clean up. 
a.  The period from March 1 through April 14 of each year shall be used for maintenance and groundskeeping purposes to prepare for the growing season. All nongrowing season decorations shall be removed by the city on or after March 1. 
b.  The period from October 16 through November 15 shall be used for maintenance and groundskeeping purposes to prepare for the growing season. All growing season decorations shall be removed by the city on or after October 16. 
(Ord. No. 06-O-0001, § 6, 2-6-2006)  
Chapter 14 - POLLUTION CONTROL AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 4; housing, Ch. 7; nuisances, Ch. 10; water and sewer services, Ch. 18. 
 
ARTICLE I. - POLLUTION CONTROL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known, cited and referred to as "The City of West Chicago Pollution Control Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 1.1, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-2. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter the following terms shall have the meanings indicated unless their context requires otherwise: 
Air contaminant is particulate matter, dust, fumes, gas, mist, smoke or vapor or any combination thereof. 
Air contaminant source is any and all sources of emission of air contaminants, whether privately or publicly owned or operated. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, this term includes all types of business, commercial and industrial plants, works, shops and stores and heating and power plants and stations, buildings and other structures of all types including single-and multiple-family residences, apartment houses, office buildings, hotels, restaurants, schools, hospitals, churches and other institutional buildings, automobiles, trucks, tractors, buses and other motor vehicles, garages and vending and service locations and stations, railroad locomotives, ships, boats and other waterborne craft, portable fuel-burning equipment, incinerators of all types, indoor and outdoor, refuse dumps and piles, and all stack and other chimney outlets from any of the foregoing. 
Air pollution is present in the outdoor atmosphere if there are one or more air contaminants in sufficient quantities and of such characteristics and duration as to be injurious to human, plant or animal life or to property or which unreasonably interferes with the enjoyment of life and property. 
Air quality standard means ambient air quality goal established for the purpose of protecting public health and welfare. 
Combustible refuse is any solid or liquid combustible waste material containing carbon in a free or combined state. 
Emission standard means that level of air contaminant emitted from an air contaminant source which is established by authority. 
Equipment is any fuel-burning, refuse-burning, combustion process device or apparatus used for the burning of fuel or combustible material from which the products of combustion are emitted. Also this shall include apparatus which generate heat and may emit products of combustion, and manufacturing, chemical, metallurgical or mechanical processes which may emit air contaminants. 
Organic materials are chemical compounds of carbon excluding carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, carbonic acid, metallic carbides, metallic carbonates and ammonium carbonate. 
Organic solvent is organic materials which are liquids at standard atmospheric conditions and which are used as dissolvers, viscosity reducers, cleaning agents, diluents or thinners. 
Photochemically reactive solvent is any solvent with an aggregate of more than twenty (20) percent of its total volume composed of chemical compounds classified below or which exceeds any of the following individual percentage composition limitations, referred to the total volume of solvent: 
(1)  A combination of hydrocarbons, alcohols, aldehydes, esters, ethers or ketones having an olefinic or cycloolefinic type of unsaturation: Five (5) percent; 
(2)  A combination of aromatic compounds with eight (8) or more carbon atoms to the molecule except ethylbenzene: Eight (8) percent; 
(3)  A combination of ethylbenzene, ketones having branched hydrocarbon structures, trichloroethylene or toluene: Twenty (20) percent. 
Ringlemann Chart is the chart which is described in the U. S. Bureau of Mines Information Circular 7718, and on which are illustrated graduated shades of gray to black for use in estimating the light-obscuring power of smoke. 
(Ord. No. 1068, §§ 1.1, 2.2, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-3. - Air pollution control officer—Power of enforcement. 
The mayor and council are hereby authorized to designate the pollution control officer and enforcing officers, who shall exercise the duties set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 3.1-1, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-4. - Same—Duties. 
The duties of the pollution control officer shall be to: 
(1)  Supervise the execution of all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to environmental pollution; 
(2)  To institute necessary proceedings to prosecute violations of this article and compel the prevention and abatement of environmental contaminants and nuisances arising therefrom; 
(3)  To examine and approve the plans of pollution control devices proposed, installed, constructed, reconstructed, repaired or added to, in any building, location or on any premises within the boundaries of the city; 
(4)  To cause inspections to be made of pollution control devices; 
(5)  To investigate complaints, make observations of contaminant conditions and take the necessary and proper action to abate nuisances therefrom; 
(6)  To advise, consult and cooperate with other governmental agencies in the furtherance of the purpose of this chapter; 
(7)  To collect, publish and disseminate appropriate educational literature and other information to the public for the purpose of advising of the necessity, purpose and methods of pollution prevention; 
(8)  To issue all permits, certificates, notices or other matters required under the provisions of this chapter; and to notify all persons concerned of any decision rendered and to provide such persons with an opportunity to be heard; 
(9)  To enlist the cooperation of civic, technical, scientific and educational groups, societies and organizations in respect to the reduction and abatement of air contaminants; 
(10)  To cause to be instituted in the court legal proceedings by the city attorney to compel compliance with any order or determination entered on recommendation of the pollution control officer and pollution committee. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 3.1-2, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-5. - Same—Right of entry; badge and identification card; assistance from other officers. 
(a)  In the discharge of his duties, the pollution control officer or his authorized inspectors shall have the authority to enter, at any reasonable hour, any building, structure or premises within the incorporated area of the city to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The council shall issue to the pollution control officer a badge of office and an identification card as is customarily issued by the city, for himself and his representatives, which shall be displayed for the purpose of identification. 
(c)  The assistance and cooperation of health, police, legal and other officers shall be available to the pollution control officer when required in the performance of his duties. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 3.1-3, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-6. - Appeals. 
(a)  The council shall have the duty and power to hear and determine appeals of the decisions and orders of the pollution control officer and to confirm, vary or reverse any such decision or order. 
(b)  Any person aggrieved by an order or decision of the pollution control officer may appeal the same to the council within twenty (20) days of said order, decision or ruling, by filing with the pollution control officer and the city clerk written notice of appeal; and said notice shall give the address where notices can be served upon him. 
(c)  The pollution control officer, upon receipt of the notice of appeal, shall forthwith transmit to the council all papers and documents constituting the record upon which his decision, order or ruling was based. The council shall set a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal and give due notice thereof by certified mail to the parties in interest. Said notice of appeal shall act as a stay of any decision, ruling or order until either approved, modified or set aside by the council. A fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid to the city at the time the notice of appeal is filed with the clerk. 
(d)  The council shall decide said appeal within a reasonable time and shall forthwith by certified mail notify all parties of its decision. 
(Ord. No. 1068, §§ 3.2-1—3.2-4, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-7. - Installation permit for fuel-burning, combustion or process equipment. 
(a)  No person shall construct, install or alter any fuel-burning, combustion or process equipment or any equipment pertaining thereto for use within the incorporated areas of the city until an application including suitable plans and specifications of the equipment and structures or buildings used in connection therewith has been filed in duplicate by the person or his agent in the office of the pollution control officer and an installation permit has been issued by the building inspector. 
(b)  The plans and specifications shall show the form and dimension of the fuel-burning, combustion or process equipment, the proposed boiler, furnace, fuel burner stack, ducts, drains and sewer connections, together with the description and dimensions of the building or part thereof in which such equipment is to be located, the character of the fuel to be used, the maximum quantity of such fuel to be burned per hour, the character and concentration of liquid wastes, the operating requirements and the use to be made of the equipment. 
(c)  In the case of routine maintenance work or minor alterations or repairs which do not adversely affect the production, emission or discharge of smoke, dust, fly ash, soot, fumes, solid or gaseous product of combustion, solid or liquid waste products, this section shall not apply. 
(d)  In the case of an emergency repair where serious consequences would otherwise result this section shall not apply; provided that application for the necessary installation permit is filed in accordance with this section on the first business day following the commencement of the repair work. 
(e)  If the proposed plans and specifications submitted pursuant to this section are not sufficiently complete, in the judgment of the pollution control officer, to show that the equipment or device for which such plans and specifications were submitted will consistently comply with and can be operated within the provisions of this chapter, by reason of the design or process being unconventional or untried; or because the person has elected to omit confidential details; or because there is insufficient data on which to estimate the air pollution potential, the pollution control officer is hereby authorized to require as a condition precedent to the issuance of an installation permit or certificate of operation proof of financial responsibility and ability to make any changes that may be required after the construction to insure compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Such proof, in the discretion of the pollution control officer, may be a written statement to such effect, signed by the owner or a responsible officer of a financially sound organization or a written guarantee of performance signed by a responsible supplier or contractor or other responsible person. The responsibility of any such person or soundness of any such organization shall be a matter within the judgment of the pollution control officer, subject to the right of appeal. 
(f)  In the event that he is not given adequate proof of financial responsibility and of ability to make any changes that may be required, the pollution control officer may require any such person, as owner, lessee, operator, supplier, contractor, vendor, or other person, to file with the pollution control officer a surety bond running to the city in the sum of not to exceed fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), executed by such person or persons, as principal and two (2) or more sureties, or a surety company authorized to do business in this state. 
(Ord. No. 1068, §§ 4.1-1—4.1-4, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-8. - Work to be commenced within one year; extension. 
If construction, installation or alteration is not started within one year of the date of the installation permit, the permit shall become void and all fees shall be forfeited. An extension, not to exceed six (6) months, may be granted by the council, upon proper application. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 4.1-5, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-9. - Operating permit for fuel-burning equipment. 
After any work of erecting, constructing, reconstructing, installing, altering or repairing any fuel-burning equipment is completed, the pollution control officer shall inspect the same; and, if such work conforms to the application, plans and specifications filed and to the provisions of this chapter, there shall be issued a permit, known as an operating permit, to the person to whom the installation permit was issued, which operating permit shall be posted in a conspicuous position adjacent to the equipment. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 4.1-6, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-10. - Violations subsequent to construction. 
The authorization of the issuance by the pollution control officer of any installation permit or operating permit shall not be held to exempt the person to whom the permit has been issued or who is in possession of the same, from prosecution for violation of provisions of this chapter. 
If, at the time of the annual inspection, it is found that the equipment is in such condition that it cannot be operated within the provisions of this chapter, the pollution control officer is hereby authorized to give notice in writing to the person owning, operating or in charge of such equipment of the defects found and an order to correct, repair or replace the defective equipment. Failure to comply with this order within thirty (30) days from its date shall be a violation of this section and the pollution control officer is hereby authorized to seal the equipment. No person shall violate the seal on any equipment that has been sealed at the direction of the pollution control officer unless authorized by him in writing to do so. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 4.1-7, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-11. - Variances. 
The council is hereby given authority for the granting of individual variances for any fuel-burning, combustion or process equipment or device, beyond the limitations prescribed in this chapter whenever it is found, upon the presentation of adequate proof, that compliance with any provision of this chapter or other ordinance relating to pollution, or any rule, regulation, requirement or order of the pollution control officer, will result in an arbitrary and unreasonable taking of property or in the practical closing and elimination of any lawful business, occupation or activity, in either case without a sufficient corresponding benefit or advantage to the people in the reduction of pollution; in such case, there shall be prescribed other and different requirements, not more onerous, applicable to plants or equipment involved. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 4.2, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-12. - Extension of time for compliance with chapter. 
In the event any person is compelled to, or deems it advisable to, install any new equipment, processes or devices, appliances, means or methods, including needed pollution control equipment, in order to comply with any provisions of this chapter, such person may obtain a continuance in order to effect such compliance in accordance with the following procedure. To obtain such continuance, a written request shall be filed with the pollution control officer by any such person and shall set forth that, following normal good operating procedures, it is impossible in the operation of any plant, fuel-burning, combustion or process equipment or devices or apparatus, to operate the same in compliance with the requirements of this chapter. Said requests shall also state evidence satisfactory to the pollution control officer that such person has taken, or will take, all steps necessary to provide for future compliance with the provisions of this chapter. The pollution control officer shall be assured that the acquisition and installation of the proper equipment, processes, devices or appliances or control equipment, will be effected within the period of time specified. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 4.3, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-13. - Fees. 
Fees required for permits, certificates and inspection of equipment and other sources of emissions shall be as prescribed in Appendix G. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 4.4, 11-2-70; Ord. No. 11-O-0007, § 39, 5-16-2011)  
Sec. 14-14. - Persons liable for violations. 
All persons, owning, operating or in charge or control of any equipment who violate or cause, suffer or allow any violation of this chapter either as owners, occupants, managers or agents, shall be jointly and severally liable to the penalties imposed for such violations. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 4.5, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-15. - Air quality standards. 
(a)  Purpose: Air quality standards are ambient air quality goals established for the purpose of protecting public health and welfare. The levels of air quality designated by the standards are designed to protect against injury to human, plant or animal life; they are further intended to allow maximum enjoyment of property consistent with the intent of this chapter. 
The first use of air resources is to sustain life. Air entering the respiratory tract must not menace health. Therefore, the air quality standards herein set forth must, as a minimum, provide air which will not adversely affect through acute or chronic symptoms, the health of the community. 
The air quality standards herein set forth will provide a basis for planning to achieve cleaner air. Even though in certain areas of the city the quality of the air may be lower than the standards, they are not a license allowing unnecessary degradation of the air, going against the intent of the act which requires a maintenance of the purity of the air resources of the state. 
The standards have also been designed for use as a basis for the development of implementation plans for the abatement and control of pollutant emissions from existing sources including development of air contaminant emission limitations and the setting of long-and short-range objectives for reduction of total emission of air contaminants as determined by emission inventories. And they will be used in the determination of air pollution control emission limitations for future installations to insure that urban and economic growth trends do not add to community air pollution problems. 
(b)  Established: Ambient air quality standards applicable in those positions of West Chicago, Illinois: 
Suspended Particulates Micrograms/cubic meter 	Interim Goal 	Standard 
Date to meet value 	January 1, 1972 	January 1, 1974 
Geometric Mean 	100 	75 
99% Point 	275 	200

1 hour Maximum 		0.50 
 
(c)  Open fires: No person shall cause, suffer, allow or permit open burning of refuse or other matter. 
(d)  Prohibited discharges: A person shall not discharge into the atmosphere from any single source of emission any air contaminants for a period or periods aggregating more than three (3) minutes in any one hour which is: 
(1)  As dark or darker in shade as that designated as No. 1 on the Ringelmann Chart, or 
(2)  Of such opacity as to obscure an observer's view to a degree equal to or greater than does smoke described in subsection (1) of this section. 
(e)  Nuisance: A person shall not discharge from any source whatsoever such quantities of air contaminants or other material which cause injury, detriment, nuisance or annoyance to any other person or to the public or which endanger the comfort, repose, health or safety of any such persons or the public or which cause or have a natural tendency to cause injury or damage to business or property. 
(f)  Particulate matter: A person shall not discharge into the atmosphere from any source particulate matter in excess of 0.10 grains per standard cubic foot of gas at standard atmospheric conditions. 
(g)  Specific contaminants: 
(1)  Sulfur Dioxide Limitation: 
a.  No person shall cause or permit the use of or if intended for use in the city the purchase, sale, offers for sale, storage or transportation of fuel which, as determined by the methods of the American Society for Testing and Materials, contains more than the following percentage of sulfur by weight: 
1.  For a period of two (2) years, beginning one year after November 2, 1970: fuel: 2.5 percent; 
2.  For a period of eighteen (18) months, beginning three (3) years after November 2, 1970: fuel: 2.0 percent; 
3.  Thereafter: fuel: 1.5 percent. 
b.  Upon the application of any person engaged in the operation of fuel-burning equipment, the pollution control officer with the approval of the council may issue a certificate of operation in those cases wherein the applicant shall establish that the fuel-burning equipment is operated in such a manner or is equipped with such control apparatus, as to continually prevent the emission of any sulfur compound or compounds in amounts greater than those that would be emitted from the burning (in the same fuel-burning equipment without such control apparatus) of fuel containing any amount permitted at the applicable time by this section. 
c.  When periods of stagnation, for twenty-four (24) hours or greater, occur, the pollution control officer with council approval shall have the power to implement a pollution incident control plan, whereby plants are required either to switch to a low sulfur fuel (less than 1.5% sulfur by weight) or curtail emission of sulfur dioxide pollution during this period until the pollution control officer determines that the stagnation period no longer exists. 
d.  Any series of articles, machines, equipment or other contrivances designed for processing a moving sheet, web, strip or wire which is subject to any combination of operations described in this subsection (g) involving any photochemically reactive solvent or material containing such solvent, shall be subject to compliance with this subsection (g). Where only non-photo-chemically reactive solvents or materials containing only such solvents are employed or applied, and where any portion or portions of said series of articles, machines, equipment or other contrivances involves operations described in this subsection (g), said portions shall be collectively subject to compliance with this subsection (g). 
(h)  Organic material: 
(1)  A person shall not discharge organic materials into the atmosphere in any one day from any article, machine, equipment or other contrivance in excess of the following quantities: 
a.  More than fifteen (15) pounds when any organic solvent comes into contact with flame or is baked, heat cured or heat-polymerized, in the presence of oxygen, unless all organic materials have been reduced either by at least eighty-five (85) percent overall or to not more than fifteen (15) pounds in any one day. 
b.  More than forty (40) pounds when employing, applying, evaporating or drying any photochemically reactive solvent or material containing such solvent unless all organic materials have been reduced either by at least eighty-five (85) percent overall or to not more than forty (40) pounds in any one day. 
Emissions of organic materials to the atmosphere from the cleanup with photochemically reactive solvents of any article, machine, equipment or other contrivance described in subsection (1)a. or (1)b., shall be included with the other emissions of organic materials from that article, machine, equipment or other contrivance for determining compliance with this chapter. 
(3)  Emissions of organic materials to the atmosphere as a result of spontaneously continuing dry or products for the first twelve (12) hours after their removal from any article, machine, equipment or other contrivance described in subsection (1)a. or (1)b. shall be included with other emissions of organic materials from that article, machine, equipment or other contrivance for determining compliance with this chapter. 
(4)  Any person using organic solvents or any materials containing organic solvents shall supply the pollution control officer, upon request and in the manner and form prescribed by him, written evidence of the chemical composition, physical properties and amount consumed for each organic solvent used. 
(5)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
a.  The manufacture of organic solvents or the transportation or storage of organic solvents. 
b.  The spraying or other employment of insecticides, pesticides or herbicides. 
c.  The employment, application, evaporation or drying of saturated halogenated hydrocarbons or perchloroethylene. 
(6)  No person shall, during any one day, dispose of a total of more than one and one-half (1½) gallons of any photochemically reactive solvent or any material containing more than one and one-half (1½) gallons of any such solvent by any means which will permit the evaporation of such solvent into the atmosphere. 
(Ord. No. 1068, §§ 5.1-1—5.4-8, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-16. - Particulate matter. 
(a)  No person shall cause or permit particulate matter to be handled, transported or stored in a manner which allows or may allow the particulate matter to become airborne. 
(b)  No person shall cause or permit a building or its appurtenances or a road to be constructed, altered, repaired or demolished without taking such precautions as may be required by the pollution control officer to prevent particulate matter from becoming airborne. 
(c)  No person shall cause or permit untreated open areas to be maintained without taking reasonable precautions to prevent particulate matter from becoming airborne. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 5.5, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-17. - Odors. 
No person shall cause or permit the emission of odorous air contaminants, including any air contaminants whose emission is not otherwise prohibited by this article, if the air contaminants cause or may cause detriment to the health, safety, welfare or comfort of any person. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 6.1, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-18. - Toxics. 
No activity or operation shall cause, at any time, the discharge of toxic matter into the atmosphere in such concentrations as to be detrimental to or endanger the public health, safety or welfare, or cause injury or damage to property or business, or be needlessly destructive of any insect, plant or animal life which contributes to the general welfare. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 7.1, 11-2-70)  
Sec. 14-19. - Tests. 
(a)  If the pollution control officer has reasonable cause to believe that any equipment or fuel is in violation of this chapter, the pollution control officer may order the owner or lessee of the equipment or fuel, or his agent, to conduct and pay for such tests as are necessary in the opinion of the pollution control officer to determine whether the equipment or fuel is in violation of this chapter and to submit the test results to the pollution control officer within ten (10) days after the tests are completed. 
(b)  Such tests shall be conducted in a manner approved by the pollution control officer. If any part of the test is conducted at a place other than the site where the equipment or fuel is located, that part of the test shall be certified by a responsible laboratory. 
(c)  The owner or lessee, or his agent, shall notify the pollution control officer of the time and place of a test at least seven (7) days before the commencement of a test. Reasonable facilities shall be made available for the pollution control officer to witness the test. 
(Ord. No. 1068, §§ 8.1-1—8.1-3, 11-2-70)  
Secs. 14-20—14-29. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENT IN CONNECTION WITH ZONING AND SUBDIVISION MATTERS 
 
Sec. 14-30. - Policy and intent. 
In concert with enhancing and preserving environmental quality, it is the policy of the city to use all practicable means and measures to create and maintain conditions under which man and nature can exist in productive harmony and fulfill the social, economic and other requirements of present and future generations. Every citizen has a responsibility to contribute to the preservation and enhancement of the quality of the environment. There is a need to understand the relationship between the maintenance of high-quality ecological systems and the general welfare of the people of the city, including their enjoyment of the natural resources of the city. It is the intent of the city that the protection and enhancement of the environment shall be given appropriate weight with social and economic considerations in public policy. Social, economic, and environmental factors shall be considered together in reaching decisions on proposed activities. In order to carry out the provisions of this article, it is the continuing responsibility of the city to use all practicable means, consistent with other essential considerations, to improve and coordinate plans, functions, programs and resources to the end that the city may: 
(1)  Fulfill the responsibilities of each generation as trustee of the environment for succeeding generations; 
(2)  Assure for all citizens, safe, healthful, productive, and aesthetically and culturally pleasing surroundings; 
(3)  Attain the widest range of beneficial uses of the environment without degradation, risk to health or safety or other undesirable and unintended consequences; 
(4)  Preserve important historic, cultural and natural aspects of our heritage, and maintain, wherever possible, an environment which supports diversity and variety of individual choice; 
(5)  Achieve a balance between growth and resource use which will permit high standards of living and a wide sharing of life's amenities; and 
(6)  Enhance the quality of renewable resources and approach the optimum attainable recycling of depletable resources. 
(Ord. No. 1254, § 1, 10-21-74)  
Sec. 14-31. - When statement required. 
Every applicant whose zoning matter or subdivision matter is referred to the city shall file an environmental impact statement with the city administrator. The requirement for an environmental impact statement does not apply to actions limited to a single-family dwelling to be used as a residence, nor extensions, enlargements, additions, changes or alterations thereof, nor ancillary structures thereon. 
(Ord. No. 1254, § 2, 10-21-74)  
Sec. 14-32. - Waiver of article provisions. 
The provisions of this article may be waived by the city council whenever the applicant has previously filed with the city an acceptable environmental impact statement for the same property and there has been no substantial change in the project or activity. Waiver may also be granted by the city council whenever an environmental impact statement acceptable to the council has been submitted and approved by another governmental unit. Applicants seeking waiver shall file a request for waiver. Such request shall be granted or denied by the city council within thirty (30) days of being filed. 
(Ord. No. 1254, § 3, 10-21-74)  
Sec. 14-33. - Applicant to receive copy of article; copies of statement to be sent city agencies. 
Promptly upon referral to the city of a zoning matter or subdivision matter, the city administrator shall send the applicant a copy of this article. 
The city administrator shall promptly, upon receipt of a referral, send notice of the proposed change with applicable environmental impact statement when filed, to the members of the plan commission and/or zoning board and other appropriate city committees and shall provide public notice of the availability of copies of the environmental impact statement. 
(Ord. No. 1254, § 4, 10-21-74)  
Sec. 14-34. - Contents of statement. 
Each environmental impact statement prepared in accordance with this article shall include: 
(1)  A description of the proposed action. 
(2)  A description of the existing environmental setting. 
(3)  The favorable and adverse environmental impacts of the proposed action. 
(4)  The means and estimated costs necessary to minimize the adverse impacts. 
(5)  Identification of alternatives to the proposed action including their impact on the environment. 
(6)  Identification of any irreversible commitment of natural resources as a result of the proposed action. 
(7)  The growth-inducing aspects of the proposed action as related to natural resources. 
The city administrator may issue further guidelines clarifying the above as directed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1254, § 5, 10-21-74)  
Sec. 14-35. - Application of article to city. 
The city declares its intention to subject its own designated actions to scrutiny on environmental considerations by providing a public environmental impact statement for review by the plan commission and/or zoning board and its citizens. 
(Ord. No. 1254, § 6, 10-21-74)  
Sec. 14-36. - Application of article to other governmental units. 
The city administrator is hereby directed to contact any state or local governmental unit proposing to engage in any activity having substantial environmental relevance in or near the city and to request that unit to cooperate fully with the city in carrying out the intent of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1254, § 7, 10-21-74)  
Secs. 14-37—14-39. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STORM WATER CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1370, § 1, adopted May 15, 1978, specifically amended the Code by adding Art. III, §§ 14-40—14-47, as herein set out. 
 
Sec. 14-40. - Intent and purpose. 
(a)  This article is adopted for the purpose of improving and protecting the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare of the people. These purposes are accomplished by the following objectives: 
(1)  To insure and preserve the natural resources of the city. 
(2)  To prevent the flooding and inundation of land by surface water, in its natural, accumulated, dammed or impounded state. 
(3)  To conserve and maintain the taxable value of land and buildings throughout the city. 
(4)  To avoid the inappropriate development of lands and to provide for adequate drainage, the cessation of erosion and reduction of flood damage. 
(5)  To fix reasonable standards to which ponds, dams, runoffs and spillways shall conform. 
(6)  To prevent such additions to, and alterations or remodeling of, existing storm water storage area as would not comply with the restrictions and limitations imposed herein. 
(7)  To foster a more rational pattern of relationship between residential, business, commercial and manufacturing uses for the mutual benefit of all so far as concerns surface water. 
(8)  To isolate or control the location of unavoidable nuisance-producing uses, and to protect against damages from surface water and flooding. 
(9)  To define the powers and duties of the administrative and enforcement officers and bodies. 
(10)  To prescribe penalties for any violation of the provisions of this article, or of any amendment thereto. 
(b)  The standards and requirements contained in this article are intended to implement the objectives of the comprehensive plan for the City of West Chicago, the provisions of Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 109, Section 2, and the floodplain statute and other statutes and ordinances pertaining thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1370, § 1, 5-15-78)  
Sec. 14-41. - Scope of regulations. 
(a)  All storm water storage areas erected hereafter shall be subject to this article. 
(b)  All storm water storage areas built hereafter shall comply with this article. Any structure rebuilt or restored after damage or destruction shall be considered to be a structure built hereafter. 
(Ord. No. 1370, § 1, 5-15-78)  
Sec. 14-42. - Rules. 
[The following rules of interpretation shall be observed in the use and enforcement of this article:] 
Masculine gender includes the feminine gender. 
Measured distances, expressed in feet, shall be to the nearest tenth foot. 
Present tense includes past tense and future tense. 
Plural number includes singular. 
Singular number includes plural. 
(Ord. No. 1370, § 1, 5-15-78)  
Sec. 14-43. - Definitions. 
Whenever a word or term defined hereinafter appears in the text of this article, its meaning shall be construed as set forth in the definition thereof; and any word appearing in parenthesis, between a word and its definition herein, shall be construed in the same sense as that word. Words herein not defined shall be interpreted in accordance with applicable definitions contained in Webster's dictionary. 
Base flood and base flood elevation: As defined in Ordinance No. 1345 [Chapter 4, Article III of this Code], as amended. 
By-pass channel: A channel formed in the topography of the earth's surface to carry storm water runoff through a specific area. 
Control structure: A structure designed to control the volume of storm water runoff that passes through it during a specific length of time. 
Dry bottom storm water storage area: A facility that is designed to be normally dry and contains water only when excess storm water runoff occurs. 
Environmental impact statement: That statement required by city Ordinance No. 1254 [section 14-30 et seq. of this Code], as amended. 
Excess storm water: That portion of storm water runoff which exceeds the transportation capacity of storm sewers or natural drainage channels serving a specific watershed. 
Ground water recharge: Replenishment of existing natural underground water supplies. 
Natural drainage: Channels formed by the existing surface topography of the earth prior to changes made by unnatural causes. 
Positive gravity outlet: A term used to describe the drainage of an area by means of natural gravity so that it lowers the free water surface to a point below the existing grade, or invert of storm drains within the area. 
Recognized agency: An agency or governmental unit that has statistically and consistently examined local and climatic and geologic conditions, and maintained records as they apply to storm water runoff, e.g., Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago, U.S. Weather Bureau, University of Illinois Engineering Experiment Station, Illinois State Water Survey, etc. 
Safe storm drainage capacity: A term used to describe the quantity of storm water runoff that can be transported by a channel or conduit without having the water surface rise above the level of the earth's surface over the conduit, or adjacent to the waterway. 
Self-cleaning velocity: A velocity of flow greater than three (3) feet per second. 
Storm water storage area: Areas designated to store excess storm water. 
Storm water runoff release rate: The rate at which storm water runoff is released from dominant to servient land. 
Storm water runoff: Water that results from precipitation which is not absorbed or detained by the soil or plant material. 
Tributary watershed: All of the area that contributes storm water runoff to a given point. 
West Chicago General Development Plan: City Ordinance No. 1260, as amended [see section 2-10 of this Code]. 
Wet bottom storm water storage area: A facility that is designed to be maintained as free-water surface or pond. 
Zoning ordinance: City Ordinance No. 717 [Appendix A of this volume], as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1370, § 1, 5-15-78)  
Sec. 14-44. - Storm water storage areas. 
(1)  Storm water storage areas shall be required in accordance with the following standards: When it is required by the city engineer, the controlled release and storage or combination thereof, of excess storm water runoff shall be required in combination for all new development for commercial, industrial, residential, planned unit developments, and special uses in the City of West Chicago. 
(2)  Storm water storage areas may be permitted under the following conditions: 
(a)  Whenever the same are requested by the owner of land located within the City of West Chicago, or within one and one-half (1½) miles from the boundary thereof. 
(b)  The said owner has complied with subsection 14-44(3) through (6) of this article. 
(3)  Whenever storm water storage areas are to be constructed and/or used within the city, or [within] one and one-half (1½) miles thereof, the owner shall not build, nor use the same, without obtaining a permit so to do. 
(4)  The owner shall submit to the city administrator of the City of West Chicago an application for a storm water storage area permit, on a form provided together with the following documents, and a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), plus any costs in excess of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(a)  A survey of the lands to be served by said storm water storage area, to a scale not smaller than one inch equals one hundred feet (1"=100'), spotting to said scale the storm water storage area to be constructed or used thereon. 
(b)  A topographic survey of the land to be served by said storm water storage area, to a scale, not smaller than one inch equals one hundred feet (1"=100'), showing two-foot contours, spotting to said scale the storm water storage area to be constructed or used thereon. 
(c)  Drawings showing the plan and cross-sections of said storm water storage area to a scale of not smaller than one inch equals forty feet (1"=40') and specifications, with detail to show compliance, or noncompliance with subsection 14-44(5) through (5.1) of this article. 
(d)  All calculations used in determining the final design of the storm water storage area, outfall structure and storm sewers. 
(e)  Items (4)(a), (b), (c), and (d) of this section shall be certified by a registered professional engineer or a land surveyor of the State of Illinois, as applicable. 
(f)  An environmental impact statement stating the effect upon the environment within the drainage basin served by the construction of the storm water storage area. Such statement should be in such detail as to show factual reasons for the conclusions set forth, and shall consider all facets of the natural environment. A list of the names and addresses of all the record owners of such land where such environmental impact shall be required shall be attached. 
(g)  A sworn statement signed by the owner listing all items of a nonnatural nature, to be damaged, covered or destroyed by the construction and use of said storm water storage area. 
(h)  A statement by the owner supported by plans and drawings, if required, showing the changes in drainage, if any, of the area lying within the drainage basin of said storm water storage area. 
(i)  A statement by the owner of the proposed maintenance of said storm water storage area. 
(j)  A statement, by the owner, suggesting uses the said city may make, other than retention of surface water, of the completed storm water storage area. 
(5)  The construction of storm water storage areas shall be in accordance with the following design standards: 
(a)  The controlled release of storm water runoff from all developments described in section 14-44(1), shall not exceed the existing safe storm drainage capacity of the natural downstream outlet channel or storm sewer system. The release rate shall be an average value computed as a direct ration to the tributary watershed area. In any case, this value shall not exceed fifteen hundredths (0.15) inches per hour from an area designed to provide storage from excess storm water. The rate at which storm water runoff is transported into a designated storage area may be determined by the design engineer, but in no case shall the velocity be below self-cleaning velocity for a storm sewer flowing full. 
(b)  The required volume for storm water detention shall be calculated on the basis of the runoff from a 100-year return frequency rainfall for the critical duration for the basin size, as published by a recognized agency. This volume of storage shall be provided for the fully developed watershed that is tributary to the area designated for detention purposes. The storm water release rate shall be considered when calculating the storm water storage capacity, and the control structure designed to maintain a relatively uniform flow rate regardless of depth of storm water in the storage area. The required storm water storage area volume shall not be located below the base flood elevation, as defined in the Corps of Engineers Flood Insurance Study for the City of West Chicago, May, 1977, as amended. 
(c)  Detention reservoirs or dry bottom storm water storage areas shall be designed to serve a secondary purpose for recreation, open space or other types of uses that will not be adversely affected by occasional or intermittent flooding. A method of carrying the low flow through these areas shall be provided in addition to a system of drains, and both shall be provided with a positive gravity outlet to a natural channel or other storm sewer facility with adequate capacity according to the definition of the term "safe storm drainage capacity." 
The combination of storage of the water from a 100-year storm and the design release rate shall not result in a storage duration in excess of seventy-two (72) hours. Maximum depths of planned storm water storage shall not exceed four (4) feet, unless the existing natural ground contours and other conditions lend themselves to greater storage depth, which shall be approved by the city engineer. Minimum grades for turf areas shall be two (2) percent, and maximum slopes shall be ten (10) percent ten (10) units horizontally to one unit vertically). Storage area side slopes shall be kept as close to the natural land contours as practical, and a ten (10) percent slope or less shall be used wherever possible. If slopes greater than ten (10) percent are necessary to meet storage requirements or area restrictions, approval shall be obtained from the city engineer. All detention ponds shall be seeded or sodded to control erosion, and constructed in accordance to the methods specified in "Standard Specifications for Soil Erosion and Sediment Control," as published by the soil and water conservation district. Outlet control structures shall be designed as simply as possible, and shall require little or no maintenance and/or attention for proper operation. Each storm water storage area shall be provided with a method of emergency overflow in the event that a storm in excess of the 100-year return frequency storm occurs. This emergency overflow facility shall be designed to function without maintenance and/or attention, and shall become part of the natural or surface channel system described in a preceding paragraph. Hydraulic calculations shall be submitted to substantiate all design features. Both outlet control structures and emergency overflow facilities shall be designed and constructed to fully protect the public health, safety and welfare. Storm water runoff velocities shall be kept to a minimum and turbulent conditions at an outfall control structure will not be permitted without complete protection for the public safety. The use of restrictive fences shall be kept to a minimum and shall be used only as a last resort when no other method is feasible. 
(d)  Retention reservoir or wet bottom storm water storage areas shall be designed with all of the items required for detention reservoir storage areas, except that a low flow conduit and a system of drains with a positive gravity outlet shall not be required. However, the following additional conditions shall be complied with: 
1.  Water surface area shall not exceed one-tenth ( 1/10 ) of the tributary drainage area. 
2.  Shoreline protection shall be provided to prevent erosion from wave action. 
3.  Minimum normal water depth shall be four (4) feet. If fish are to be used to keep the pond clean, a minimum of one-fourth (¼) of the pond area shall be a minimum of ten (10) feet deep. 
4.  Facilities shall be available, if possible, to allow the pond level to be lowered by gravity flow for cleaning purposes and shoreline maintenance. 
5.  Control structures for storm water release shall be designed to operate at full capacity with only a minor increase in the water surface level. Hydraulic calculations shall be submitted to substantiate all design features. 
6.  Aeration facilities to prevent pond stagnation, if required, shall be provided. Design calculations to substantiate the effectiveness of these aeration facilities shall be submitted with final engineering plans. 
7.  In the event that the water surface of the pond is to be raised for purposes of storing water for irrigation or in anticipation of the evapotranspiration demands of dry weather, the volume remaining for storage of excess storm water runoff shall still be sufficient to contain the 100-year storm runoff. 
(e)  Paved surfaces that are to serve as storm water storage areas shall have minimum grades of one percent, and shall be restricted to a storage depth of one foot maximum. Rooftop storage shall be designed with permanent-type control inlets and parapet walls to contain runoff on the rooftop. Emergency overflow areas shall be provided to insure that the weight of water stored will not exceed the structural capacity of the roof. Release rate and storage volume requirements for paved storage areas shall be as hereinabove outlined in subparagraphs (a) and (b). If a portion of an area within a storm water storage area is to be paved for parking or recreational purposes, the paved surface shall be placed at the highest elevation within the storage area as possible. 
(f)  Where developments form only a portion of a watershed or contain portions of several watersheds, the requirements for providing storage shall be based upon that proportion of the area being developed as compared to the total watershed tributary to the storage area. Compensating storage will be acceptable whenever it is justified and feasible. 
(g)  The ability to retain and maximize the ground water recharge capacity of the area being developed is encouraged. Design of the storm water runoff control system shall give due consideration to providing ground water recharge to compensate for the reduction in the percolation that occurs when the ground surface is paved and/or roofed over. Specific design calculations and details shall be provided with the final plans and specifications presented for review. The use of natural gravel deposits for the lower portions of storm runoff storage areas, the flattening of drainage slopes and the retention of existing topography are samples of possible recharge methods. 
(h)  Where development of a property presents the threat of flooding or damage by flash runoff to downstream residents, the facilities for storm water runoff control shall be constructed prior to any earthmoving or drainage construction on the project site. 
(i)  The construction of the storm water control system shall be accomplished as part of the cost of land development. If the amount of storage capacity can be increased to provide benefit to the municipality, negotiations for public participation in the cost of development may be feasible. 
(j)  During the construction phases of land development, facilities shall be provided to prevent the erosion and washing away of the earth. Silting of downstream areas can be prevented through the strategic use of stilling basins, sodding of runoff channels, and by limiting the period of time during which the earth is stripped of vegetation. 
(k)  Final engineering plans shall show complete details for all of the items covered in this article and shall be submitted for review and approved prior to the start of construction. 
(5.1)  A floodway for all tributary upstream areas shall be provided in accordance with the following standards: A "natural" or surface channel system shall be designed with adequate capacity to convey through the development the storm water runoff from all tributary upstream areas. This "by-pass" channel shall be designed to carry the peak rate of runoff from a base flood assuming all storm sewers are blocked and that the upstream areas are fully developed and have been saturated with antecedent rainfall. No habitable structures shall be constructed within this floodway; however, streets and parking or playground areas and utility easements shall be considered compatible uses. Design of this floodway system shall also take into consideration control of storm water velocity to prevent erosion or other damage to the facility which will restrict its primary use. Depths of flow shall be kept to a minimum and retention of channel configurations shall be totally under municipal control. In the event that the area within this "by-pass" channel is re-shaped or restricted for use as a floodway, the municipality will cause to have any restrictions removed at the expense of the party or parties causing said restriction. Should the development contain an existing "natural" waterway, this land configuration shall be preserved as part of the "by-pass" channel system. Construction of a "low flow" system of storm sewers to carry the minor storm runoff and re-shaping of the channel with a maximum of six (6) horizontal to one vertical side slopes and bottom of a width adequate to facilitate maintenance and carry the flood runoff without eroding velocities shall be included in the plans for land development. 
(6)  The owner of said storm water storage area shall place, with the city, a cash escrow fund, letter of credit, or other security in an amount not less than one hundred twenty-five (125) percent of the estimated construction cost, as prepared by a registered professional engineer and as approved by the city attorney and city engineer, to guarantee that construction shall be in accordance with all statutes, laws and ordinances governing the same, and, such security shall not be released until the city engineer of the City of West Chicago certifies that the same has been so completed. 
(Ord. No. 1370, § 1, 5-15-78)  
Sec. 14-45. - Hearings and fact finding. 
(1)  When all the documents set forth in section 14-44(4) have been submitted to the city administrator, and show that the proposed storm water storage area serves an area greater than ten (10) acres or that the storm water storage area is proposed to be dedicated to the City of West Chicago, the administrator shall cause the documents to be delivered to the secretary of the plan commission. 
(2)  Upon reviewing said documents, the said secretary shall: 
(a)  Schedule, within sixty (60) days, a public hearing on said application. 
(b)  Cause a publication of such hearing to be made in a newspaper of general circulation within said city for three (3) consecutive weeks, the first publication to be not more than twenty-eight (28) days from the date of the hearing. 
(c)  Serve notice by depositing the same in the United States mail to all persons, at the address shown, set forth in section 14-44(4)(f). 
(d)  The public hearing shall be conducted as follows: 
i.  The plan commission shall hear any and all testimony and evidence offered relevant to the storm water storage area. 
ii.  The hearing may be continued from time to time by the plan commission. 
iii.  Within thirty (30) days from the final hearing on said application, the plan commission shall recommend, or not recommend, to the city council, a plan for the designated use of said storm water area, taking into account the guidelines pertaining thereto in this article, and other ordinances of the City of West Chicago and statutes of the United States of America and the State of Illinois. 
(e)  The city council may either approve, disapprove, or amend said recommendation, and, if not disapproved, forward the same to the engineering department for plan review. Said engineering department shall, if said plan conforms with this article, forthwith issue a permit. 
(3)  When the area served by a proposed storm water storage area is less than ten (10) acres, or the proposed storm water storage area is to be private, the hearing and fact finding requirements of subsections (1) and (2) shall be waived. 
(Ord. No. 1370, § 1, 5-15-78)  
Sec. 14-46. - Use and maintenance of said storm water storage area. 
(1)  Each and every storm water storage area plan, approved as above set forth, shall be designated and used as follows: 
(a)  Either: 
1.  Public. In which event it shall be dedicated, with sufficient land around said pond as to compatibly secure its use by the City of West Chicago, in accordance with rules and regulations adopted by the city council, from time to time, for one of the following uses: 
(aa)  Environmental: Whenever, in the opinion of the plan commission, it receives an environmental statement, as herein provided, or otherwise, to the effect that the area served by said storm water storage area or the storm water storage area itself, has a positive impact on a unique part or portion of the environment, then, and in that event, said storm water storage area shall be designated for "environmental use," and its construction, operation and maintenance shall also be directed towards that end. 
(bb)  Recreational: Whenever, in the opinion of the plan commission, it believes that the area served by said storm water storage area, or the storm water storage area itself, can best be used by the citizens of the City of West Chicago, for recreational purposes, then, and in that event said storm water storage area shall be designated for "recreational use" and its construction, operation and maintenance shall also be diverted towards that end. 
2.  Whenever a storm water storage area is not, as hereinbefore provided, designated a public use, then, and in that event, it shall be designated as a private storm water storage area. 
(b)  Whenever a storm water storage area is designated a public use, hereinabove, then, and in that event, the land used for such storm water storage area, and so much additional land as shall allow proper use for the public use so designated, shall be dedicated to the city. 
(2)  Maintenance: 
(a)  Public. Whenever a storm water storage area is designated a public use hereinabove, the maintenance of said storm water storage area, as well as the public use, other than as a storm water storage area, shall be the responsibility of the city. 
(b)  Private use: Whenever a storm water storage area is designated a private storm water storage area under section 14-46(1)(1)2., hereinabove, then, and in that event, the following maintenance shall be provided: 
1.  The design, storage capacity and other features of the storm water storage area shall be maintained at all times. The city engineer shall make periodic inspections to determine if the storm water storage area is being maintained in accordance with the original design and provides the required controlled release and storage of excess storm water for the area served. In the event the city engineer determines any deficiencies exist in a privately owned storm water storage area, the city engineer shall take action in accordance with section 14-47. 
2.  The owner, planner or developer shall present to the city council for its approval, a plan to finance, in perpetuity, the maintenance above required. 
3.  In the event, for any reason whatsoever, the maintenance of said private retention pond, is no longer required, any sums, of any nature, kind, or description, placed with the city, or under its management or control, for maintenance shall become the sole and exclusive funds of the city and may be used by it for any purpose whatsoever. 
In the event a private retention pond shall, at a former date, have been determined to be a private retention pond and the owner of the same determines that the use has so changed, so that in effect said retention pond fits the definition of a public retention pond, as herein set forth, he may file a petition herein setting forth such facts with the city administrator, together with all the documents required in section 14-44(4) hereof, and shall be accompanied by a deposit fee of one hundred five dollars ($105.00), plus any costs in excess of one hundred five dollars ($105.00). Upon receipt of all of the required documents, the petition shall be heard in accordance with the proceedings set forth in section 14-45 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 1370, § 1, 5-15-78; Ord. No. 1429, § 1, 7-2-79)  
Sec. 14-47. - Adherence to approved drainage plans; enforcement appeal and penalties. 
(a)  Adherence to approved plans. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to construct or improve any structure, to grade or do any earth moving, to construct or improve any by-pass channel or storm water storage area, or to install any control structure, on any property subject to this article, or on any property for which final engineering plans have been approved pursuant to this article, except as provided for in such final engineering plans as are approved pursuant to this article. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any property which has been improved, graded or developed in accordance with final engineering plans approved pursuant to this article or upon which a control structure has been installed or a by-pass channel or storm water storage area has been constructed in accordance with such engineering plans, to alter or change any structure, grade, contour line, by-pass channel or storm water storage area in contravention of such approved engineering plans; to alter or remove any control structure required by such approved engineering plans; or to allow the property to remain or become in a condition which does not conform to such approved engineering plans in any respect. 
(b)  Enforcement. The city engineer is hereby authorized and directed to enforce all of the provisions of this article. The city engineer and his duly authorized representatives may enter, at reasonable times, upon any property within the city to investigate or ascertain the condition of the subject property in regard to any aspect regulated by this article. 
(c)  Duty of property owner. It shall be the duty of the owner of any property required to be improved, developed or maintained in conformance with final engineering plans approved pursuant to this article to bring such property into compliance with said engineering plans within a specified time or receipt of notice from the city engineer, that a determination has been made that the said property does not conform to final engineering plans under which said property was improved or developed. 
(d)  Penalties. Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall be penalized as provided in section 1-8 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1370, § 1, 5-15-78)
