Note: If a vehicle requires a permit due to multiple weight and/or dimension issues, the total fee will be based on the highest individual weight or dimension fee. Any application for a permit which exceeds the maximum weight and dimensions listed in schedule (e) is subject to special assessment fees at the discretion of the chief of police or his designee. 
(f)  Police escorts are generally required for vehicles operating under a valid overweight or over dimension permit which exceeds the weight and size limits described in schedule (e), and when, in the discretion of the police chief or his designee, is necessary to protect life safety, traffic flow and infrastructure. 
(g)  The permittee must make all arrangements with the police department at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the move. 
(h)  Fees for police escort, when required, shall be in addition to the permit fees. The applicant shall pay the cost for a police vehicle escort at the minimum overtime rate of the highest salaried police officer and per any collective bargaining agreement. 
(i)  The chief of police or his designee is authorized to approve the application for approved routes. Upon approval and payment of all required fees, the city shall issue a permit allowing passage of the oversize and/or overweight vehicles over city streets. The permit shall be specific and contain: 
(1)  Permit number. 
(2)  The dates the permit is valid. 
(3)  Whether the permit is for single, round or multiple trip routing. 
(4)  The description of object or vehicle to be moved. 
(5)  Authorized gross weight, axle weights, width, length and height. 
(6)  The authorized routing over city streets including the origin and termination point within the city. 
(7)  The fee paid. 
(8)  The date and signature of the chief of police or his designee. Permits issued electronically shall be considered signed by the chief of police or his designee. 
(9)  In addition, the permit will specify general conditions that the permittee must comply with that are consistent and reasonable for the protection of the general public and city streets. A copy of all permits issued will be provided to the city administrator for informational purposes. Any provisions listed on an approved permit will not be more restrictive than those afforded by the Illinois Department of Transportation (IDOT) OPER 993 form or the American Association of State and Highway Transportation Officials (AASHTO) Guidelines. 
(j)  It is the duty of the permittee to read and familiarize himself with the permit provisions upon receipt. Undertaking of the permit move is deemed prima facie evidence of acceptance of the permit and that: 
(1)  The permittee is in compliance with all operation requirements; 
(2)  All dimension and weight limitations specified in the permit will not be exceeded; 
(3)  All operation, registration and license requirements have been complied with; 
(4)  All financial responsibilities, obligations and other legal requirements have been met; and 
(5)  The permittee assumes all responsibility for injury or damage to persons or to public or private property, including his or her own, or to the object being transported, caused directly or indirectly by the transportation or movement of vehicles and objects authorized under the permit. The permittee agrees to hold the city harmless from all suits, claims, damages, or proceedings of any kind and to indemnify the city for any claim it may be required to pay arising from the movement. 
(k)  The permit shall be carried in the vehicle to which the permit applies at all times while operating on streets within the city and shall be exhibited upon demand to any law enforcement officer, police officer or authorized official of the city. Electronic display of a permit on a device which may be inspected is authorized. 
(l)  Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a city permit whether it be by size, weight or general provisions, and either or both the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty, and either or both the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. 
(m)  Vehicles prohibited on certain streets. 
(1)  As provided under the authority of ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, §§ 15-111 and 15-316, it shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle upon any street where the operation of that vehicle is prohibited by ordinance and where signs of such prohibition are posted. Vehicles operating under the authority of ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, §§ 15-111 or 15-316 shall use the most direct route to points of loading and unloading. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to park a commercial motor vehicle on a residential street while said truck is running between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. the following day. 
(n)  Oversize/weight vehicles permitted on certain streets. 
(1)  As provided under the authority of ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, § 15-111(f), the city has designated the following portions of streets and/or highways as Class II designated streets. Vehicles utilizing those as such, can be of a length consistent with ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, § 15-107 (length). 
Class II designated streets:

• Downs Drive. 
• Fenton Lane. 
• Fremont Street - between West Washington Street and Grandlake Boulevard. 
• Grandlake Boulevard - west of Fremont Street. 
• Hawthorne Lane - between Kress Road and Atlantic Drive. 
• Helena Drive. 
• Howard Drive. 
• Industrial Drive. 
• Joliet Street - between Route 38 and Brown Street. 
• Main Street - between Route 59 and Wilson Avenue. 
• Main Street - between Wilson Avenue and West Washington Street.

• Town Road - between Washington Street and the Burlington Northern Railroad Tracks.

• Western Drive.

• Winston Street. 
• Wood Street - between West Washington Street and Church Street. 
(2)  The director of public works is authorized and directed to post or cause to be posted, streets designated as class II truck routes as governed by subsection (n)(1). 
(o)  Penalty. 
(1)  Any person, firm or corporation who or which violates, disobeys, neglects, fails to comply with or resists enforcement of the provisions of this chapter will be fined according to the penalty structures provided in the Illinois Vehicle Code as adopted by Ordinance 17-1 of this Code. 
(2)  In addition to seeking a fine, as hereinabove provided, the city attorney may institute any proper action in the name of the city to enjoin the violation of any provision of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 02-O-0129, §§ 1, 2, 11-4-2002; Ord. No. 05-O-0062, § 3, 8-1-2005; Ord. No. 15-O-0006, § 1, 7-6-2015)  
Secs. 17-92—17-95. - Reserved.

(Ord. No. 2545, § 1, 5-4-92)

ARTICLE XIII. - NO-PASSING ZONES GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 17-111. - Council to designate; compliance required. 
The city council shall determine and designate those portions of any highway where overtaking and passing or driving to the left of the roadway would be especially hazardous. The city engineer shall, by appropriate signs or markings on the roadway, indicate the beginning and end of such zones. When the signs or markings are in place and clearly visible to an ordinarily observant person, every driver of a vehicle shall obey the directions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89)  
Secs. 17-112—17-115. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 17-116. - All-night parking prohibited. 
No person shall park a vehicle on any street for a period of time longer than thirty (30) minutes between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. except holders of permits for residential parking on the east side of Clayton Street. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 03-O-0024, § 2, 4-7-2003)  
Sec. 17-117. - Temporary prohibitions, police order. 
(a)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to determine and designate by proper signs places in which the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic due to events in the area including but not limited to road construction, parades, street cleaning or road maintenance. 
(b)  When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized herein no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 17-118. - After snowfall. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park or allow to remain any vehicle on any portion of any public street or highway on which there is an accumulation of snow two (2) inches or greater in depth. 
(b)  Whenever any police officer finds a vehicle in violation of this section, such officer is hereby authorized to require the driver or other person in charge of the vehicle to move the same or to provide for the removal of such vehicle to the nearest garage or other place of safety by means of towing. 
(c)  All expenses and charges incurred by reason of the towing of any vehicle under the provisions of this section and all charges for the storing of any vehicle under the provisions of this section shall be paid by the owner of the vehicle or other person legally entitled to possession thereof, and no vehicle against which there are any unpaid costs or charges under these provisions shall be released to the owner or other person legally entitled to possession thereof until all such charges and costs have been paid and fully satisfied. Notice and opportunity for hearing shall be given to the owner or other person legally entitled to possession in accordance with the applicable general orders of the police department shall be given. 
(d)  The provisions of this section are not to be construed as being in lieu of any penalty or penalties provided for elsewhere in this code or in any other ordinances for violation of the provisions of any ordinance, including this section, but are in addition thereto and are necessary for the maintenance of the free and unobstructed flow of traffic and for the direction and control thereof within the city. 
(e)  The city, its agents, employees and servants shall not be held to answer in any action or damages to any owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of any vehicle which is dealt with by them under the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 4045, § 1, 12-15-97)  
Sec. 17-119. - In alleys. 
No person shall park a vehicle within an alley. Nothing herein contained shall prohibit a person from making a delivery in an alley, but the vehicle parked for such purposes shall not be so parked for a period in excess of ten (10) minutes. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 17-120. - Violations. 
(a)  Reports. It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city acting in accordance with this Code to report: 
(1)  The vehicles occupying those areas so restricted by signs and that the vehicle is or has been parking in violation of any of the provisions of this Code. 
(2)  The state of registration and license number of each vehicle. 
(3)  The time such vehicle is parking in violation of any of the provisions of this Code. 
(4)  Any other facts, knowledge of which is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. 
(b)  Notice. Each such police officer shall also attach to such vehicle a notice to the owner or operator thereof that such vehicle has been parked in violation of this Code. Each such owner or operator may, within ten (10) days of the time when such notice of violation was attached to such vehicle, make payment to the city as follows: 
(1)  Handicapped parking violations ..... $350.00 
(2)  Tows necessary for the maintenance of the free and unobstructed flow of traffic ..... 55.00 
(3)  Parking violations at the commuter station parking lot ..... 50.00 
(4)  All other parking violations ..... 35.00 
If payment is not received within ten (10) days, the charge for each violation shall be doubled. 
Upon failure to comply with this notice, the collection of this debt shall be turned over to a collection agency or as prescribed by law. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 4376, § 1, 12-18-2000; Ord. No. 02-O-0013, § 1, 2-18-2002; Ord. No. 03-O-0085, § 9, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 11-O-0022, § 1, 5-2-2011; Ord. No. 18-O-0028, § 1, 6-4-2018)  
Sec. 17-121. - Commuter station parking lot. 
(a)  Location. The commuter parking facilities are those off-street parking facilities owned or operated by the city, generally located south of Main Street and west of Neltnor Boulevard, serving and intended for the convenience of METRA commuters. 
(b)  Designations. The commuter parking facilities shall be designated and posted as daily metered and permit parking areas; provided, however, that parking on the portion of the facilities owned by METRA shall be daily parking only. It shall be unlawful to park or to allow a vehicle to be parked in the commuter parking facilities in violation of any provision of this Code or any section of the Illinois Vehicle Code pertaining to the parking of motor vehicles. 
(c)  General parking restrictions. It shall be unlawful for the owner of a vehicle to allow that vehicle to be parked: 
(1)  In any location within the commuter parking facilities which is not a designated/marked parking space; 
(2)  In any manner other than a "head-in" position, with the vehicle driven forward into the parking space; 
(3)  In any designated handicapped parking space or portion of a handicapped parking space without displaying an official handicapped parking permit, sticker or vehicle registration plates; 
(4)  As a permit parking vehicle in a designated daily pay parking space; 
(5)  As a daily pay vehicle in a designated permit parking space; 
(6)  In a daily pay parking space without immediately depositing the daily or multiple day fee and the corresponding parking space number into a "pay-by-space" machine; or 
(7)  In a permit parking space in excess of seventy-two (72) consecutive hours. 
(d)  Hours of operation. The commuter parking facilities shall be open and the parking regulations enforced on a twenty-four (24) hour basis each day with each day commencing at 12:00 a.m. and ending at 11:59 p.m., except that no daily parking fee and/or parking permit will be required on Saturday, Sunday and the following legal holidays: 
(1)  New Year's Day; 
(2)  Memorial Day; 
(3)  Independence Day; 
(4)  Labor Day; 
(5)  Thanksgiving Day; or 
(6)  Christmas Day. 
(e)  Daily parking fee. The daily parking fee shall be as prescribed in Appendix G. 
(f)  Multiple day parking fee. A daily parking fee shall be paid for each twenty-four-hour period the vehicle occupies a specific parking space. The "pay-by-space" machines will accept payment for consecutive twenty-four-hour periods. 
(g)  Permit parking. Parking permits may be available for purchase at the City of West Chicago on a quarterly, semi-annual or yearly basis. The price of the permits shall be determined by the daily parking fee in subsection (e), plus an administrative fee to be determined by the city administrator. Vehicles occupying a parking space in the permit parking designated spaces shall display a valid city commuter parking permit in clear view handing from the rear view mirror, with the side showing the permit number and expiration date facing the front of the vehicle. 
(h)  Remedies. The owner of any vehicle in violation of this section shall be subject to fine, as provided in subsection 17-120(b)(3), and the vehicle shall be subject to towing. 
(Ord. No. 2489, § 1, 11-4-91; Ord. No. 4049, § 1, 3-18-98; Ord. No. 4354, § 1, 9-18-2000; Ord. No. 08-O-007, § 3, 2-4-2008, eff. 5-1-2008; Ord. No. 11-O-0007, § 42, 5-16-2011)  
Sec. 17-122. - Turner Court parking lot. 
(a)  Location. The Turner Court Parking Lot is the parking lot operated by the City of West Chicago, generally located west of Turner Court, south of Washington Street. 
(b)  Designations. The Turner Court Parking Lot shall be designated and posted as daily free parking and overnight permit parking only. It shall be unlawful to park or to allow a vehicle to be parked in the Turner Court Parking Lot in violation of any provision of the Code of Ordinances or any section of the Illinois Vehicle Code pertaining to the parking of motor vehicles. 
(c)  General parking restrictions. It shall be unlawful for the owner of a vehicle to allow that vehicle to be parked: 
(1)  In any location within the Turner Court Parking Lot which is not a designated/marked parking space; 
(2)  In any manner other than a "head-in" position, with the vehicle driven forward into the parking space; 
(3)  In any designated handicapped parking space or portion of a handicapped parking space without displaying an official handicapped parking permit, sticker or vehicle registration plates; 
(4)  Between 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. daily without a valid parking permit; 
(5)  In a parking space in excess of seventy-two (72) consecutive hours even with a valid permit. 
(d)  Hours of operation. The Turner Court Parking Lot shall be open and the parking regulations enforced on a twenty-four hour basis each day with each day commencing at 12:00 a.m. and ending at 11:59 p.m. 
(e)  Permit parking—Residents. Parking permits for residents living within the Turner Junction Historic District are available at the West Chicago Police Department. A maximum of two (2) permits shall be issued per dwelling unit with a maximum of forty (40) total parking permits issued. Vehicles shall display a valid City of West Chicago Turner Court Parking Lot Permit in clear view hanging from the rear view mirror with the side showing the permit number and expiration date facing the front of the vehicle. 
(f)  Permit parking—Commercial vehicles. Business owners within the Turner Junction Historic District may receive a parking permit at the West Chicago Police Department to park one (1) commercial vehicle (B-plate or lower) in the Turner Court Parking Lot. To obtain this permit, a business owner must provide proof that he has a business registered with the city and is otherwise legally operating. Five (5) spaces in the Turner Court Lot will be reserved for commercial vehicles. No parking permit shall be issued to any business owner who owes, or who has a family member who owes, the city any money for any purpose whatsoever. 
(g)  Remedies. The owner of any vehicle in violation of this section shall be subject to fine as provided in section 17-120, and the vehicle subject to towing. 
(Ord. No. 10-O-0055, § 1, 7-6-2010; Ord. No. 11-O-0026, § 1, 6-6-2011)  
Secs. 17-123—17-125. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LOADING AND UNLOADING ZONES; PUBLIC CARRIERS 
 
Sec. 17-126. - City council to designate loading and unloading zones. 
The city council shall determine and designate the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones. 
The city engineer shall install all necessary signs to implement said designated zone's restrictions, if any, and the hours during which the restrictions are applicable. All persons shall comply with the terms of the posted passenger and freight curb loading zone signs. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 17-127. - Public carrier stops; city council to designate. 
The city council shall determine and designate bus stops, bus stands, taxicab stands and stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such public streets in such places and in such number as they shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public. The city engineer shall place and maintain signs and pavement markings defining such bus stops, bus stands, taxicab stands or other stands. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89)  
Secs. 17-128—17-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PARKING RESTRICTIONS ON SPECIFIED STREETS 
 
Sec. 17-131. - Prohibited during certain hours. 
The city council shall determine and designate streets and locations within the city on which parking shall be prohibited during certain hours or at all hours. The city engineer shall place and maintain signs giving notice of the prohibition against parking. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within the area or place so designated by the city council and specified by such signs. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 4251, § 1, 11-5-99)  
Secs. 17-132—17-135. - Reserved.

ARTICLE XV. - PEDESTRIAN'S RIGHTS AND DUTIES 
 
Secs. 17-146—17-155. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVI. - BICYCLE REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 17-156. - Emerging from an alley or driveway. 
The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall, upon approaching the sidewalk, or the sidewalk extending any alleyway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk or sidewalk area, and, upon entering the street, shall yield the right-of-way to all approaching vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 17-157. - Clinging to vehicles prohibited. 
No person riding upon any bicycle or skateboard shall attach the same or himself to any moving vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 17-158. - Riding on sidewalks. 
No person shall drive any vehicle upon a sidewalk or sidewalk area except upon a permanent or duly authorized temporary driveway. This section does not apply to any vehicle moved exclusively by human power to any electric personal assistive mobility device, nor to any motorized wheelchair. Nothing in this section shall be deemed to limit or pre-empt the authority of any home rule or non-home rule unit of local government from regulating or prohibiting the use of electric personal assistive mobility devices. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 2209, § 2, 11-6-89; Ord. No. 3029, § 1, 6-17-96; Ord. No. 01-O-0093, §§ 1, 2, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0102, §§ 1, 2, 9-7-2004) 
Cross reference— Public ways, Ch. 15; zoning, App. A.  
Secs. 17-159—17-165. - Reserved.

DIVISION 4. - YIELD INTERSECTIONS 
 
Sec. 17-181. - Designated; compliance required. 
Every driver of a vehicle approaching a yield intersection indicated by a yield sign shall yield to traffic at the designated yield street described as: 
Fulton Street. All Fulton Street traffic shall yield for all Center Street traffic. 
Lakeside Drive. All Lakeside Drive traffic shall yield for all Willow Creek Drive traffic. 
Long Oak Drive. All Long Oak Drive traffic shall yield for all Willow Creek Drive traffic. 
Persimmon Drive. All Persimmon Drive traffic shall yield to all High Ridge Drive traffic and all Dunham Drive traffic. 
(Ord. No. 15-O-0016, § 1, 5-4-2015; Ord. No. 17-O-0022, § 1, 7-3-2017)  
Secs. 17-182—17-185. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING PROHIBITED 
 
Sec. 17-186. - Designated; compliance required. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to park, or be parked within thirty (30) feet upon the approach to any yield sign, stop sign or traffic-control signal located at the side of a roadway, on the following streets as described: 
(1)  Those streets listed as numbers (1) through (103) in section 17-176, "Stop intersections." 
(2)  Those streets listed as numbers (1) through (12) in section 17-216, "Traffic-control devices," of the Code. 
(3)  Those streets listed as numbers (1) through (14) in section 17-181, "Yield intersections," of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 17-187. - Stopping and standing prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to stop the vehicle or leave it standing while occupied on the following described streets: 
Conde Street, north side between Route 59 and Gates Street. 
(Ord. No. 2583, § 1, 6-15-92)

DIVISION 7. - PARKING PROHIBITED DURING CERTAIN HOURS ON CERTAIN STREETS 
 
Sec. 17-196. - Designated; compliance required. 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle between the hours specified herein on any day, except Sundays and public holidays, upon any streets or parts of streets as follows. 
(a)  The following named streets are limited to two-hour parking between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. daily: 
(1)  Dale Street, the north side from South Oak Street to Route 59 (South Neltnor Boulevard). 
(2)  Fremont Street, both sides, from McConnell Avenue to Washington Street. 
(3)  Galena Street, both sides, from Main Street to High Street. 
(4)  Joliet Street, west side, from a point twenty (20) feet south of the centerline, extended, of Spencer Street to a point twenty (20) feet north of the centerline, extended, of Spencer Street. 
(5)  Reserved. 
(6)  Main Street, both sides, from Washington Street to Chicago Street. 
(7)  Washington Street, both sides, from Main Street to Aurora Street. 
(b)  The following named streets are limited to four-hour parking between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. daily: 
(1)  Reserved. 
(2)  Center Street, the north side from Washington Street to High Street. 
(3)  Chicago Street, the south side from High Street to Oakwood Avenue. 
(4)  Fulton Street, the east side from Chicago Street to Washington Street. 
(5)  Galena Street, the south side from High Street to Washington Street. 
(6)  High Street, the east side from Chicago Street to Center Street. 
(7)  McConnell Avenue, the north side from Arbor Avenue to Sophia Street. 
(8)  Turner Court, the west side from Main Street to Washington Street. 
(c)  Parking, standing or stopping shall be prohibited on the following streets between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on school days: 
Natalie Drive , the south side from the intersection of the centerlines of Marcella Lane, Natalie Drive and Thomas Drive to a point one hundred fifty (150) feet south/southwest. 
Marcella Lane , the south side from the intersection of the centerlines of Marcella Lane, Natalie Drive and Thomas Drive to a point one hundred eighteen (118) feet north/northeast. 
Thomas Drive , both sides from the intersection of the centerlines of Marcella Lane, Natalie Drive and Thomas Drive to a point two hundred fifty (250) feet northwest/west. 
Marcella Lane , the west side from a point four hundred thirty-four (434) feet north of the intersection of the centerlines of Willow Creek Drive and Woodside Drive to a point five hundred four (504) feet north. 
(d)  The street portion of the following named streets shall be limited to twenty (20) minutes of parking between the hours specified: 
(1)  George Street, the north side from the east right-of-way line of Sherman Street to a point eighty (80) feet east, a loading zone area, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. on school days. 
(2)  Reserved.

DIVISION 13. - LEFT TURNS 
 
Sec. 17-226. - Use of turn lane designated; compliance required. 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall disobey the directions of any sign indicating no left turn by southbound and northbound traffic, except by use of a constructed and approved Illinois Department of Transportation left turn stacking lane, at the following locations: 
From a point beginning at the intersection of the median strip of Route 59 (Neltnor Boulevard) and the southern right-of-way line of Main Street, for a distance of eight hundred twelve (812) feet measured in a southerly direction along the center line of Route 59 (Neltnor Boulevard). 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 17-227. - Prohibited from driveways. 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall disobey the directions of any sign indicating "no left turn" from a driveway at the following locations: 
(1)  From a point beginning at the intersection of the easterly right-of-way line of Route 59 (Neltnor Boulevard) and the southerly line of Main Street for a distance of eight hundred twelve (812) feet measured in a southerly direction along the easterly right-of-way of Route 59 (Neltnor Boulevard). 
(2)  From a point beginning at the intersection of the westerly right-of-way line of Route 59 (Neltnor Boulevard) and the northern right-of-way line of Main Street for a distance of three hundred thirty-nine (339) feet measured in a northerly direction along the westerly right-of-way of Route 59 (Neltnor Boulevard). 
(3)  From a point beginning at the intersection of Arbor Avenue and Route 59 on the westerly right-of-way line of Route 59 (Neltnor Boulevard) for a distance one thousand (1000) feet in the northerly direction along the westerly right-of-way line of Route 59 (Neltnor Boulevard). 
(Ord. No. 2125, § 2, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 2751, § 1, 4-4-94)

Editor's note— Formerly, § 17-228 prohibited left turns at specific intersections. Such section, derived from Ord. No. 2125, § 2, adopted Feb. 21, 1989, was deleted by Ord. No. 4031, § 3, adopted Nov. 3, 1997.
