(Verification)       _____________________ 
(Jurat) 
(2)  Upon receiving said petition and all attachments, the said city clerk shall forward the same to the chairman of the plan commission. 
8.7-2. Final disposition. 
(1)  The plan commission shall then find that items 1 through 7 of said petition are true and correct and may hold whatever hearing, subpoena witness or require consultation with persons it deems needed to ascertain this fact. 
(2)  The plan commission shall determine that item 8 is within the purpose, spirit and intention of the original plat of subdivision particularly, both without limitation as to zoning and environmental impact. 
(3)  Upon making a finding of the above, the plan commission shall cause said finding to be made in writing and sign the same. 
(4)  The plan commission shall submit its findings or recommendations to the city council for their review and consideration. 
(Ord. No. 2139, §§ 1, 2, 6-19-89; Ord. No. 3048, § 10, 12-2-96)  
Article IX. - Required Land Improvements. 
9.1.  No subdivision of land shall be approved unless the improvements required herein are complied with and satisfactory assurance of the completion of the improvements is furnished to the City Council of West Chicago by the subdivider. 
9.2.  All sanitary sewers, water mains, storm sewers and their appurtenances shall be built in accordance with the "Standard Specification for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois," (latest edition), published by the Illinois Society of Professional Engineers as amended in addendum A as attached and made a part hereof, and in accordance with chapter 18 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of West Chicago. 
9.3.  The subdivider shall install street and utility improvements, and other improvements indicated on the approved plans as herein provided. The subdivider shall before the recording of his plan, enter into a contract with the City of West Chicago, agreeing to install the required improvements. The subdivider shall meet all requirements of Section 12.6 of the ordinance. Upon completion of the required improvements, guaranteed by the surety, reproducible "as built" engineering drawings of the subdivision shall be submitted prior to acceptance of all work, to the administrative officer, by the developer of the subdivision. The city engineer shall review and approve the "as-built" drawings before the improvements are accepted by the city. "As-built" drawings must conform to the requirements set forth in Chapter 4, Article I, Section 4-1(l)(10)k. 
Governmental units to which these bond and contract provisions apply may file, in lieu of said contract or bond, an intergovernmental agreement signed by officers authorized to act in their behalf, agreeing to comply with the provisions of this article. 
9.3-1. Water supply and distribution. 
(a)  All subdivisions within the corporate limits shall have an interconnected water distribution system supplying all lots with water from the City of West Chicago water system. A subdivision outside corporate limits may be supplied with water from individual wells located on each lot provided that such water supplies are approved by the county health department having jurisdiction over such subdivision. 
(b)  The water distribution system shall be constructed throughout the subdivision in such a manner as to provide each lot with a separate connection. Water mains shall not be less than eight (8) inches in diameter, shall extend to the extremities of streets, alleys or easements which are served by water mains, and shall in each case be looped; that is, arranged to avoid dead ends. The system shall be designed and constructed in conformance with the all applicable rules and regulations of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. Shut-off valves shall be provided at each branch, at each main connection, at intervals not exceeding six hundred (600) feet on all mains except principal feeders, at intervals not exceeding one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet on all principal feeders, and elsewhere as required to permit adequate sectionization for maintenance purposes. Fire hydrants shall be installed throughout the entire system at intervals not exceeding three hundred (300) feet. A house service connection shall be provided at the center of each lot, extending to the property line, before roadway pavement is constructed. Materials, systems arrangements and details of design shall be subject to the approval of the city council of West Chicago, upon recommendation of city engineer. 
9.3-2. [ Sewer systems. ] 
(a)  All subdivisions within the corporate limits of West Chicago shall have a public system of sanitary sewers serving each lot, connected to the West Chicago wastewater system. A subdivision outside the corporate limits may have sewage disposal facilities on individual lots provided that such sewage disposal facilities are approved by the county health department having jurisdiction over such subdivision. 
(b)  Sewer systems and sewage treatment facilities shall meet the requirements of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. Sanitary and storm sewers shall not be combined. Sewer mains, with house stubs, shall be installed prior to the construction of the pavement. Service stubs shall be run to the center of each lot and shall extend to the property line. The sewer main shall be extended to the end of the street, alley or easement it is serving. Sanitary sewer mains shall be a minimum of eight (8) inches in diameter. Service stubs for new construction shall be a minimum of six (6) inches in diameter. For maintenance and rehabilitation of existing services and with the approval of the city engineer, provided flow calculations are submitted and approved, service stubs may be sliplined, or repaired by some other equivalent method, with a nominal four (4) inch diameter line. 
(c)  Material system arrangement and details of design shall be subject to approval by the city council, upon recommendation of city engineer. 
9.3-3. Storm water. 
(a)  Storm water management shall be provided for all subdivisions, in accordance with chapter 14, article III of this Code. All street curb and gutter systems shall discharge directly into the storm sewer system, which shall convey the storm water to an approved storm water storage area. 
(b)  Storm sewers shall be designed to carry without surcharge above the crown of the pipe, stormwater runoff deposited by a storm of a ten-year frequency as defined in the Illinois State Water Survey Bulletin 70. Storm sewers shall be designed to carry the ten-year frequency design flow at a minimum velocity of three (3) feet per second and a maximum velocity of ten (10) feet per second. 
(c)  Storm sewers to be maintained by the city shall have not less than three (3) feet of cover over the top of the pipe. Storm sewers to be maintained by private landowners shall not have less than three (3) feet of cover over the top of the pipe, unless this cover is not feasible due to existing conditions. Storm sewers to be maintained by private landowners shall not have less than two (2) feet of cover over the top of the pipe. Inlets shall be placed in the street gutters at all street intersections and elsewhere as required by the terrain, but shall not be spaced more than four hundred (400) feet apart along the gutter. Where curbs and gutters are not required, (Section 9.3-4(a)(6)), adequate culvert pipes shall be provided at all street intersections, driveway approaches and at other locations considered necessary by the city engineer to provide adequate flow of storm water. Materials, sewer and manhole arrangement and details of design of all storm drainage facilities shall be subject to the approval of the City Council of West Chicago, upon recommendation of the city engineer. 
9.3-4. Street improvements. All roadway and sidewalk improvements shall be in accordance with the State of Illinois Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction (latest edition). 
(a)  Roadways. 
(1)  All streets shall be improved with paved roadways to an overall width in accordance with Table No. 1. 
(2)  Roadway design shall comply with Section 7-0000, Structural Pavement Design, of Section 7, Pavement Design, of the design manual published by the Illinois Department of Transportation. The design period of all pavement shall be twenty (20) years. A soil support CBR value of two and one-half (2½) may be assumed. Higher CBR values must be verified by laboratory analysis. Residential traffic volumes may be computed by assuming twelve (12) trips per dwelling unit per day. 
(3)  Rigid pavement design. 
a.  Standard for design. Rigid pavements shall be designed in accordance with the latest revision of Section 7-100, Structural Design of Rigid Pavements, of Section 7, Pavement Design, of the manual published by the Illinois Department of Transportation. 
b.  Typical rigid pavement. 
Class of 
street 	A D T 	Minimum 
thickness 
(in inches) 
IV 	Under 750 	6 
III 	750 to 2,000 	7 
II 	Over 2,000 	
 
All rigid pavements shall be constructed with standard reinforcement and placed on a 4-inch granular base. 
(4)  Flexible pavement design. 
a.  Standard for design: Flexible pavements shall be designed in accordance with the latest revision of the Manual of Instructions for Structural Design of Bituminous Pavements on Project Involving MFT, FAS, FAUS and Topics Funds, as published by the Illinois Department of Transportation with the following exceptions: 
1.  Bituminous surface treatments shall not be allowed. 
2.  Minimum allowable structural numbers (Dt) allowed are: 
i.  Collector and minor streets, residential ..... 3.0 
ii.  Collector and minor streets, commercial and industrial ..... 4.0 
iii.  Collector and minor streets, Class II truck routes ..... 5.0 
b.  Typical flexible pavement. 
1.  Collector and minor streets, residential 3-inch Class I surface on 5-inch BAM, minimum Marshall stability ..... 1,700 
2.  Collector and minor streets, commercial and industrial, 4-inch Class I surface on 9-inch BAM, minimum Marshall stability ..... 1,700 
3.  Collector and minor streets, Class II truck route, 4-inch Class I surface on 12-inch BAM, minimum Marshall stability ..... 1,700 
4.  The pavement cross section shall meet the structural number by use of a stabilized base. Nonstabilized granular base is not allowed. 
(5)  The roadways of all major thoroughfares shall be constructed in accordance with the appropriate authorities' requirements. 
(6)  Curbs and gutters are required on all streets within the corporate limits of West Chicago and shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete of a design equal to State of Illinois Standard #2130-4, B-6-12 and shall be continuously reinforced with two (2) #4 reinforcing bars. On streets not within the corporate limits of West Chicago, the curb and gutter shall be of such material and design as is acceptable to the county officials. 
(7)  All curb corners shall have a radius of not less than twenty-five (25) feet in residential areas and forty (40) feet in commercial and industrial areas. 
(8)  A paved driveway approach between curb and sidewalks, or between curb and lot line, shall be provided at each lot before an occupancy permit is issued. Approaches shall be constructed as specified in section 154 of the City Code. 
(9)  Subgrade. Existing underlying soils upon which a roadway is to be constructed shall be of stable quality and of sufficient bearing capacity to properly support and distribute the loads placed thereon. Unstable material shall be removed and replaced with a crushed stone or gravel, meeting Illinois Department of Transportation requirements for CA-6 or stabilized by another method acceptable to the city engineer. 
(b)  Sidewalks. 
(1)  Sidewalks shall be provided along both sides of all major thoroughfares, collector streets, minor streets and cul-de-sacs in all subdivisions. The city council may, sua sponte or upon application of the subdivider, in its discretion, require or approve alternative path systems, such as bike paths, as a condition to the approval of any subdivision. 
(2)  Sidewalks shall be of Portland cement concrete not less than five (5) inches thick and not less than four (4) feet wide on minor streets and five (5) feet wide on collector streets and built in accordance with the requirements of section 15-4 of this Code. 
9.3-5. Street lighting. In all subdivisions within the corporate limits of West Chicago, street lighting shall be provided throughout the subdivision by the subdivider. Streetlight standards shall be served by underground wiring with connections to a power supply of the Commonwealth Edison Company. All streetlight installations shall be in accordance with the requirements of section 4-70 of this Code. 
9.3-6. Street trees. Trees shall be planted on both sides of all roadways. Trees shall have a trunk diameter, measured twelve (12) inches above the ground, of not less than two and one-half (2½) inches. All street trees shall be in accordance with the requirements of section 15-5 of this Code. 
9.3-7. Street names and signs. Street signs are to be placed at all intersections within or abutting the subdivision. The type and location shall be approved by the city engineer. No street names shall be used which will duplicate or be confused with the names of existing streets. New streets, which are extensions of or obviously in alignment with existing streets, shall bear the name of the existing streets. Street names shall be subject to the approval of the city council. 
9.3-8. Grading. The area subdivided shall have necessary grading completed at the final elevation shown on the grading plan. All land shall be at the proposed grade plus or minus 0.1 foot unless the area in question is specifically designed for that purpose. All grading must comply with requirements for erosion and sedimentation control found in section 14-50 of this Code. 
9.3-9. Monuments. The subdivider shall place permanent reference monuments in the subdivision as required herein. The external boundaries of a subdivision shall be monumented in the field by monuments of stone or concrete, not less than thirty (30) inches in length, not less than four (4) inches square or five (5) inches in diameter, and marked on top with a cross, brass plug, iron rod, or other durable material securely embedded; or by iron rods or pipes at least thirty (30) inches long and two (2) inches in diameter. These monuments shall be placed not more than one thousand four hundred (1,400) feet apart in any straight line, at all subdivision corners, at each end of all curves, at the point where a curve changes its radius, at all angle points to be not less than twenty (20) feet back from the bank of any river or stream, except that when such corners or points fall within a street, or proposed future street, the monuments shall be placed in the sideline of the street so referenced. All internal boundaries and those corners and points not referred to in the preceding paragraph shall be monumented in the field by iron rods or pipes at least thirty (30) inches long and two (2) inches in diameter. These monuments shall be placed at all block corners, at each end of all curves, at a point where a curve changes its radius, and at all angle points in any line. All lot corners shall be monumented in the field by iron pipes at least twenty-four (24) inches long and one inch in diameter, or by round or square iron bars at least twenty-four (24) inches long. The lines or lot that extend to rivers or streams shall be monumented in the field by iron pipes at least thirty (30) inches long and one inch in diameter, or by round or square iron bars at least thirty (30) inches long. These monuments shall be placed at the point of intersection of the river or stream lot line, with a meander line established not less than twenty (20) feet back from the bank of the river or stream. All monuments shall be properly set in the ground by a registered Illinois land surveyor before final plat approval. All monuments shall be set flush with the ground and planted in such a manner that they will not be changed by frost. 
9.3-10. Other improvements. All utilities and service facilities shall be placed underground. All underground work such as sewers, water and gas mains, service connections and any underground conduits for cable television, electric and telephone lines shalt be installed and approved prior to the construction of the street pavement. The surface course on bituminous pavement and concrete pavement shall not be constructed until the backfilling of all trenches dug for the installation of the aforementioned utility services have completely settled, or compacted, to the satisfaction of the city engineer. 
9.3-11. Landscaping. Topsoil shall not be removed from residential lots and used as spoil, but shall be stockpiled and then redistributed so as to provide at least six (6) inches of cover on the lots between sidewalks and curbs, and shall be stabilized by seeding or sodding. All landscaping shall be in accordance with Chapter 14, Article IX, of this Code. 
9.4. Municipal service and emergency access easements. 
(a)  Easements shown on plats for municipal access purposes shall be restricted to use for municipal utility and emergency services, unless such easements are also co-existent with roadways designated on the plat as private roads or drives. No such easement, whether or not also co-existent with private road or drive, shall be, or shall be deemed or regarded as, a public right-of-way for any purpose. For residential subdivisions only, where there is a failure or absence of maintenance of such easement by the developer, homeowners' association, or other person responsible therefor, the city may, but is not obligated to, undertake maintenance of such easement in such a manner as it deems in its sole discretion appropriate for the purposes of assuring access to the subdivision for municipal utility and emergency services. Such maintenance may include plowing, salting, patching and repairing the easement surface; removal of brush and fallen trees or tree limbs obstructing passage; and the cleaning and repairing of any lighting as the city determines necessary and appropriate to allow for the easement's usage by municipal service and emergency vehicles. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be parked or allowed to remain on any portion of a private roadway that is co-extensive with a municipal access easement on which snow has accumulated to a depth of two (2) inches or greater. The city may cause any vehicle parked or allowed to remain on such private roadway in violation of this prohibition to be removed to the nearest garage or other place of safety by means of towing. All expenses and charges incurred by reason of the towing of such vehicle and the storing of it because of towing shall be paid by the owner of the vehicle or other person legally entitled to possession thereof, and no vehicle against which there are any unpaid costs or charges under these provisions shall be released to the owner or other person legally entitled to possession thereof until all such charges and costs have been paid and fully satisfied. Notice and opportunity for hearing shall be given to the owner or other person legally entitled to possession in accordance with the city's administrative hearing procedures. The provisions of this subsection are not to be construed as being in lieu of any penalty or penalties provided for elsewhere in this code or in any other ordinances for violation of the provisions of any ordinance, including this section, but are in addition thereto and are necessary for the maintenance of obstructed access for municipal service and emergency purposes. 
(c)  Regardless of whether the easement is co-existent with a private roadway, neither this section nor the city's undertaking maintenance of a municipal access easement shall create any duty on the part of the city or its agents or contractors with respect to any easement or private roadway user or subdivision property owner or any person claiming through them, and no cause of action shall lie against the city or its agents or contractors on account of any act of maintenance or alleged omission of such act by the city under this section. 
(d)  Where a municipal access easement is co-extensive with a private roadway, nothing in this section shall be deemed to preclude persons responsible for maintaining the roadway, such as a developer, homeowners' association, or property owners with user rights to it, from undertaking maintenance of it, provided such complies with applicable city ordinances and regulations and does not interfere with the municipal access easement. 
(e)  This section shall apply to municipal access easements in existence at the time of its effective date as well as prospectively. 
(Ord. No. 2030, § 1, 7-5-88; Ord. No. 3048, §§ 11—23, 12-2-96; Ord. No. 03-O-0022, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 05-O-0013, §§ 1—3, 3-21-2005; Ord. No. 10-O-0039, § 4, 4-19-10; Ord. No. 14-O-0006, § 2, 2-17-2014)  
Article X. - Design Standards. 
10.1.  Conformance to applicable laws, ordinances, codes, rules and regulations. The provisions of this ordinance shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, morals and welfare. Where the standards and/or conditions imposed by any provision of this ordinance are either more restrictive or less restrictive than comparable conditions imposed by any other provisions of this Code or any other law, ordinance, code, rule or regulation of any kind, the conditions which are the most restrictive or impose the higher standards or requirements shall govern. 
10.2.  Streets. 
10.2-1. General considerations. Streets shall be designed and located in relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions and natural terrain features such as streams and existing tree growth, to public convenience and safety, and in appropriate relation to the proposed uses of land to be served by such streets. 
10.2-2. Arrangement. 
(a)  All streets shall be properly integrated with the existing and proposed system of thoroughfares and dedicated rights-of-way as established in the comprehensive plan. 
(b)  All thoroughfares shall be properly related to special traffic generators such as industries, business districts, schools, churches, and shopping centers; to population densities; and to the pattern of existing and proposed land uses. 
(c)  Minor streets shall be laid out to conform as much as possible to the topography, to discourage use by through traffic, to permit efficient drainage and utility systems, and to require the minimum number of streets necessary to provide convenient, safe access to property. 
(d)  The rigid rectangular gridiron street pattern need not necessarily be adhered to, and the use of curvilinear streets, culs-de-sac, or U-shaped streets shall be encouraged where such use will result in more desirable layout. 
(e)  Proposed streets shall be extended to the boundary lines of the tract to be subdivided, unless prevented by topography or other physical conditions, or unless in the opinion of the plan commission such extension is not necessary or desirable for the coordination of the layout of the subdivision with the existing layout or most advantageous future development of adjacent tracts. 
(f)  In business and industrial developments, the streets and other accessways shall be planned in connection with the grouping of buildings, location of rail facilities, and the provision of alleys, truck loading and maneuvering areas so as to minimize conflict of movement between the various types of traffic. 
10.2-3. Railroads and highways. Railroad rights-of-way and limited access highways where so located as to affect the subdivision of adjoining lands shall be as follows: 
(a)  In residential districts a buffer strip at least twenty-five (25) feet in depth, in addition to the normal depth of the lot required in the district, shall be provided adjacent to the railroad right-of-way or limited access highway. This strip shall be part of the platted lots and shall be designated on the plat: "This strip is reserved for the planting of trees and shrubs by the owner. The placement of structures hereon is prohibited." (See Figure 1 of Appendix A). 
(b)  In districts zoned for business, commercial, or industrial uses, the nearest street extending parallel or approximately parallel to the railroad shall, wherever practicable, be at a sufficient distance therefrom to ensure suitable depth for commercial or industrial sites. 
(c)  Streets parallel to the railroad when intersecting a street which crosses the railroad at grade shall, to the extent practicable, be at a distance of at least one hundred fifty (150) feet from the railroad right-of-way. Such distance shall be determined with due consideration of the minimum distance required for future separation of grades by means of appropriate approach gradients. 
10.24. Access to major streets. Where a subdivision borders on or contains an existing or proposed major street, the city council may require that access to such streets be limited by one of the following means: 
(a)  The subdivision of lots so as to back onto the major street and front onto a parallel local street; no access shall be provided from the major street and screen planting shall be provided in a strip of land along the rear property line of such lots. 
(b)  A series of culs-de-sac, U-shaped streets, or short loops entered from and designed generally at right angles to such a parallel street, with the rear lines of their terminal lots backing onto the major street. 
(c)  A marginal access or service street shall be separated from the major street by a planting or grass strip and having access thereto at suitable points. The number of residential streets entering a major street shall be kept to a minimum. 
10.2-5. Minor and collector street standards. The following minimum standards shall apply to the design of minor residential streets, including marginal access streets which shall be in accordance with Table No. 1:

Notes: 
(1)  Sidewalks shall be located with the outer edge one foot inside of the right-of-way line unless otherwise approved by the city engineer. 
(2)  Cul-de-sac streets' turnaround areas shall have a minimum pavement radius of forty-five (45) feet measured from the center to the back of the curb or outer edge of roadway pavement. 
(3)  Pavement width shall be measured from the back of curb to back of curb. 
10.2-6. Private streets. The city council may, in its discretion, approve the construction, maintenance and use of private streets within subdivisions, and may allow access to lots therein by means of such private streets. The following standards shall apply to the construction, maintenance and use of private streets within the city: 
(a)  All private streets shall conform to all requirements provided under this Code for public streets. 
(b)  No private street, or interconnected system of private streets, shall intersect with more than one (1) public street. 
(c)  All private streets shall feature street signs substantially similar in size, lettering and placement to the street signs for public streets within the city. 
(d)  The subdivider of any subdivision featuring one (1) or more private streets shall provide a performance guarantee to the city for the completion of the private streets and associated improvements, in the same manner as provided under this ordinance for the performance guarantee for the completion of construction of the public improvements for a subdivision. 
(e)  The subdivider shall record a declaration of covenants, conditions and restrictions with respect to the subdivision, in a form acceptable to the city, which includes: 
(1)  The establishment of a subdivision owners' association which shall: 
a.  Hold title to the private streets and be obligated to maintain the private streets. 
b.  Have the right and obligation to impose assessments against the lots within the subdivision for the purpose of maintaining the private streets. 
c.  Have the right and obligation to file a written request with the city pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/11-209.1, for traffic regulation enforcement by the city upon the private streets. 
d.  Have the right to dedicate the private street to the city. 
(2)  The grant of an easement in, under, over and upon the private streets to the city for purposes of ingress and egress, and to repair, replace, maintain and/or install public improvements, and to all providers of public, or quasi-public, services such as cable television, refuse collection and recycling services for the purposes of ingress and egress. 
(3)  The grant to the city of the right, but not the obligation, to enter upon the private streets and repair, replace and/or maintain the private streets, and to place a lien upon each and every lot within the subdivision for the costs and expenses incurred by the city in the performance of such work. 
(4)  The prohibition on any amendment to such declaration which affects the provisions required under this section, without the written consent of the city. 
10.2-7. Street grading. The grade of major thoroughfares shall not exceed three (3) percent. The grade of all other streets shall not exceed five (5) percent unless the city engineer finds a topographical situation that requires a steeper grade. The minimum grade of all streets shall be five-tenths of one (1) percent. The grades of pedestrianways or crosswalks shall not exceed eight (8) percent. 
10.2-8. Vertical curves. All changes in street grades shall be connected by vertical curves of a minimum length in feet equivalent to the algebraic difference in the percent of grade times a K factor; such K factor to be derived as follows: 
	K factor 
Design speed 	Crest curve 	Sag curve 
30 	30 	35 
35 	45 	45 
 
No vertical curves shall be required on minor streets or collector streets where the algebraic difference in percent of grade is less than one (1) percent. 
10.2-9. Tangents. A tangent at least one hundred (100) feet in length shall be introduced between reverse curves on minor streets and cul-de-sacs with a tangent of two hundred (200) feet on collector streets. 
10.2-10. Cul-de-sac. 
(a)  A cul-de-sac street shall not exceed one thousand (1,000) feet in length. 
(b)  The diameter of a cul-de-sac turnaround, measured at the outside right-of-way, shall be not less than one hundred twenty (120) feet. Pavement diameter of a cul-de-sac turnaround shall be not less than ninety (90) feet. 
10.2-11. Street intersections. 
(a)  Streets shall be designed to intersect approximately at right angles. A proposed intersection of two (2) new streets at an angle of less than seventy-five (75) degrees shall not be acceptable. Not more than two (2) streets shall intersect at any one point unless approved by the city council. (See Figure 2 of Appendix A). 
(b)  Proposed new intersections along one side of an existing street shall whenever practicable coincide with any existing intersections on the opposite side of an existing street shall whenever practicable coincide with any existing intersections on the opposite side of such street. Street jogs with center line offsets of less than one hundred fifty (150) feet shall not be permitted. Where streets intersect major streets, their alignment shall be continuous as in Figure 3, page 71, Appendix A. 
(c)  Minimum curb radius at the intersection of any two (2) local streets shall be at least twenty-five (25) feet. Alley intersections and abrupt changes in alignment within a block shall have the corners cut off in accordance with standard engineering practice, to permit safe vehicular movement. 
(d)  Intersections shall be designed with a flat grade wherever practical. In hilly or rolling areas, at the approach to an intersection, a leveling area shall be provided having a grade of not greater than two (2) percent for a distance of sixty (60) feet, measured from the nearest right-of-way line of the intersection street. (See Figure 4 of Appendix A). 
(e)  Where there are earth banks or existing vegetation inside a corner lot that could create a traffic hazard by limiting visibility, the developer shall cut such ground or vegetation including trees in the grading of the public right-of-way to the extent necessary to provide adequate visibility. 
10.3.  Easements. 
10.3-1. Easements across lots or on the rear or side lot-lines shall be provided for utilities private and municipal where required by the city council. Such easements shall be at least twenty (20) feet wide. The public utility easement shall be established by coordination between developer and utility. (See Figure 5 of Appendix A.) 
10.3-2. Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainage swales, channels, or stream, there shall be provided a storm water easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially to the boundaries of such watercourse drainage swale, channel or stream. Wherever possible, it is desirable that the drainage shall be maintained by an open channel, with landscaped banks, adequate for maximum potential volume of flow. 
10.4.  Blocks 
10.4-1. Residential blocks. 
(a)  Blocks shall have sufficient width to provide for two (2) tiers of lots of appropriate depths. Exceptions shall be permitted in blocks adjacent to major streets, railroads, or waterways. 
(b)  The lengths, widths, and shapes of blocks shall be such as are appropriate for the locality and the type of development contemplated. Block in residential areas shall not be more than two thousand (2,000) feet nor less than four hundred (400) feet in length. Wherever practicable, blocks along major arterials and collector streets shall not be less than one thousand (1,000) feet in length. 
(c)  Pedestrianways or crosswalks, not less than ten (10) feet wide, may be required by the city council through the center of blocks more than eight hundred (800) feet long where deemed essential to provide circulations or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation or other community facilities. 
10.5.  Lots. 
10.5-1. In general, the size, shape and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the tee of development and use contemplated. Lot dimensions shall conform to the requirements of the City of West Chicago Zoning Ordinance. 
10.5-2. Depth and width of properties reserved or laid out for business commercial, or industrial purposes, shall be adequate to provide for off-street parking and loading facilities required for the type of use and development set forth in the City of West Chicago Zoning Ordinance. 
10.5-3. Where residential lots fronting on major streets or highways are permitted by the city council, they should be platted with extra depth to permit generous distances between the buildings and such. Where lots front on major streets, the normal building setback line shall be increased by an additional twenty (20) feet. Business commercial, or industrial buildings in residential blocks shall be provided with setbacks at least equal to the setback of the residential properties in that block and shall comply with all applicable zoning requirements. 
10.5-4. Every lot shall front on or abut a public street unless access by private ways is approved by the city council. 
10.5-5. Lots shall be laid out so as to provide drainage away from all buildings, and individual lot drainage shall be coordinated with the general storm drainage pattern for the area. Drainage shall be designed to avoid concentration of storm drainage water on adjacent lots. On all buildings, the first floor shall be set eighteen (18) inches above the top of the curb or the lowest point of the adjacent roadway. 
10.5-6. Side lot lines shall be approximately at right angles or radial to street lines. 
10.5-7. Corner lots for residential use shall have extra width to permit appropriate building setback from both streets. 
10.5-8. Lot lines shall follow municipal boundary lines whenever practicable, rather than cross them. 
10.5-9. Double frontage lots shall be avoided except where necessary to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries, or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. 
10.5-10. Flag (reserve) lots shall be prohibited unless approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2030, § 2, 7-5-88; Ord. No. 3048, §§ 24—28, 12-2-96; Ord. No. 05-O-0067, § 17, 9-19-2005)  
Article XI. - Preliminary Plats. 
Every proposed subdivision shall be, submitted to the West Chicago Plan Commission for preliminary plat approval prior to the submission of a final plat. The preliminary plat is not intended to be a final plat and must be prepared in such form as not to be confused with a final plat. Its purpose is to show graphically all facts needed to enable the plan commission and other public bodies to determine whether the proposed layout of the land in question is satisfactory from the standpoint of the public interest. The preliminary plat shall be prepared by a qualified professional, trained and experienced in the layout of subdivisions. The following graphic and descriptive items are normally required to be shown on the preliminary plat and that accompanying application for approval. The lack of information under any item specified herein, or improper information supplied by the applicant, may be cause for disapproval of a preliminary plat. 
11.1. Application for approval. Written application by the owner, or his agent, for approval on forms furnished by the City of West Chicago shall accompany each preliminary plat and contain the following information: 
11.1-1. Name for file identification. 
(a)  Name of subdivision if property is within an existing subdivision. 
(b)  Proposed name if not within a previously platted subdivision. The proposed name shall not duplicate the name of any plat previously recorded in DuPage County or Kane County. 
(c)  Name of property if no subdivision name has been chosen. This is commonly the name by which the property is locally known. 
11.1-2. Location and description of property. Location of property by government lot, section, township, range and county. 
11.1-3. Basic facts and proposals pertaining to the property. 
(a)  Size of tract in acres or of existing lots, if any, in square feet. 
(b)  Existing zoning classification of property and any rezoning proposed to be requested. 
(c)  Number of lots proposed in the subdivision. 
(d)  Area of lots proposed, showing minimum, average, and maximum. 
(e)  Proposed type of water and sewer facilities. 
(f)  Any other proposals, such as parcels of land intended to be dedicated, conveyed, or reserved for public use, and the conditions proposed for such disposal and use. 
11.14. Information as to ownership, preparation of plan, and submission thereof. 
(a)  Name and address, including telephone number, of owner of record and the agent, if any, of the property and a citation of the last instrument conveying title to each parcel of property involved in the proposed subdivision, giving grantor, grantee, date and land records reference. 
(b)  Citation of any existing legal rights-of-way or easements affecting the property. 
(c)  Existing covenants on the property, if any. 
(d)  Name and address, including telephone number, of the professional responsible for the subdivision design shall be shown on the preliminary plat as submitted. The registered professional engineer of Illinois responsible for the design of public improvements, and registered Illinois land surveyor responsible for surveys shall be shown on said plat. 
11.2. The drawing. The preliminary plat shall be drawn with waterproof nonfading black ink or legibly drawn with pencil on tracing cloth or tracing paper of good quality at a scale of not more than one hundred (100) feet to the inch, and shall show correctly on its face the following information: 
(a)  Date, scale, and north point. 
(b)  The proposed subdivision name must be the same as that specified in the application. 
(c)  The name and address of the owner, the subdivider, and the surveyor preparing the plat. 
(d)  Location of the subdivision by government lot, quarter section, section, township, range and county. 
(e)  A vicinity sketch or small scale drawing of the section or area within which the subdivision lies, with the location of the subdivision indicated thereon. 
(f)  The exact length and bearing of the exterior boundaries of the subdivision. Dimensions shall be expressed in feet and decimals of a foot. 
(g)  Location and names of adjacent subdivisions and the owners of adjoining parcels of unsubdivided land. 
(h)  Zoning on and adjacent to the subdivision. 
(i)  Location, width, and names of all existing and platted streets, alleys, and other public ways and easements, railroad and utility rights-of-way, parks, cemeteries, watercourses, drainage ditches, permanent buildings, bridges and other pertinent data. 
(j)  The water elevations of adjoining lakes or streams at the date of the survey and the approximate high and low water elevations of such lakes or streams. All elevations shall be referred to the United States Geological Survey datum plane. 
(k)  If the subdivision borders a lake, river, or stream, the distances and bearings of a meander line established not less than twenty (20) feet back from the ordinary high water mark of such waterways. 
(l)  Layout and width of all new streets and rights-of-way, including alleys, highways, easements for sewers and water mains and other public utilities. 
(m)  Existing sewers, water mains, culverts, and other underground structures within the tract or immediately adjacent thereto. The location and size of the nearest water main and sanitary and storm sewers are to be indicated in a general way upon the preliminary plat. 
(n)  Plans of proposed utility layouts (water, sewers, and storm drains) showing connection to any existing or proposed utility system. 
(o)  Approximate dimensions and areas of lots. 
(p)  Approximate radii of all curves, length of tangents, and central angles on all streets. 
(q)  Approximate location and area of all property proposed to be dedicated or reserved for public use or to be reserved by deed covenant for use of all property owners in the subdivision, with the conditions if any, of such dedication or reservation. 
(r)  Contours at vertical intervals of not more than two (2) feet. More frequent intervals may be required by the city engineer for land with unusual topography. The topography should extend to all users within three hundred (300) feet of the boundary of the subdivision. 
(s)  Building setback lines.  
Article XII. - Final Plats. 
12.1.  Final plat may constitute a portion of the approved preliminary plat. A final plat may constitute only a portion of the area contained in approved preliminary plat provided that the public improvements to be constructed in the area covered by the plat are sufficient by and of themselves to accomplish a proper development and to provide adequately for the health, safety and convenience of the proposed residents therein and for adequate access to contiguous areas. 
12.2.  Application for approval. Written application by the owner or his agent for approval on forms furnished by the City of West Chicago shall accompany each final plat and shall contain the following information: 
(a)  Name of subdivision and description of blocks and lots included plat. 
(b)  Location of subdivision by government lot, section, township, range and county. 
(c)  Name, date of approval, and file number of the preliminary plat upon which the final plat is based. 
(d)  Zoning classification of the property. 
(e)  Total numbers of lots and/or parcels included on the plat. 
(f)  Total area shown on the plat, including streets, and total area dedicated to public use, if any. 
(g)  Existing or proposed covenants, if any. Reference shall be made to any private restrictions, and plats shall contain proper acknowledgements of owners and mortgages accepting said platting and restrictions. 
(h)  Name and address, including telephone number, of the owner, his agent and the surveyor who prepared the plat. 
(i)  Submission to the city engineer and approval by him of final engineering plans and specifications for all water systems, sanitary sewage disposal systems and all storm drainage facilities, showing connection to any existing or proposed utility system, detention basins, streetlights and landscaping plans. 
(j)  Final engineering drawings showing street profile plans for all existing and proposed streets, containing all information required by the city engineer. 
12.3.  The drawing. The final plat shall be drawn with waterproof nonfading black ink, at a scale of not more than one hundred (100) feet to the inch, on muslinbacked white paper of four (4) mil transparent Mylar, twenty-nine (29) inches wide by twenty-nine (29) inches long. When more than one sheet is used for any plat, each sheet shall be numbered consecutively and shall contain a notation giving the total number of sheets in the plat and showing the relation of that sheet to the other sheets, and each sheet shall bear the name of the subdivision. Each plat shall show correctly on its face the following information: 
12.3-1. Map and engineering information. 
(a)  Date, scale and north point. 
(b)  The exterior boundaries of the land surveyed and divided. 
(c)  All monuments erected, corners and other points established in the field in their proper places. The material of which the monuments, corners or other points are made shall be noted at the representation thereof or by legend, except that lot corners need not be shown. The legend for metal monuments shall indicate the kind of metal, the diameter, length, and weight per lineal foot of the monument. 
(d)  The exact length and bearing of the exterior boundaries, the boundary lines of all blocks, public grounds, streets and alleys, and all lot lines, except that when the lines in any tier of lots are parallel, it shall be sufficient to mark the bearings of the outer lines on one tier thereof. Easements shall be shown by center line and width when lines are parallel to a boundary, otherwise boundary bearings and distances shall be shown. Where the exterior boundary lines show bearings or lengths which vary from those recorded in abutting plats or certified surveys, the recording bearing, or length, or both, shall be shown. 
(e)  Blocks, if designated, shall be consecutively numbered. Additions to subdivisions bearing the same name shall be numbered or lettered consecutively through the several additions. 
(f)  All lots in each block consecutively numbered. Outlots shall be lettered in alphabetical order. If blocks are numbered and lettered, outlots shall be lettered in alphabetical order within each block. 
(g)  The exact width of all easements and streets. 
(h)  All lake or stream shore meander lines established by the surveyor in accordance with Section 7.24(f) of this ordinance, the distances and bearings thereof, and the distance between the point of intersection of such meander lines with lot lines and the ordinary high-water mark. 
(i)  The center line of all streets. 
(j)  The number of degrees and minutes in all exterior boundary and block angles. When such angles are between a curve and its tangent, the angle shown shall be that between the tangent and the main chord of the curve; when between curves of different radii, the angle between the main chords. 
(k)  When a street is on a circular curve, there shall be noted their bearings and lengths, the radius of the circle of which a part, the central angle subtended and the tangent bearing at either the point of curve or point of tangency. 
(l)  When strict compliance with a provision of this section will entail undue or unnecessary difficulty or tend to render the plat more difficult to read, and when the information on the plat is sufficient for the exact retracement of the measurement and bearings or other unnecessary dimensions, the City Council of the City of West Chicago, upon the recommendations of the city engineer, may waive such strict compliance. 
12.3-2. Name, location and position. The name of the subdivision shall be printed on the plat in prominent letters, and the following information relating to the position and location of the subdivision shall be shown thereon: 
(a)  The location of the subdivision by township, section, town and range, or other legal description, and the county permanent index number (P.I.N.) for each parcel being subdivided. 
(b)  The exact location of the subdivision, indicated by distances and bearings with reference to a corner or corners established in the U.S. Public Land Survey. 
(c)  A small drawing of the section, or governmental subdivision of the section, in which the subdivision lies, with the location of the subdivision indicated thereon. This drawing shall be oriented on the sheet in the same direction as the main drawing. 
(d)  Where provision is made for access to any lake or stream, the plat shall show the area over which access is provided to the lake or stream together with a small scale drawing clearly indicating the location of the subdivision in relation to the lake or stream and the location of the area over which access is provided. 
(e)  The names of adjoining streets, state highways, and subdivisions shown in their proper location underscored by a dotted line. 
(f)  Abutting street and state highway lines of adjoining plats shown in their proper location by dotted lines. The width of these streets and highways shall be given also. 
12.3-3. Roads and public spaces. 
(a)  The name of each road or street in the plat shall be printed thereon in prominent letters. 
(b)  All lands dedicated to public use except roads and streets shall be clearly marked "Dedicated to the City of West Chicago." 
(c)  Each lot within the plat must abut a public street except where approval has been granted under section 10.5-5 of this ordinance. 
12.3-4. Site conditions and topography. 
(a)  All existing buildings. 
(b)  All watercourses, drainage ditches, and other existing features pertinent to proper subdivision. 
(c)  The water elevations of adjoining lakes, rivers, or streams at the date of the survey and the approximate high and low water elevations of such lakes, rivers, and streams. All elevations shall be referred to the U.S.G.S. datum plane. 
(d)  No plat shall be approved by the city council unless, in addition to any other requirements of the city council, the topographical and profile studies pertaining to the subdivision plat have on their face the certification of a registered professional engineer. The topographical and profile studies required herein shall not be recorded, but shall be retained and filed by the City of West Chicago as permanent public documents. 
12.4.  Recording of final plat. To entitle a final plat to be entered in the proper record books in the office of the Recorder of Deeds of DuPage County or Kane County, the following certificates together with the certificate of approval of the city council shall accompany it. These certificates shall be lettered or printed legibly with black durable ink, or typed. 
12.4-1. Acknowledgement. The following shall be submitted with each plat: 
(a)  A correct description of the land or parcel of land to be subdivided. 
(b)  A notarized statement to the effect that the subdivision as it appears on the plat is with the free consent and in accordance with the desire of the owner and spouse, if applicable, acknowledging the adoption of the plat and the dedication of streets and other public areas, and granting a release of mortgage on such as are dedicated for public use. 
12.4-2. Certificate for surveyor. The final plat shall be accompanied by a certificate from a registered Illinois land surveyor, attesting to the fact that the plat represents a survey made by him and that monuments and markers shown thereon exist as located and that all dimensional and geodetic details are correct, and that he has complied with all the rules contained herein governing plats, and noting exception, if any. Surveyor also must certify that the subdivision is or is not within five hundred (500) feet of a watercourse draining six hundred forty (640) acres or more. 
12.4-3. County clerk's certificate. The final plat shall be accompanied by a certificate from the county clerk, attesting to the fact that all taxes are paid for the current year and all prior years, or that the required statutory security has been deposited in the office of the county clerk, guaranteeing payment thereof. (See Appendix B for sample certificate.) 
12.4-4. Engineer's certificate. To the best of our knowledge and belief the drainage of surface waters will not be changed by the construction of such subdivision or any part thereof, or, that if such surface water drainage will be changed, adequate provision has been made for collection and diversion of such surface waters into public areas, or drains which the subdivider has a right to use, and that such surface waters will not be deposited on the property of adjoining land owners in such concentration as may cause damage to the adjoining property because of the construction of the subdivision. 
Dated this _____ day of ________, 19___. 
_____	_____
Engineer 	Owner or Attorney 
 
12.4-5. Planning commission certificate. The final plat shall contain a statement that the City of West Chicago Plan Commission has recommended approval of the final plat, which statement shall be signed by the chairman and attested to by the secretary. 
12.4-6. Certificate as to special assessments. 
STATE OF ILLINOIS 
COUNTY OF DUPAGE 
I, ___________, Collector of the City of West Chicago, do hereby certify that there are no delinquent or unpaid current or forfeited special assessments or any deferred installments thereof that have been apportioned against the tract of land included in the plat. 
Dated at West Chicago, DuPage County, Illinois, this _____ day of ________ A.D., 19___. 
_____
City Collector 
12.5.  Record of plats. All of such plats of subdivisions, after the same have been submitted and approved, as provided in this ordinance, shall be filed and kept by the city clerk among the records of the City of West Chicago. 
12.6.  Filing requirements of final plat. The final plat shall be accompanied by a statement signed by the owner or subdivider setting forth: 
(1)  The plans and specifications for the required public improvements have been completed and such plans approved by the city engineer. 
(2)  The required public improvements will be installed in accordance with such plans and specifications. 
(3)  Cash, certified checks, or irrevocable letters of credit, in a form acceptable to the corporation counsel, have been deposited with the city, in an amount equal to one hundred twenty-five (125) percent of the cost, as estimated by a registered professional engineer on behalf of the subdivider and approved by the city engineer, of the completion of all required public improvements. 
(4)  Guarantee deposit. In addition to the security to be provided for in paragraph (3) above, a deposit shall be made to the city in cash, irrevocable letters of credit (in a form approved by the city attorney) or maintenance bond equal to ten (10) percent of the cost of public facility installations. This deposit shall be a guarantee of satisfactory performance of the facilities constructed within the development (subdivision) and shall be held by the city for a period of eighteen (18) months after acceptance of such facilities by the city. After such eighteen (18) months, the deposit shall be refunded if no defects have developed, then the balance of such deposit shall be refunded after reimbursement for amounts expended in correcting any defective facilities. 
(Ord. No. 3048, §§ 30—33, 12-2-96)

	Final Plat 			
1. 	Final plat is filed within one year of approval of the preliminary plat (including all or part of the original plat). 			
2. 	Written Application Containing 			
	a. 
Name of subdivision, description of blocks and lots included on plat.

Outlots are shown.

Existing and proposed covenants on property, including acknowledgement of all encumbrancers.

Name and address, phone number of each owner and/or his agent. 			
3. 	Drawing 			
	The final plat is drawn with waterproof nonfading ink, scale of not more than 100 feet to the inch on transparent Mylar or equivalent at a size (in multiples of 8½ × 11"). An index to sheets to be provided for any subdivision containing more than one sheet. 			
	a. 
Date, scale and north point. 			
	b. 
Subdivision name, not duplicating any other subdivision name. 			
	c. 
Legal description, location by government lot, quarter section, section and township. 			
	d. 
Monuments erected in the field to be referenced (kind of monument, type of materials). 			
	e. 
Exact length and bearing of: 			
	(1) All exterior boundary lines; 			
	(2) All blocks; 			
	(3) Public grounds for dedication; 			
	(4) Streets and alleys; 			
	(5) All lot lines. 			
	f. 
Blocks are numbered consecutively. 			
	g. 
Lots in each block are numbered consecutively. 			
	h. 
All outlots are clearly marked. 			
	i. 
Exact width of easements and streets or alleys are marked. 			
	j. 
All lakes and streams are properly surveyed and marked. 			
	k. 
Center lines of all streets are shown, dimensions. 			
	l. 
All points of curve, points of tangency, length of tangent, length of curve, and central angles of all curves of streets, are shown. 			
	m. 
Vicinity sketch, small scale, showing general area of the subdivision. 			
	n. 
The names of all existing and proposed streets. 			
	o. 
All lands to be dedicated to the public to be clearly marked "Dedicated to Public." 			
	p. 
All roads shown on the plat and not dedicated to be clearly marked "Private Road," "Private Street," or "Private Way." 			
	q. 
All existing buildings are shown. 			
	r. 
All watercourses, drainage ditches and other existing features are properly shown. 			
	s. 
The water elevations of all adjoining lakes, rivers or streams at the date of survey, along with the approximate high and low water elevations of such features, are shown. 			
4. 	The following certificates, acknowledgements, and approval clauses are provided: 			
	a. 
Dedication clause including use of corporate seal. 			
	b. 
Notarization. 			
	c. 
Certificate of survey and platting. 			
	d. 
Certificate of approval of the planning commission. 			
	e. 
Certificate of approval, enforcing officer. 			
	f. 
Certificate of approval, (city, village or county) engineer. 			
	g. 
Certificate of approval, legislative body. 			
	h. 
Certificate of approval or acceptance of all encumbrancers. 			
 
	General Considerations 	Yes 	No 	Remarks 
1. 	Is the proposed subdivision in complete conformity with the comprehensive plan? 			
2. 	Does the subdivision make adequate provisions for storm and floodwater runoff channels or basins? 			
3. 	The subdivision gives consideration to the preservation of natural features such as large trees and watercourses and to historical and similar features. 			
4. 	Is the parcel to be subdivided suitable for residential use? 			
5. 	Streets Generally 			
	a. 
Streets are located in relation to topographical conditions and natural terrain features, i.e., streams and existing tree growth, etc. 			
	b. 
Streets are properly integrated with the existing and proposed system of thoroughfares as established on the comprehensive plan. 			
	c. 
Thoroughfares are properly related to special traffic generators, i.e., industries, business districts, schools, churches, etc. 			
	d. 
Minor and local streets are laid out to conform to topography and to discourage use by through traffic. 			
	e. 
Proposed streets are extended to the boundary lines of the subdivision. 			
6. 	Subdivisions Adjacent to Railroad Rights-of-Way or Limited Access Freeways 			
	a. 
In residential districts, a buffer strip (25 feet wide) is added to the normal depth of each lot. 			
	b. 
In commercial or industrial districts lots are of sufficient depth for uses to back on railroad or highway. 			
	c. 
Streets parallel to a railroad intersecting street crossing the railroad are at least 150 feet distant from railroad. 			
7. 	Access to Major Arterials 			
	When a subdivision borders on or contains an arterial streets, access is limited in one of the following ways: 			
	a. 
Subdivision lots back onto major street fronting on a parallel street with screen planting between the lot and the arterial. 			
	b. 
A series of culs-de-sac, u-shaped or loop streets entered from and designed generally at right angles to a parallel street, with the rear lines of their terminal lots backing onto the arterial street. 			
	c. 
A marginal access or service road is provided (separated from the arterial by a planting strip). 			
	d. 
Total number of residential or local streets entering arterial is kept to a minimum. 			
8. 	Street Design Standards 			
	All streets meet the minimum design standards: 			
	a. 
Local streets: 			
	(1) Right-of-way 40, 50, 60 ft. 			
	(2) Pavement 24, 26, 32 ft. 			
	b. 
Collector streets: 			
	(1) Right-of-way 60, 60, 70 ft. 			
	(2) Pavement 30, 32, 40 ft. 			
	c. 
Street grades for major streets do not exceed 6 percent. 			
9. 	Other Street Requirements 			
	a. 
Culs-de-sac serving less than 25 dwelling units to not exceed 1,000 feet in length. 			
	b. 
Culs-de-sac serving 25 or more dwelling units do not exceed 500 feet in length. 			
	c. 
No half (½) streets are provided. 			
10. 	Street Intersections 			
	All street intersections meet the following criteria: 			
	a. 
Streets intersect at right angles (not less than 75 degrees). 			
	b. 
Center line offsets (jogs) of streets are at least 150 feet. 			
	c. 
Curb radii as follows are provided: 			
	(1) Intersection, two local streets, 20 feet. 			
	(2) Intersection involving collector street, at least 30 feet. 			
	d. 
Intersections are designed with a flat grade. 			
	e. 
Cross slopes of all streets, including intersections are 3 percent or less. 			
11. 	Alleys 			
	a. 
Alleys are provided in all commercial and industrial areas. 			
	b. 
All alleys are 24 feet in width or greater. 			
	c. 
No dead-end alleys are included without adequate turnaround facilities. 			
	d. 
No alleys are provided in residential areas. 			
12. 	Block Standards 			
	a. 
All blocks have two (2) tiers of lots (except blocks adjacent to railroad rights-of-way, etc.). 			
	b. 
Block lengths: 			
	(1) Blocks do not exceed 2,000 feet in length. 			
	(2) Blocks are at least 500 feet long. 			
	(3) Blocks along major arterial and collector streets are not less than 1,000 feet. 			
	c. 
Pedestrianways (10 feet wide) are provided through all blocks exceeding 800 feet in length where essential. 			
13. 	Lot Standards 			
	a. 
Lot sizes conform to the zoning ordinance (resolution). 			
	b. 
Depth and width of properties reserved for commercial-industrial uses are sufficient to provide for off-street parking and loading. 			
	c. 
Lots fronting on arterial streets or commercial-industrial lots provide at least 25 feet additional depth. 			
	d. 
Every lot (notwithstanding planned developments) has principal access on a public street. 			
	e. 
Drainage flows away from the lot to an approved drainage system. 			
	f. 
Generally, lots are not platted at right angles to each other. 			
	g. 
Side lot lines are at approximately right angles to street lines. 			
	h. 
Corner lots have extra width to provide appropriate setbacks. 			
	i. 
No double frontage lots are platted. 			
 
APPENDIX D  
Section 1. - Dedication of park lands, school sites and other public lands, or cash contribution in lieu thereof. 
As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision or of a final plan and plat of a planned unit development or any other development of land (hereinafter referred to as a development), each subdivider or developer (hereinafter referred to as a developer) will be required to: dedicate land for park and recreational purposes, land for school sites, and other public lands, to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents or occupants of the development; make a cash contribution in lieu thereof; or some combination of both, at the option of the City, provided, however, that if the park, school and/or fire protection district within which the development is located files with the City a written waiver such dedication and/or contribution with respect to such respective park, school and/or fire protection needs, either in whole or in any specified part, the City shall not require such dedication and/or contribution, either in whole or in any specified part in accordance with such waiver. It shall be a precondition to the enforcement of this Appendix D, with respect to dedications and/or contributions for such respective park, school and/or fire protection needs, that the park, school and/or fire protection district within which the development is located shall have executed and tendered to the city an intergovernmental agreement, in a form acceptable to the city's corporation counsel, including provisions requiring it to hold and use such dedications and/or contributions in accordance with the requirements of this Appendix D, as amended from time to time, and to indemnify, hold harmless and defend the city with respect to: the manner of adoption, amendment or enforcement of this Appendix D, as amended from time to time; the appropriateness, amount or timing of any required dedication and/or contribution or any other aspect of this Appendix D, as amended from time to time; and the park, school and/or fire protection district's holding and use of such dedications and/or contributions. Unless otherwise provided in the resolution or ordinance approving such final plat or final plan and plat or other instrument granting final development approval, such dedication and/or contribution shall be due as a precondition to such approval. Such dedications and/or contributions shall be in accordance with the following criteria: 
1.  Criteria for Requiring Park And Recreation Land Dedication: 
1.1.  Requirements And Population Ratio: The ultimate population of a proposed development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required for dedication. The total land dedication requirement shall be ten (10) acres of land per one thousand (1,000) of ultimate population. The required ten (10) acres may be allocated by the City Council, in its discretion, based upon the following criteria: 
Classification 	Approximate 
Size 	Minimum 
Acres Per 
1,000 People 
(a.) 
Neighborhood Parks 	 4-10 acres 	 4.0 
(b.) 
Community Parks 	10-20 acres 	 6.0 
Total: 		10.0 acres 
of land per 
1,000 people 
 
The ultimate population of a proposed development shall be calculated in accordance with Section 6 hereinbelow. 
1.2.  Location: The Comprehensive Park and Recreation Plan and/or the "Standards by Types of Recreation and Park Area" as adopted by the West Chicago Park District shall be used as a guideline in locating sites. A park site, of not less than five (5) acres, adjoining all elementary school sites shall be considered a requirement. A central location which will serve equally the entire development is most desirable. In large developments these sites can be located throughout the development according to established standards for park area distances. 
1.3.  Credit for Private Open Spaces and Recreation Areas: When developers provide their own open space for recreation areas and facilities, it has the effect of reducing the demand for local public recreational services. Depending on the size of the development, a portion of the park and recreational area in developments may, at the option of the City Council, be provided in the form of "private" open space in-lieu-of dedicated "public" open space. The extent of same shall be determined by the City Council, based upon the needs of the projected residents and in conformance to the total park and recreation land for the general area. 
In general, a substitution of private open space for dedicated parks will imply a substantially higher degree of improvement and the installation of recreational facilities, including equipment by the developer as part of his obligation. Detailed plans of such areas, including specifications of facilities to be installed, must be approved by the City, and before any credit is given for private recreation areas, the developer shall guarantee that these private recreation areas will be permanently maintained for such use by the execution of the appropriate legal documents. Private "swimming clubs" are included in this provision. When an adjustment for private recreation areas is warranted, it will be necessary to compute the total park land dedication that would have been required from the subdivision or planned unit development and then subtract the credit to be given. 
2.  Criteria for Requiring School Site Dedication: 
2.1.  Requirements and Population Ratio: The ultimate number of students to be generated by a proposed development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required to be dedicated for school sites. The land dedication requirement shall be determined by obtaining the ratio of: (a) the estimated number of children to be served in each school classification over (b) the maximum recommended number of students to be served in each such school classification as stated herein, and then applying such ratio to (c) the minimum recommended number of acres for a school site of each such school classification as sated herein. The product thereof shall be the acres of land deemed needed to have sufficient land for school sites to serve the estimated increased children in each such school classification. 
2.2.  School Classifications and Size of School Site: School classifications and size of school sites within the city shall be determined in accordance with the following criteria: 
School Classification 
by Grades 	Maximum Number 
of Students for 
each such School 
Classification 	Minimum Number 
of Acres of Land 
for each school 
Site of such 
Classification 
Elementary Schools 
grades kindergarten 
through 6th 	  600 students 	11 acres 
Junior High Schools 
grades 7th through 8th 	  700 students 	27 acres 
High Schools grades 
9th through 12th 	2,300 students 	53 acres 
 
2.3.  Location: The Comprehensive School Plan and/or the standards adopted by the affected school district shall be used as a guideline in locating sites. 
3.  Criteria for Requiring Other Public Land Dedication, Fire Protection Sites: 
3.1.  Requirements And Fire Protection Burden: The fire protection burden to be generated by a proposed development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required to be dedicated for fire protection sites. In order to provide and/or maintain adequate fire protection, including the ability to dispatch firefighting and emergency medical service equipment and personnel with adequate response times and to provide necessary housing of general and specialized equipment, personnel quarters, training facilities and administrative facilities, a series of individual local fire stations, together with a supporting central and/or regional fire station(s), is necessary. 
Each individual local fire station providing basic, first line units for initial response to fires and emergency medical service needs requires two and four/tenths (2.4) acres of land. Each such local fire station is supported be a central and/or regional fire station providing additional first line units, specialized equipment and training and administrative facilities, requiring an additional six/tenths (0.6) of an acre for each such local fire station which it supports. Each individual local fire station, therefore, requires a total of three (3) acres of land for itself and the additional incremental area for a central and/or regional fire station. 
Each area of residential development of two (2) square miles (i.e. 1,280 acres) generates the need for an individual local fire station. Each area of non-residential (i.e. commercial and/or industrial) development containing six million two hundred fifty thousand (6,250,000) square feet of non-residential buildings generates the need for an individual local fire station. The required land dedication shall be determined for residential developments, or residential portions of developments, by multiplying the total acreage to be developed by 0.00234 (i.e. the ratio of three (3) acres required for fire protection purposes per 1,280 acres of territory). The required land dedication shall be determined for non-residential developments, or non-residential portions of developments, by multiplying the total building square footage to be constructed by 0.00000048 acres per square foot (i.e. the ratio of three (3) acres required for fire protection purposes per 6,250,000 square feet of commercial and/or industrial buildings). 
3.2.  Location: The Comprehensive Fire Protection Plan and/or standards adopted by the affected fire protection district shall be used as a guideline in locating sites. 
4.  Criteria for Requiring Library Land Dedication: 
4.1.  Requirements And Population Ratio: The ultimate population of a proposed development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required for dedication. The total land dedication requirement shall be one-and-one-half (1½) acres of land per ten thousand (10,000) of ultimate population. The ultimate population of a proposed development shall be calculated in accordance with Section 6 hereinbelow 
4.2.  Location: The Comprehensive Library Plan and/or standards adopted by the affected library protection district shall be used as a guideline in locating sites. 
5.  Criteria for Requiring a Cash Contribution In-Lieu-Of Park, School, Fire Protection and/or Library Sites: The City shall require the developer to pay a cash contribution in-lieu-of or in combination with the land dedication required when so determined by the public body which would be the recipient of the land, subject to final City approval. The cash contributions in-lieu-of park and recreation land dedication shall be held in trust by the City, or other public body designated by the City, solely for the acquisition and or improvement of park and recreation land as hereinbefore classified, which will be available to serve the immediate or future needs of the residents of that development. The cash contributions in-lieu-of school sites shall be held in trust by the City, or other public body designated by the City, solely for use in the acquisition and/or improvement of land for school sites to serve the immediate or future needs of children from that development. The cash contributions in-lieu-of fire protection sites shall be held in trust by the City, or other public body designated by the City, solely for use in the acquisition and/or improvement of land for fire station sites to serve the immediate or future needs of the residents or occupants of that development. The cash contributions in-lieu-of library sites shall be held in trust by the City, or other public body designated by the City, solely for use in the acquisition and/or improvement of land for library sites to serve the immediate or future needs of the residents or occupants of that development. 
Improvements under this Section 4 shall be liberally construed and shall include, but shall not be limited to the development of: sidewalks; adjacent streets, including but not limited to pavement, curbs, gutters and street lights; connections with sewers, water, electrical and other utility lines; and, as appropriate, grading, seeding and/or sodding, and/or drainage and erosion controls. 
If any improvement provided for herein shall require voter referendum approval under existing statutory authority before such funds may be lawfully expended, then and in those cases such approval shall be first obtained. 
If any portion of a cash contribution in-lieu-of dedication of land is not expended for the purposes set forth herein within ten (10) years from the date of receipt, it shall be refunded to the owners of record of all lots, except lots dedicated pursuant to the provisions hereof, in the development for which such contribution was made. The refund shall be paid to the person who is the owner of record on the day which is the tenth anniversary of the receipt of such contribution. The amount of the refund due to each lot owner shall be equal to the amount of the original contribution, divided by the total number of lots in the development (excluding only those lots which were dedicated pursuant to the provisions hereof) for which such contribution was made. 
The cash contributions in-lieu-of land shall be based on the fair market value of the acres of land in the area improved as specified in section 8 herein, that otherwise would have been dedicated pursuant to the provisions hereof. If has been determined that the present fair market value of such improved land in and surrounding the City is: (a) one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) per acre with respect to residential use land (or six hundred dollars ($600.00) per acre for library purposes); and (b) two hundred thirty thousand dollars ($230,000.00) per acre with respect to non-residential use land (or eleven cents ($0.11) per square foot of building area for fire protection purposes). The fair market value for non-residential use land shall be used for developments of a mixed-use nature. Said figures shall be used in making any calculation herein unless the developer files a written objection thereto. In the event of any such objection the developer shall submit an appraisal showing the fair market value of such improved land n the area of his development or other evidence thereof and final determination of said fair market value per acre of such improved land shall be made by the City Council based upon such information submitted by the developer and from other sources which may be submitted to the City Council by the park district, school district, fire protection district, library district or others. The City shall be entitled to an administrative fee in connection with the administration hereof, which fee shall total five (5) percent of the contribution required under this section. 
6.  [Formula] For Determining Ultimate Population, Ultimate Numbers of Students and Fire Protection Burden: The following table of population density represents current and short range projected trends in family size for a new residential construction and shall, where applicable, be used in calculating the amount of required dedication of acres of land and/or the cash contribution in-lieu-thereof unless a written objection is filed thereto by the developer:
