Naperville, Illinois 
For all developments in which the population density and/or the square footage of non-residential buildings to be constructed, cannot be precisely determined at the time of approval of the development, the land donation requirement shall be determined as follows. The ultimate population and number of children to be served in each school classification shall be calculated on the basis of a mix of bedrooms by dwelling unit type for each residential zoning district, determined by the City on the basis of the current trends resulting from actual permits issued in similar developments. In planned unit developments, the bedroom mix used for single-family detached dwelling units shall be based upon the bedroom mix for that zoning district which is most representative of the lot sizes approved, as determined by the City on the basis of current trends resulting from actual building permits issued for such representative zoning district; and the bedroom mix used for single-family attached and multiple-family dwelling units shall be based upon the number of units and mix of bedrooms as indicated on the approved final plan and plat of planned unit development. The square footage of non-residential buildings to be constructed shall be determined by the City on the basis of the current trends resulting from actual permits issued in similar developments. 
In the event a developer files a written objection to one or more of the tables, formulae and/or determinations pursuant to this section, he shall submit his own study showing the estimated additional population and/or non-residential building square footage to be generated from the development and in that event final determination of the formula to be used in such calculations shall be made by the City Council based upon such information submitted by the developer and from other sources which may be submitted to the City Council by the park districts, school districts, fire districts or others. It is recognized that population density, age distribution and local conditions change over time, and the specific formula for the dedication of land, or the payment of fees in-lieu-thereof, as stated herein, is subject to periodic review and amendment as necessary. 
7.  Reservation of Additional Land: Where the Comprehensive Plan of the City calls for a larger amount or size of park and recreational land and/or school and/or fire protection sites in a particular proposed development, than the developer is required to dedicate pursuant to the provisions hereof, the land needed beyond the developer's required contribution shall, if so determined by the City Council, be reserved for subsequent purchase by the City or other public body designated by the City, provided that such purchase is made, or proceedings to acquire such land by condemnation are commenced, within one year from the date of approval of the final plat or plan for the development. 
8.  Combining With Adjoining Developments: For all developments of less than fifty (50) acres, public open space, or school or fire protection sites, which are to be dedicated should, where possible, be combined with dedications from adjoining developments in order to produce usable recreation areas or sites without undue hardship to a particular developer. 
9.  Dedicated Sites, Topography, Grading and Improvements: The slope, topography and geology of each dedicated site as well as its surroundings must be suitable for its intended purposes. Grading on dedicated sites shall not differ greatly from surrounding land. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a dedicated site may, with the consent of the public body which would be the recipient of such site, include areas of minimal or limited suitability, such as wetlands and stormwater detention areas. The acreage of such areas of minimal or limited suitability shall not be used to satisfy, or be credited against, the land dedication requirement with respect to such public body, except to the extent that the standards adopted by such public body provide a formula or methodology for crediting or partial crediting of such areas of minimal or limited suitability. 
All sites shall be dedicated as improved sites, i.e. in a graded, seeded and/or sodded condition with appropriate drainage and erosion controls and ready for full service of streets (including but not limited to pavement, curbs, gutters and street lights), sewers, water and electrical and other utilities, or acceptable provision made therefore. Sidewalks and trees shall be included within the definition of improved sites, but may be delayed for school and fire protection sites due to the delay time between dedication of any such sites and construction of facilities thereon. 
10.  Title of Sites: All sites shall be conveyed to the City either by warranty or trustee's deed, provided, however, that the City may permit such conveyance directly to the public body which would be the recipient of such site. The subdivider or developer shall be responsible for conveying good, merchantable title to such sites, and shall be responsible for payment of all real estate taxes to the date of conveyance, including any agricultural roll back taxes which might be extended or levied against such sites, for any tax years or periods prior to the time of conveyance. 
11.  Sale of Dedicated Land: When, in the opinion of the unit of local government holding title to any parcel of land dedicated hereunder, any such parcel has become unnecessary or unsuitable or inconvenient, such parcel may be sold as provided by applicable statutory authority and the proceeds shall be held in trust by said unit of local government, solely for such uses as are provided for herein, and said proceeds shall be subject to the ten (10) year expenditure requirements from and after the date when said land is converted to cash proceeds. 
12.  Property Conveyance. Any property transferred to the City of West Chicago hereunder shall be transferred so as to be unencumbered by any liens, taxes or other clouds upon title of said property. The Grantor of any property hereunder shall remain responsible and liable for any and all real estate taxes accrued but not yet due and payable. Said tax obligation shall not be rolled into or extinguished by a deed to the City of West Chicago. 
As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision or of a final plan and plat of a planned unit development or any other development of land, each subdivider, developer or builder shall be required to pay a cash contribution for library purposes in an amount equal to $500.00 per acre. 
(Ord. No. 3060, § 1, 3-17-97; Ord. No. 02-O-0091, § 1, 7-15-2002; Ord. No. 04-O-0012, § 1, 6-21-2004; Ord. No. 08-O-003, § 1, 2-4-2008)  
Article XVI. - Addendum "A" 
CITY OF WEST CHICAGO 
AMENDMENTS TO "STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS FOR WATER AND SEWER MAIN 
CONSTRUCTION IN ILLINOIS" THIRD EDITION, SEPTEMBER, 1978 
Division I. General Requirements and Covenants 
Section 7-2.01A. In the third paragraph, the fifth and sixth lines, delete the phrase "or within ten (10) days after the execution of the contract, whichever date is reached first." In the eleventh and twelfth line strike the phrase "or within ten (10) days after the execution of the contract, whichever date is reached first." 
Section 7-2.02. In the third paragraph strike the phrase "or within ten (10) days after the execution of the contract whichever date is reached first." 
Section 9-11. Delete this entire section. 
Division II. Excavation and Clean-up 
Section 20-2.20A(1)(a). In the first paragraph delete the second sentence and change the first sentence to read as follows: "Granular Cradle, to a depth of six (6) inches below the bottom of each conduit, shall be constructed prior to the placement of all conduit, except when a modification is ordered by the Engineer or shown on the plans." In the second paragraph, delete the following sentences: "Granular Cradle shall be allowed for separate payment only in the locations where the use of these items is specified or ordered by the Engineer. A Change in type of cradle material shall not be made unless a minimum of two (2) cubic yards of material is allowed for payment." 
Section 20-2.20A(1)(b). Delete the second paragraph. Change title of section to read "Water Drain Pipes and Pipe Sewers." 
Section 20-2.20A(1)(c). Delete this section. 
Section 20-2.20A(2). Delete this section as written. Insert the following: "When unsuitable soil conditions are encountered, which require the removal of unsuitable materials lower than six (6) inches below the bottom of the conduit or the depth of bedding shown on the plan, the contractor shall replace the material removed with granular cradle of the grade approved by the Engineer."

APPENDIX C - PERSONNEL RULES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 2378, adopted Jan. 7, 1991, deleted former App. C, Personnel directors of the executive department, which was amended by Ord. No. 1764, § 1, adopted Oct. 1, 1984. A new App. C was enacted by § 3 of Ord. No. 2378, effective Jan. 9, 1991, except Art. V, which became effective May 1, 1991. Ord. No. 4181, § 1, adopted May 17, 1999, deleted App. C, Art. IX, safety program. Ord. No. 4192, § 1, adopted June 21, 1999 enacted new Arts. I, II, and V—IX of the personnel manual as set out herein. Ord. No. 4212, § 1, adopted Sept. 7, 1999 deleted Arts. III and IV which pertained to position classification plan and compensation plan, respectively. New Arts. III and IV of the personnel manual attached to Ord. No. 4212 as "Exhibit A" were set out herein. The user's attention is directed to the Code Comparative Table at the back of this volume for derivation of App. C. 
Cross reference— Civil service rules and regulations, App. D. 
 
ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
A. - Authority and administration 
The city administrator shall administer, or cause to be administered, the provisions of this manual. This authority includes the following activities: 
(1)  Hire and promote within budgeted authority; 
(2)  Establish and approve appropriate work rules consistent with the terms of this manual; 
(3)  Discipline, demote, suspend, lay off and recommend dismissal of any employee; 
(4)  Determine when work performed by employees may be more effectively or efficiently contracted; and 
(5)  Interpret the meaning of these rules. 
The department heads will be expected to work with the administration department concerning any personnel matter in their departments. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
B. - Amendments and revisions 
This manual will be issued to all employees. New full-time employees will receive the manual during their employee orientation. The City of West Chicago, like so many other employers, must be dynamic and changes may occur. 
Amendments to these rules will be made from time to time by ordinance prepared by the city administrator and approved by the city council. All amendments shall be acknowledged by employees through the signing of an "Amendment Acknowledgement Form". As you receive changes, either make a note of them in the manual or place a copy in the manual for future reference. 
Amendments will normally be posted prior to their effective date. The city, however, reserves the right to make changes without notice when it is deemed appropriate. Amendments may have a retroactive effect to reflect a practice adopted prior to a formal revision of the rules. 
In any event, if you have questions, either speak to your supervisor or contact the administration department. They'll be happy to speak to you. City employees are encouraged to submit comments or suggestions to the administration department. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
C. - External agreements and laws 
In the event of a conflict between the terms of this manual and those of an applicable collective bargaining agreement, the collective bargaining agreement shall control. If any of the policies adopted herein conflict with state or federal laws, or the rules and regulations of the Civil Service Commission, those laws and rules shall take precedence. Some employees may have an employment agreement or contract with the city; in the event of a conflict, that employment agreement shall take precedence. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
D. - Gender clause 
Whenever the male gender is used in this manual (he, him, his), the term shall be interpreted to mean and apply to both males and females equally. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
E. - Application 
Unless otherwise provided, the personnel rules shall apply to all officers and employees of the City of West Chicago, except elected officials, board and commission members, and the city attorney. Rules and regulations specifically applicable to employees not covered by the civil service commission are noted throughout the manual. If conflicts arise between the provisions of this manual and either collective bargaining agreements or employment contracts, the latter shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 06-O-0001, § 2, 2-6-2006)  
F. - Civil service commission 
Additional personnel policies pertaining to sworn personnel in the police department covered under civil service jurisdiction in those positions deemed classified under the Civil Service Act will be found under the civil service rules and regulations published by the civil service commission, and are located in appendix D of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 06-O-0001, § 3, 2-6-2006)  
G. - Chain of command 
The city recognizes everyone's right to freedom of expression in matters of public concern. Matters that are merely personal to the employee should be addressed through the hierarchy of command, starting with the immediate supervisor. The management and administration of the city has the responsibility to address issues or decisions that may affect personal aspects of employment, and in many cases they can be resolved. The city maintains a grievance procedure to resolve issues between employees and the city regarding the inappropriate or misapplication of policy contained in the personnel manual. Violating this provision of the manual may lead to disciplinary action. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
H. - Requests for city personnel 
Department heads shall inform the city administrator of vacancies in their departments. If the city administrator approves the request for a non-appointed employee, he shall forward such request to the chief examiner for the civil service commission to establish an eligible list that will be used to fill the vacancy. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
I. - Employment categories 
The city classifies positions in three categories: full time, part-time and temporary/seasonal. 
(1)  Full-time: Regular employees scheduled to work a minimum workweek of forty (40) hours. Full-time employees who have successfully completed their probationary period are eligible for the complete benefit program of the city. 
(2)  Part-time: Regular employees scheduled to work less than forty (40) hours a week with no set duration of employment. Part-time employees who have successfully completed their probationary period, are only eligible for vacation time as mentioned later in the manual and legally required mandated benefits, including deductions for the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund (IMRF). They are also eligible for certain payroll deductions such as deferred compensation plans, direct deposit, medical/dental and dependant care at their own cost, etc. 
(3)  Seasonal or temporary: Employees hired for a specific period of time or for the duration of a specific project or group of assignments of limited duration, not to exceed ninety (90) days in a twelve (12) month period. This category of employees is eligible only for legally mandated benefits. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
J. - Definitions 
Appointed or exempt position: A position that is filled by the mayor with the consent of the city council. Employment may be governed by a contract signed with the city. 
City: As used in this manual, City means the City of West Chicago. 
City council: As used in this manual, city council refers to the city council of the City of West Chicago. 
City administrator: The city administrator is the chief administrative officer of the city who is appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council. 
Classified position or protective service: A position that has been appointed by the city administrator from the civil service commission's eligibility list who has successfully completed his probationary period. 
Collective bargaining agreement: As used in these rules, this term will refer to any effective and applicable labor agreement between the City of West Chicago and unions representing employees. 
Continuous service: As used in this manual, this term describes the method by which work time is calculated for the purpose of determining vacation and sick leave benefit accumulation only. Except as otherwise provided by this manual, a unit of continuous service is earned if the employee works at least fifty (50) percent of the days he or she is scheduled in the period appropriate to that unit. Continuous service for all benefits and leave will be calculated from the date of the most recent employment. Past employment will not be calculated and applied toward earnings. 
Discharge/termination: Discharge is the permanent removal from employment with the corresponding permanent loss of all privileges of employment. 
Grievance: The timely expression of dissatisfaction by an employee regarding the application of any of the terms and conditions of employment described in this manual including, but not limited to, the application of disciplinary procedures by a supervisor, rates of pay, hours of work, or application of standard of workload. 
Immediate family: This term refers to an employee's child, spouse or parent. "Parent" means the person who acted as the employee's parent when the employee was a child. Except as otherwise noted, this term does not include a parent-in-law. 
Job evaluation and classification. A technique for analyzing work in which the Activities and requirements of a job are described according to a standardized procedure. Individual jobs are then classified with those sufficiently similar. Jobs are evaluated on a point based system. Points are based on the factors of expertise, decision making, supervisory responsibilities, contact with others required by the job, and working conditions. 
Performance evaluation: This is an objective evaluation of the employee's performance through which an opportunity is provided for the employee to discuss such items as expectations, personal performance, and methods of improvement with a supervisor. 
Regular schedule: Not less than eighty (80) hours per pay period. 
Regular workday: A workday is defined as an eight and one-half (8½) hour day which includes a thirty (30) minute unpaid lunch. 
Reprimand—oral: Oral reprimands consist of a conference between the employee's supervisor or department head issuing the reprimand and the employee for the purpose of expressing disapproval of misconduct or poor work performance, clarifying applicable rules or standards of performance, policies and procedures and warning that repetition of the misconduct or failure to improve work performance may result in more severe discipline. 
Reprimand—written: Written reprimands consist of a conference between the employee's supervisor or department head issuing the reprimand and the employee; and of a letter or memorandum expressing disapproval of misconduct or poor work performance, clarifying applicable rules or standards of performance, policies and procedures and warning that repetition of the misconduct or failure to improve work performance may result in more severe discipline. 
Suspension: A suspension is a temporary removal from employment, which may or may not be accompanied by a concurrent temporary loss of privileges of employment, including, but not limited to, salary and benefits. 
Time worked: A day will be considered worked if the employee is present for their full regular schedule or on a paid holiday, paid vacation or paid leave. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
K. - Appointment of temporary acting city administrator 
In the event that the city administrator shall be absent from the city or ceases to perform the duties or hold the office of city administrator, the mayor may appoint a temporary acting city administrator to perform the duties of said office until the city administrator returns to the city of a new city administrator is appointed to and qualifies for office. 
(Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
ARTICLE II. - TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT 
 
A. - General provisions 
The city administrator is appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council. With the exception of those specific positions listed in Article III of the City Code, whose appointments adhere to the same rules, hiring for all other positions falls within the authority of the city administrator or the civil service commission as appropriate. All recruitment and selection processes shall adhere to federal, state and local employment laws. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 06-O-0001, § 5, 2-6-2006)  
B. - Equal employment opportunity 
The City of West Chicago, its officials, agents and employees are legally required to practice policies that are in compliance with federal equal employment opportunity laws and executive orders forbidding any type of discrimination against the employees or applicants. It is the city's policy to offer equal employment opportunity to all persons without regard to race, color, creed, religion, sex, age, national origin or ancestry, marital status, military status (except dishonorable discharge), or qualifying disability or other legally protected category. Any individual's legally protected status shall not be a factor in any phase of employment, including hiring, payment of wages, job assignment, seniority, promotion, transfer, layoff, discipline, discharge, or any other term or condition of employment. No one will be retaliated against by the city for exercising his rights under this policy. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
C. - Employment application 
In general, applications for employment shall be submitted to the administration department on a prescribed employment application form. The application form shall be completed in its entirety and any evidence of falsification or fraud on the form may be grounds for discharge or disqualification from consideration for employment. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
D. - Background investigation 
A background investigation may be completed on every new employee prior to employment. Applicants must possess, or qualify to possess, a valid driver's license of the appropriate class depending on the nature of their position or assignment. Driver's license status, along with driving history, must be verified with the secretary of state's office. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
E. - Post-offer examination: physical and drug/alcohol screen 
Applicants for a full or part-time position who receive a conditional offer of employment may be required to take a post-offer medical examination and/or drug/alcohol screen by a licensed physician designated, and paid for, by the city. Individuals who, with reasonable accommodation, are capable of performing the essential functions of the job will be considered for employment. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
F. - Citizenship and residence 
All employees of the city hired after November 6, 1986, must be citizens of the United States or be an alien authorized to work in the United States under the provisions of the Federal Immigration Reform and Control Act. All new employees will be required to submit documentation to the city which establishes both the employee's identity and eligibility to work in the United States as required by law. 
Although city employees are encouraged to reside in West Chicago, residency within the city or at any specific distance from the city is not a prerequisite for initial or continued employment unless specifically required in a job description or contract. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
G. - New employee orientation and training 
It is important for an employee to understand the benefits and conditions of employment from the very outset. An orientation will be conducted by the administration department, on an individual or group basis, on or before you begin work on the first day. During orientation, you will be given enrollment information for the city's benefit plans, required legal documentation will be completed, and you will have the opportunity to ask questions concerning your employment. 
It is the responsibility of the department to orient and train new employees as to the procedures within the department. Such orientation will include an introduction to departmental employees and an explanation of the operations of the department in which the new employee will be working. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
H. - Probationary period 
All persons employed by the city to fill a position must serve a six (6) month probationary period. 
(1)  The purpose of the probationary period is to evaluate the employee's ability to satisfactorily perform the job and complete the necessary training or education required for the position. An employee's supervisor will monitor the employee's job performance during this period. If the probationary employee fails to attain satisfactory job performance, the employee may be dismissed by the department head upon recommendation to and approval by the city administrator or his designee and, in the case of civil service employees, the civil service commission. 
(2)  Three (3) months after an employee's hire, transfer or promotion, an informal performance evaluation shall be conducted. A formal evaluation of performance by an immediate supervisor shall occur five (5) months after an employee's hire, transfer or promotion. This evaluation will be submitted to the city administrator or his designee and will provide a recommendation for dismissal or retention of the newly hired employee. 
(3)  Upon successful completion of the probationary period, the employee is entitled to all city benefits and privileges prescribed in this manual. If the position is classified, the city administrator or his designee shall notify the civil service commission of a change in an employee's status. 
(4)  During the probationary period, employees are not entitled to use either vacation or personal days. However, under certain circumstances, exceptions may be made with the approval of the department head and city administrator or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4212, § 2, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
I. - Performance appraisals 
Performance appraisals are the formal record of the determinations on which merit pay decisions are made. These tools are also used to: recognize good performance unrelated to pay considerations; document poor performance as a part of the system of correcting such problems; and document progress in correcting performance problems identified in an earlier review or by other means. Employees should use performance appraisals as an opportunity to discuss employee development and training needs; as a record of past performance; and as an opportunity to objectively discuss, with the supervisor, expectations, personal performance and methods of improvement. 
(1)  Formal performance evaluation reports shall be prepared biannually on forms approved by the city administrator. 
(2)  A supervisor should review the employee's personnel file, including prior reviews of goals and success in meeting them and any relevant documentation in advance of the meeting. The departmental performance evaluation should be completed prior to the meeting. 
(3)  Whether an employee is entitled to a pay increase or not, the supervisor will present a written performance appraisal in November (update goals) and April (merit pay review). The employee will be asked to sign this document whether he agrees or disagrees with the contents; the employee may incorporate his own comments in the evaluation. The signature on the completed appraisal means that the employee has had an opportunity to review the document and does not necessarily signify agreement with the supervisor's opinions. 
(4)  Completed appraisals will be forwarded to the department head for review and to add written comments, and then it is submitted to the administration department for final review. The administration department will review each performance evaluation to ensure that there is sufficient supporting evidence of the results of the review. The evaluation will be placed in the employee's official personnel file and each department should keep a copy as well. 
(5)  A performance evaluation expresses the supervisor's opinions and judgments concerning job performance throughout the evaluation period. Because of this, the results of the evaluation are not subject to review or appeal through the grievance procedure or other formal review process. If an employee is in disagreement with the appraisal, he may discuss the issues with the next level of management (within five (5) days of receiving his appraisal) and then to the city administrator or his designee (within five (5) days of receiving the last response). However, their decision is final and must be reported to the applicable supervisor and department head in writing. 
(6)  At any time, a supervisor may elect, and is encouraged, to make a record of specific performance without completing a full evaluation. Such reports should be limited to recognition or problem identification. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
J. - Change of employment classification 
If department operations permit, as determined by the department head and city administrator, a full-time employee may, upon request, work part-time hours instead of full-time hours in the same position. While on part-time employment status, the following conditions shall apply: 
(1)  The actual length of time on part-time employment status will be determined by the department head and city administrator or his designee. Regardless of the time permitted, part-time employment status will be continuously monitored and may at any time be revoked by the department head and city administrator or his designee. 
(2)  The employee will be treated the same as any other part-time employee. That is, the employee will earn the same benefits as other part-time employees, as outlined in this manual. 
(3)  The employee will not earn any sick leave or vacation credits while working on a part-time basis, but will earn time toward longevity. 
(4)  The employee will be permitted to continue participation in the health and dental programs under the guidelines set forth in article VI, section O of this manual. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
K. - Transfers 
(1)  Employee's request: Employees who wish to transfer back to a former position shall not be guaranteed the position. 
(2)  Management's request: An employee may be laterally transferred within a department or between departments to a position having the same pay grade and required skill level upon request of the department head of the department to which the employee would be transferring and approval of the city administrator or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 02-O-0112, § 1, 10-7-2002)  
L. - Time reports 
Each department will provide forms for recording time worked. 
All employees shall be required to: record time accurately and submit a time sheet daily; not sign in or start work before their schedule; take a lunch or dinner break if provided for in their regular shift schedule and record it as time not worked; identify absences which are not considered hours worked for pay purposes; and complete only their own time reports and submit on a timely basis. Supervisors are required to approve each subordinate's time report or pay period time sheet. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
ARTICLE III. - POSITION CLASSIFICATION PLAN 
 
A. - Purpose 
The purpose of the Classification Plan is to provide a complete and continuous inventory of all positions in the municipal service and accurate descriptions and specifications for each class of employment to allow for the effective and efficient operation of the City. The Plan standardizes titles, each of which is indicative of a definite range of duties and responsibilities, and has the same meaning throughout the municipal service. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
B. - Policy statement 
(1)  On an annual basis in the first quarter of the calendar year, the city administrator will prepare a comprehensive classification pay plan and table of organization to achieve consistent equitable and competitive salary ranges and practices, to the extent possible. 
(2)  Pay practices shall be consistent with the goal of pay for performance for each employee classification. General pay and pay increases will be based primarily on an employee's performance evaluation. 
(3)  In developing the classification and pay plans, the city administrator will rely on appropriate analytical techniques, including the use of salary survey data. 
(4)  The job evaluation shall be used to rank jobs and identify benchmark positions for the compensation comparisons described herein. 
(5)  If no comparative data is available for a particular position, a position's rank when compared to other similar city positions shall be used as a guide to establish the pay range. 
(6)  The city's compensation pay plan is a goal. These personnel rules or pay plan do not create or constitute a promise or contract and shall not be binding upon the city. 
(7)  Nothing in these rules guarantees that any employee is entitled to any particular compensation, except as may be required by law. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
C. - Composition of the classification plan 
The classification pay plan consists of: 
(1)  A grouping into classes of positions which are substantially similar in degree of difficulty, required responsibility, which require the same general qualifications, and which can be equitably compensated within the same range of pay under comparable working conditions. 
(2)  A title which identifies and describes the position of each written classification. 
(3)  Written class specifications for each class of position, containing a description of the nature of the work and of the responsibility of the positions in the class, examples of work which are illustrative of duties of positions assigned to the class, requirements of knowledge, abilities, and skills necessary for performance of the work, a statement of experience and training desirable for recruitment or inclusion into the class and, in certain cases, necessary special qualifications. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
D. - Preparation of job descriptions 
A written job description will usually be developed for all personnel positions of the City of West Chicago. Each job description may include the following items and requirements: 
(1)  Title or position. 
(2)  Definition or description of position. 
(3)  Required, or assigned, supervision. 
(4)  Examples of primary responsibilities and duties divided into essential and non-essential categories. 
(5)  Qualifications including required knowledge and ability statements necessary for the position. 
(6)  Experience and training required for the position. 
(7)  Other special licenses, certifications or requirements for the position. 
All new personnel positions shall have a job description submitted to and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
E. - Class titles 
Class titles shall be used in all personnel, budget, appropriation, and financial records, wherever possible. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
F. - Class specifications 
Specifications are to be interpreted in their entirety, and in relation to others in the classification plan. Specifications are deemed to be descriptive and explanatory of the kind of work performed and not necessarily inclusive of all duties performed. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
G. - Uses of the classification plan 
The classification plan shall be used: 
(1)  In preparing public announcements of examinations for vacancies or openings. 
(2)  As a guide in preparing examinations that will measure qualifications needed to adequately perform the duties and responsibilities of the class. 
(3)  In determining the lines of promotion according to the civil service rules and regulations. 
(4)  For developing training programs. 
(5)  In preparing personnel expenditures in departmental budgets. 
(6)  In determining salaries or salary ranges for various types of work. 
(7)  In providing uniform job terminology, which is easy to understand by all city officials, employees, and the general public. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
H. - Maintenance of the classification plan 
The city administrator, or his designee, shall make necessary amendments to the classification plan in the form of new classes, revision of existing classes and the elimination of classes no longer required in the plan. Revisions of class specifications and reallocations within the classification plan shall be made as follows: 
(1)  The city administrator, or his designee, shall review the duties and responsibilities of each new position as it is created and positions which duties and responsibilities have changed and designate the appropriate pay range using the principles of internal and external parity. 
(2)  The city administrator, or his designee, shall periodically review the classification of positions and, upon the basis of these investigations, may combine, upgrade, downgrade, eliminate, or, if necessary, establish new classifications. 
(3)  An employee who wishes to have the classification of that position reviewed should refer to the steps in the grievance procedure of these rules. (See Article VII, Employee Conduct and Disciplinary Procedure, Section C, Grievance Procedure). 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
ARTICLE IV. - COMPENSATION PLAN 
 
A. - Composition of the compensation plan 
The compensation pay plan shall be administered by the city administrator and shall include the schedules of standard salary ranges consisting of minimum and maximum rates of pay included in the classification plan. 
The objectives of the pay plan are: 
(a)  To provide salary ranges which are reasonably comparable to those paid by other governmental jurisdictions in the immediate area. 
(b)  To maintain internal parity among positions of similar responsibility and skill levels. 
(c)  To provide a plan based on merit. 
(d)  To provide orderly and uniform means of recognizing employees for good performances. 
(e)  To simplify and facilitate payroll administration, budgeting, and other phases of financial and personnel administration. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
B. - Development and maintenance of salary ranges 
(1)  Salary ranges shall be reflective of position classification and shall be determined with due regard to the following factors: 
(a)  The knowledge, skills, and abilities required to satisfactorily perform the work. 
(b)  The nature and degree of supervision received. 
(c)  The nature of supervision exercised. 
(d)  Any special working conditions related to the work. 
(2)  Prior to the preparation of each annual budget, as well as at other times as determined by the city administrator, the city administrator shall make or shall cause to have made such comparative studies as deemed necessary to assess and evaluate the factors affecting the level of salary ranges. On the basis of information derived from such studies and other sources, the city administrator may make changes in the assignment of salary ranges to classes. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
C. - Appointment rate 
(1)  The minimum rate of pay for a class shall be paid upon appointment to the class, except that appointment rates above the minimum rate may be paid if the department head submits a written request outlining reasons for such action, which request is subject to approval by the city administrator. 
(2)  Justification for approval will be limited to recognition of exceptional qualifications of a candidate or lack of available candidates at the minimum rate. If a former employee is re-employed in a class in which he was previously employed, the city administrator may approve an appointment at the same rate of pay which the employee was receiving at the termination or separation of his service, provided it is within the appropriate salary range. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
D. - Rate of pay in transfer, promotion or demotion 
If an employee is transferred, promoted or demoted, the rate of pay for the new position shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  If the rate of pay in the former class is less than the minimum rate established for the class in the new position, the rate of pay shall be increased at least to the minimum for the class, as approved by the city administrator. 
(2)  If the rate of pay in the former class is more than the maximum rate established for the new class, the pay shall be reduced to the maximum rate or an intermediate increment of the new range, as approved by the city administrator. 
(3)  If the rate of pay in the former class falls within the new salary range, the rate of pay shall remain the same in the case of transfer. Rate of pay shall be increased in the case of promotion by an amount or percentage established by the city administrator. At the discretion of the department head, with the approval of the city administrator, rate of pay shall remain the same or shall be adjusted to a lower rate of pay in case of demotion. 
(4)  If a reclassification of a position results in a revised salary range, the employee serving in the position shall have the rate of pay increased if necessary, to the minimum for the class. 
(5)  If a reclassification of a position results in an employee's rate of pay exceeding the maximum rate of pay for the new position, the employee's rate of pay shall not be reduced. Raises for employees in this situation shall only be by incentive. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
E. - Rate of pay 
Rate of pay increases shall be made on the recommendation of the department head and are subject to approval by the city administrator, as indicated by performance evaluations. Reclassification of a position to a lower grade shall not automatically require a reduction in pay rate to anyone earning in excess of the new grade level, but it will preclude general increases. The city shall approve any annual salary adjustments in the budget process for that particular year; pay ranges shall be automatically increased by this adjustment, and shall require no further council action. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
F. - Incentive pay 
(1)  All employees at the top of their salary range shall be eligible for incentive pay. Incentive pay shall be based on the merit raise set by the city administrator and established in the approved budget. 
(2)  The results of the performance evaluation must be above the median category by employees at the top of their salary range before incentive pay can be earned. 
(3)  Incentive pay may be granted by department heads. Payment shall be made four (4) times per year in checks separate from employee's paychecks. The incentive pay shall not be added to the base salary of employees. Incentive pay must be earned in each year before it is paid out. Employees leaving city employment shall receive incentive pay accrued but not paid. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
G. - Overtime/compensatory work 
The city compensates for overtime in conformity with the expressed provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act, as amended. Generally, the city will compensate employees required to work in excess of forty (40) hours at the rate of one and one-half-hours (1½) for each hour of authorized overtime worked. Paid leave, holidays, personal days, and vacation are counted in determining work which is in excess of the regular work period. Overtime may only be worked upon approval of an employee's supervisor; employees will be disciplined for working overtime which their supervisor has not approved (unauthorized overtime). Employees are expected to work overtime hours if required by departmental needs. 
A regular work period is established for each position by department heads in accordance with payroll schedule. This work period may be changed by the department head depending on the department's needs. Overtime will not be paid for scheduled changes in the work period. Emergency situations are excluded from this prohibition. 
With the department head's approval, and at the employees' option, employees may take compensatory time off in lieu of pay to the rate one and one-half (1½) hours for each hour of authorized overtime. Employee requests for using compensatory time shall follow department procedures and shall not be unreasonably denied. 
Overtime shall be recorded and reported according to the following rules: 
(1)  Overtime shall be reported in units of one-quarter hour. 
(2)  An employee shall be given credit for one-quarter hour only if he has worked half of that period. 
(3)  The City reserves the right to assign overtime based on an employee's performance record as determined by their Department Head. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
H. - Pay review 
1.  Biannual reviews . All regular full-time and part-time employees are considered for merit pay raises based on performance evaluations conducted each April and each October based upon budgetary considerations, merit pay may be given at any point during the fiscal year, of which shall be at the discretion of the city administrator. 
2.  Probationary review 
(a)  Appointed employees. All appointed employees are subject to a probationary period established by these rules. All such employees, who satisfactorily complete their probationary period may be eligible for a pay increase. 
(b)  All classified employees . All classified employees are subject to a probationary period established by these rules. All such employees, who satisfactorily complete their probationary period and are granted civil service status to a regular full-time or part-time position with the city may be eligible for a pay increase. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
I. - Longevity pay 
Longevity pay shall be granted to regular full-time employees and shall be paid annually in addition to the employees' base salary according to the following schedule: 
Years of service as of May 1 of each year 	Annual Payment 
Zero through ten (10) years 	$  0.00 
Ten (10) years and one (1) day through fifteen (15) years 	$100.00 
Fifteen (15) years and one (1) day through twenty (20) years 	$200.00 
Twenty (20) years and one (1) day years 	$300.00 
 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
J. - Holiday pay 
Employees shall receive eight (8) hours' pay in addition to their regular pay for all such holidays worked. Employees working on a holiday shall also receive either (1) additional half-time pay for such hours worked; or (2) an equivalent number of compensatory hours off work at the employer's election and in accordance with this policy. Employees shall work all holidays when scheduled as part of the work schedule. To be eligible for holiday pay, an employee must work his regularly scheduled day before and after the holiday, in addition to the holiday, when scheduled as part of his normal departmental work schedule. If an employee is absent from work the day before or after a holiday, the employee will not receive holiday pay until proof of illness or excusable absence is established to the satisfaction of the department head. An employee not scheduled to work on a holiday who does work on the holiday shall receive holiday pay of one and one-half (1½) times the employee's regular straight time hourly rate of pay for the Actual hours worked on the holiday. This section only pertains to full-time employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
K. - Call-in or call-back pay 
Employees who are called to duty by their department head, supervisor or city administrator, shall receive a minimum of two (2) hours' pay at the overtime rate in accordance with the previously stated overtime policy. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
L. - Errors 
Adjustments to pay may be made to correct computational errors at any time. Employees will be notified of the error and the date of the correction as soon as possible. It is the employee's responsibility to inform the city if an error occurs in his pay. 
(Ord. No. 4212, § 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 04-O-0024, § 1, 4-5-2004)  
ARTICLE V. - LEAVE BENEFITS 
 
A. - Holidays 
(1)  Except as otherwise authorized, all full-time employees will receive the following days off with pay: 
New Year's Day 
Memorial Day 
Independence Day 
Labor Day 
Thanksgiving Day 
Day after Thanksgiving 
Christmas Day 
One-half (½) day on Christmas Eve* 
One-half (½) day on December 31* 
* City offices, except those providing essential services, shall close at 12:00 p.m. on these days whenever Christmas and New Year's Day fall on a Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday. When Christmas and New Year's Day fall on a Sunday, Monday or Saturday, employees will be permitted to take an additional floating holiday over the course of the fiscal year, in lieu of the one-half (½) day for Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve. [2] 
(2)  Holidays which occur on a Sunday are normally observed on the following Monday; those which occur on a Saturday are normally observed on the previous Friday. 
(3)  If an employee is absent from work the day before or after a holiday, the employee will not receive holiday pay until proof of illness or excusable absence is established to the satisfaction of the department head. 
(4)  New full-time employees become eligible to take scheduled holidays upon employment. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Public Works employees shall work the first four hours of their normally scheduled workday. 
 
B. - Floating holidays 
In consideration of other holidays not included in section A, employees shall receive three (3) floating holidays per fiscal year. 
(1)  Floating holidays do not accumulate from fiscal year to fiscal year; however, as noted below, employees hired in the last six (6) months of a fiscal year may carry over their floating holidays, but must use them within the first six (6) months of the next fiscal year. 
(2)  Newly-hired employees earn floating holidays based on the following: 
Month of Hire 	Number of Floating 
Holidays 	Carry-Over 
May-August 	3 	No 
September-December 	2 	Yes (if hired in Nov. or Dec.) 
January-April 	1 	Yes 
 
(3)  Floating holidays may not be used by full-time employees until the probationary period has been successfully completed. 
(4)  Floating holidays may be taken at any time or for any reason provided seventy-two (72) hours' notice is given to the immediate supervisor. A supervisor may refuse such leave because of departmental needs. A floating holiday may be used with less than seventy-two (72) hours' notice if approved by the department head. 
(5)  The use of floating holidays shall be limited to increments of either four (4) or eight (8) hours. 
(6)  Temporary, part-time and employees on leaves of absence or layoffs are not eligible for floating holidays. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
C. - Personal days—Sick leave reward 
Full-time employees shall be given eight (8) hours off with straight time pay each fiscal year. In addition, a full-time employee may earn an additional eight (8) hours of straight time pay for every fiscal quarter (i.e., May-July, August-October, November-January, and February-April) that such an employee does not use any sick time. Employees may accumulate up to forty (40) hours for personal days per fiscal year. The following provisions shall govern personal days: 
(1)  Employees on probation shall be eligible to earn personal days, but shall not be able to take them until after successful completion of the probationary period. If a probationary employee takes time off for any reason during his/her probationary period, this time will be counted against earning personal days. An employee who quits or is terminated before the end of the probationary period will not be paid for personal days. 
(2)  Non-probationary employees may carry over earned personal days to the next fiscal year. Forty (40) hours can be carried over to the next fiscal year, but must be used within the first six (6) months of that fiscal year. 
(3)  Personal days may be taken at any time or for any reason, provided at least seventy-two (72) hours' notice is given to the immediate supervisor, provided a supervisor may refuse such leave because of department needs. A personal day may be used with less than seventy-two (72) hours' notice, but only if approved by the department head. 
(4)  The employee shall not have to provide a reason for taking the personal day. 
(5)  The use of personal days shall be limited to increments of either four (4) or eight (8) hours. 
(6)  There shall be no payment in lieu of taking personal days. 
(7)  Personal days may be coupled with other types of paid leave if an employee so chooses, provided such other types of paid leave have been earned and have been scheduled in accordance with the provisions of this agreement. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 07-O-0032, § 1, 4-16-2007)  
D. - Vacation leave 
(1)  Classified employees are eligible for the following paid vacation benefits annually: 
Years of Service 	Days per Month 	Days Per Year 
0—6 years 	0.833 	10 
6 years and 
one day —12 years 	1.250 	15 
12 years and 
one day —18 years 	1.660 	20 
18 years and 
one day or more 	2.080 	25 
 
(2)  Employees beginning employment from the first through the fifteenth day of the month shall be granted 0.833 days for that month of service. Employees beginning the sixteenth day to the end of the month shall receive 0.416 days for that month's service. 
(3)  All appointed employees will follow the same paid vacation schedule as classified employees, with the addition of one (1) week for each earned vacation period. Notwithstanding the foregoing, appointed employees subject to the Fair Labor Standards Act shall not be eligible for the additional one (1) week for each earned vacation period. 
(4)  Vacation time may not be used during an employee's first six (6) months of employment with the city. For classified employees, this period coincides with the probationary period. 
(5)  Eligible employees shall earn vacation on a monthly basis. 
(6)  For the purposes of determining vacation eligibility, the employee's date of employment, and not the calendar year, is controlling. 
(7)  Employees may only carry over up to a maximum of their annual leave rate from one (1) fiscal year to the next. Employees may only carry over more than their annual leave allotment for scheduled medical reasons brought to the attention of and approved by the city prior to the end of the current fiscal year. If an employee has a scheduled medical issue within the first quarter of the upcoming fiscal year and believes that he will exhaust his sick leave bank and need additional time to attend to such, the employee may place a request to carry over vacation time, in writing, and submit it for approval to the employee's department head and the assistant city administrator. Such approval shall not be unreasonably denied, so long as this written request is accompanied by a note from the employee's personal physician indicating: that surgery or some other medical procedure has been scheduled during the first quarter of the upcoming fiscal year and the total amount of time the doctor believes the employee will be away from work to attend to such issue. All vacation leave carried over for this purpose shall be paid at the employee's rate of pay at the time the request was made. The city may request additional written updates from the employee's personal physician during the time of the employee's absence to ensure that the employee returns to work as soon as he is able. Failure to use all carried over leave for this purpose by the end of the first quarter of the fiscal year shall result in its forfeiture. 
(8)  Employees ordinarily earn vacation time before vacation days are used. However, with the prior approval of the department head and assistant city administrator, an employee may receive an advance of up to five (5) vacation days. If the employee uses this advance, and subsequently decides to leave the employ of the city prior to the beginning of the next fiscal year, the city shall deduct such time from the employee's final paycheck. 
(9)  As of March 30 of any fiscal year, employees who earn at least three (3) weeks of vacation leave per year may request pay in lieu of taking all or a portion of this time, the amount subject to the city administrator's approval and budget considerations. Said payment shall be provided in April of the applicable year. 
(10)  No vacation credits shall accrue in any month while an employee is on emergency leave, disability leave not work related, or when the employee is paid for less than half the number of working days in that month. Vacation, personal days, sick leave and disability leave under workers' compensation shall be counted toward time worked. 
(11)  Employees shall be paid for all earned vacation upon separation from employment with the city, regardless of the nature of the separation. 
(12)  Vacation periods shall be taken in minimum one-half (½) day increments at a time. All vacation periods shall be approved by an employee's department head or designee prior to the commencement of the vacation period. 
(13)  All employees classified and appointed with twenty (20) or more years of service with the city shall be entitled to an extra day (eight (8) hours) of vacation for each year of full-time employment, during the year before retirement, to be granted at a time or times approved by the department head, or in the case of department heads, as approved by the city administrator. 
Employees must provide their department head with at least one (1) year written notice of their retirement; with an exact date of retirement to be given no later than four (4) months prior to retirement. The primary purpose of this benefit is to allow the employee additional time to adjust and prepare for retirement. Therefore, employees can not take a cash payment in lieu of all or part of this special vacation allowance and the time off should be taken at different periods throughout the year. Any exceptions to this policy can only be made though the city administrator. If an employee for some reason does not retire by the designated date, the employee shall pay back the city the value of the extra awarded vacation. 
(14)  Each year, the department heads shall, in consultation with their employees, determine the departmental vacation schedule. Where conflicts in vacation selection occur, the employee with seniority shall be given first choice up to April 1. After April 1, vacations will be granted based on the priority of submission of vacation request. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4254, § 1, 12-20-99; Ord. No. 4334, § 1, 8-21-2000; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 06-O-0026, § 1, 3-20-2006; Ord. No. 07-O-0028, § 1, 3-19-2007)  
E. - Family and medical leave 
(1)  Employees who have been employed for at least one (1) year, and for at least twelve hundred fifty (1,250) hours during the preceding twelve-month period are eligible for family and medical leave. For employees not eligible for family and medical leave, the City of West Chicago will review and consider the individual circumstances. 
(2)  There are three (3) types of leave covered by this policy: 
(a)  Birth/adoption of daughter or son: Employees granted FMLA leave for the birth of a son or daughter, the care for the newborn daughter or son, or for placement of a daughter or son for adoption or foster care shall substitute in the following order accrued paid personal leave and all but one (1) week's worth of vacation leave for all of any unpaid FMLA leave. At the employee's discretion, he or she may use the remaining week of vacation leave. 
(b)  Serious health condition of a family member: Eligible employees on FMLA leave shall be required to substitute in the following order paid sick leave (to the extent they are otherwise eligible under section G herein), personal leave and all but one (1) week's worth of vacation leave for all of any unpaid FMLA leave relating to care for a family member with a serious health condition. At the employee's discretion, he or she may use the remaining week of vacation leave. 
(c)  Serious health condition of employee: Eligible employees on FMLA leave shall be required to substitute in the following order paid sick leave, personal leave and all but one (1) week's worth of vacation leave for all of any unpaid FMLA leave relating to employee's own serious health condition. At the employee's discretion, he or she may use the remaining week of vacation leave. 
(3)  An employee may take leave intermittently or arrange a reduced work schedule depending on the circumstances. If the leave is for the birth or placement of a daughter or son for adoption or foster care, the employee may take intermittent leave or have a reduced work schedule only if the city agrees, except that the city's agreement is not necessary if the mother has a serious health condition in connection with the birth or her child or the newborn child has a serious health condition. Leave may also be taken intermittently or on a reduced work schedule when medically necessary for planned and/or unanticipated medical treatment of a related serious health condition by or under the supervision of a health care provider or for recovery from treatment or recovery from a serious health condition. It may also be taken to provide care or psychological comfort to an immediate family member with a serious health condition. 
(4)  All such paid leave that qualifies for FMLA leave shall be counted toward the maximum twelve (12) week FMLA leave. Employees will be notified when such paid leave has been credited as FMLA leave. 
(5)  The City of West Chicago will post the rights of employees under the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 in all municipal facilities. 
(6)  Reason for leave: All employees who meet the applicable time-of-service requirements may be granted a total of twelve (12) work weeks of unpaid family and/or medical leave during a twelve-month period for the following reasons: 
(a)  The birth of an employee's daughter or son and in order to care for the daughter or son; 
(b)  The placement of a daughter or son with an employee for adoption or foster care; 
(c)  To care for a spouse, daughter or son, parent or parent in-law who has a serious health condition; or 
(d)  A serious health condition that renders the employee unable to perform the functions of his or her job. 
(7)  Definitions 
EMPLOYMENT BENEFITS: The term "employment benefits: shall include all benefits provided or made available to employees by an employer, including group life insurance, health insurance, disability insurance, sick leave, annual leave, educational benefits and pensions, regardless of whether such benefits are provided by a practice or written policy of employer. 
HEALTH CARE PROVIDER: The term "health care provider" means (A) a doctor of medicine or osteopathy who is authorized to practice medicine or surgery (as appropriate) by the state in which the doctor practices; or (B) any other person determined by the Secretary of Labor to be capable of providing health care services. 
PARENT: The term "parent" means the biological parent of an employee or an individual who stood in loco parentis to an employee when the employee was a son or daughter. 
REDUCED LEAVE SCHEDULE: The term "reduced leave schedule" means a leave schedule that reduces the usual number of hours per workweek, or hours per workday, of an employee. 
SERIOUS HEALTH CONDITION: The term "serious health condition" means an illness, injury, impairment or physical or mental condition that involves (A) inpatient care in a hospital, hospice or residential medical care facility including any period of incapacity or any subsequent treatment in connection with such inpatient care; or (B) continuing treatment by a health care provider. 
SON OR DAUGHTER: The term "son or daughter" means a biological, adopted or foster child, a stepdaughter or son, a legal ward or a daughter or son of a person standing in loco parentis, who is (A) under eighteen (18) years of age; or (B) eighteen (18) years of age or older and incapable of self care because of a mental or physical disability. 
SPOUSE: The term "spouse" means a husband or wife, as the case may be. 
(8)  Application for leave: In all cases, an employee requesting leave must complete a form provided by the city and return it to the administration department. The completed application must state the reason for the leave, the duration of the leave, and the starting and ending dates of the leave. 
(9)  Notice of leave: An employee intending to take family or medical leave, if the leave is foreseeable based on an expected birth or placement, or because of a planned medical treatment for a serious health condition of the employee or a family member, must submit an application for leave at least thirty (30) days before the leave is to begin. If such is not practicable, notice must be given as soon as practicable. 
(10)  Medical certification of leave: Within fifteen (15) days of filing an application for leave based on the serious health condition of the employee or the employee's spouse, daughter or son, or parent, the employee must also file a medical certification on a form provided by the city and completed by the health care provider of the employee or an ill family member. Such certificate shall contain such information as is permitted by the FMLA. 
The city can pay for a second opinion if it doubts the validity of the original certification. If the second opinion conflicts with the original, the employer may pay for a third opinion. The provider of the third opinion must be jointly designated or approved by the city and the employee. The third opinion will be final. Copies of the second and third opinions shall be provided to the employee upon request. The city may also require periodic recertification of certain medical conditions or updates as to the status and intention of the employee's return to work. 
Failure to satisfy the certification requirements may result in delaying or revocation of the taking of leave until such documentation is provided. 
(11)  Benefits' coverage during leave: During a period of family or medical leave, an employee will be retained on the city health plan under the same conditions that applied before leave commenced. To continue health coverage, the employee must continue to make any contributions that he or she made to the plan before taking leave. Failure of the employee to pay his or her share of the health insurance premium may result in loss of coverage. 
If the employee fails to return to work after the expiration of the leave, the employee will be required to reimburse the city for payment of the employee's portion of the health insurance premiums during the family leave, unless the reason the employee fails to return is the presence of a serious health condition which prevents the employee from performing his or her job or to circumstances beyond the employee's control. 
An employee who takes family or medical leave will not lose any seniority or employment benefits that accrued before the date leave began. 
(12)  Restoration to employment: An employee eligible for family and medical leave will be restored to his or her old position or to a position with equivalent pay, benefits, and other terms and conditions of employment. The city cannot guarantee that an employee will be returned to his or her original job. 
(13)  Return from leave: An employee must complete a "Notice of Intention to Return From Family or Medical Leave" before he or she can return to active status. If an employee wishes to return to work prior to the expiration of a family or medical leave of absence, notification must be given to the administration department at least two (2) working days prior to the employee's planned return. After submitting such notice, an employee will await confirmation from the administration department stating that he or she may return to work. 
(14)  Failure to return from leave: The failure of an employee to return to work upon the expiration of a family or medical leave of absence may subject the employee to immediate termination unless an extension is granted in writing. An employee who requests an extension of family leave or medical leave due to the continuation, recurrence or onset of his own serious health condition, or of the serious health condition of the employee's spouse, daughter or son or parent, must submit a request for an extension, in writing, to the employee's immediate supervisor. This written request should be made as soon as the employee realizes that he will not be able to return at the expiration of the leave period. The city will notify the employee failing to return from leave about COBRA and her or his obligations under the program. 
If a leave extension is granted, the city will make its best effort to keep an employee's job open until her or his return. However, if the city feels that it is necessary to fill the position to successfully perform its operations, it will submit a letter to said employee informing her or him of the decision. The employee will then have seven (7) calendar days to inform the city of his desire to return to work. If the employee does not feel that he is capable of returning to work, the city will take the steps necessary to fill that position and subsequently place the employee's name on a rehire list which will make her or him eligible to fill a similar position in the city. 
(15)  Concurrent running of other leave: The leave provisions provided for in other sections of the City Code shall run concurrently with the leave provisions provided for under this section. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
F. - Funeral leave 
In the event of a death in the immediate family, the employee will be granted up to three (3) days of paid funeral leave with pay to attend the funeral; the department head or designee may approve an employee's request for up to two (2) additional days and if granted, such additional day(s) shall be deducted from the employee's accumulated sick leave or other accrued benefit leave time. For this purpose, "immediate family" shall be defined as the employee's spouse, parent, sibling, child, grandparent, grandchild, or the parent, sibling or child of the employee's spouse. Stepparent, child and sibling shall be included in the definition of "immediate family." In the event of a death of an employee's son-in-law, daughter-in-law, aunt, uncle, niece or nephew, the employee will be granted one (1) day of paid funeral leave with pay to attend the funeral; the department head or designee may approve an employee's request for up to two (2) additional days and, if granted, such additional day(s) shall be deducted from the employee's accumulated sick leave or other accrued benefit leave time. An employee shall provide satisfactory evidence of the death of the affected family member and the employee's attendance at the funeral if so requested by the city. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4334, §§ 2, 3, 8-21-2000; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 07-O-0032, § 2, 4-16-2007)  
G. - Sick leave 
(1)  Full-time employees will have sick leave pay accrued at the rate of one (1) day of sick pay for each full month of employment for a total of twelve (12) days per year. To be eligible for sick leave, a new employee must have completed his six (6) month probationary period. 
(2)  Sick leave shall not be considered a right which may be used at the employee's discretion, but shall be allowed only in the following situations: 
(a)  Actual sickness, injury, hospitalization or disability of the employee. 
(b)  Medical or dental appointments which cannot be scheduled outside of working hours, with the approval of the department head. 
(c)  Up to two (2) days of sick leave per incident may be used to care for an illness or disability of the employee's immediate family, as defined as the employee's parents, spouse, children, step-parent and step-child. If needed and requested documentation is provided, the department head, after consulting the city administrator or designee, may allow additional sick leave to be used for this purpose. 
(3)  The supervisor or department head may require an employee who is on sick leave to submit a doctor's note which indicates the specific nature of the illness or injury, and require the employee to provide a prognosis from the physician as to the earliest date when the employee will be able to return to work and perform the essential job functions of the position or any restricted duty assignment. 
The supervisor or department head may require an employee to have the doctor's note updated should the employee not return to work within the time frame originally established by the physician. Any cost associated with providing a physician's statement is the responsibility of the employee. 
(4)  Sick leave shall not be authorized for illness, injury or disability incurred in employment other than with the City of West Chicago. 
(5)  The department head, with the approval of the city administrator or his designee, may require an employee to submit to a physical or psychological examination, at city expense, to determine whether the employee is still able to perform the essential functions of his job. 
(6)  There is no limit on the number of sick days an employee can earn. An absence attributable to a work-related injury shall not be credited against an employee's earned sick leave, except as provided in section K of this article. 
(7)  According to department rules, the employee shall personally notify the supervisor or department head of a sick leave absence on the day of the absence and, upon return to work, report and explain the absence to the supervisor or department head. 
In the event of elective surgery which may result in the employee being away from work for a period of one (1) week or more, the employee is required to give at least two (2) week's notification to the supervisor or department head. 
In the event the employee is unable to personally notify the supervisor or department head on the day of the absence, it is the responsibility of the employee to cause notification to be made to the supervisor or department head. 
(8)  The supervisor or department head may send an employee home on sick leave if the employee appears ill and threatens the health of other employees. 
(9)  Any abuse of sick leave policy may result in non-payment of sick leave benefits and shall be grounds for disciplinary action. Abuse of sick leave shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
a.  Failure to notify the department head or supervisor of an absence and the condition causing the absence; 
b.  Failure to provide medical documentation required by this policy to the department head or supervisor; 
c.  A continual pattern of absences; 
d.  A high incidence of absences, the number of which, are detrimental to the efficient operation of the employee's department; 
e.  Failure of an employee to abide by an approved reduction in leave absence plan as referenced in subsection (10)d. below. 
(10)  If the sick leave absence continues beyond the number of sick leave days the employee has earned, consideration will be given to the following: 
a.  Placement on an unpaid leave of absence; 
b.  Transfer to disability benefits under the appropriate retirement fund; 
c.  Termination of employment if not eligible for disability compensation under the appropriate retirement fund; 
d.  Employee's preparation and submission of a written proposal within five (5) days of his department head or supervisor's request, proposing a plan for avoiding a high incidence of sick leave absences, which may be approved or modified by the department head, and which after the department head's approval, shall become the employee's obligation to implement. Failure of an employee to submit a proposal within the five (5) days may result in the employee's department head or supervisor formulating a reduction of sick leave absences plan which shall become the employee's obligation to implement. 
(11)  Time taken as sick leave as well as absences beyond an employee's accumulated sick leave, may qualify for treatment under the Family and Medical Leave Act. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4334, §§ 4, 5, 8-21-2000; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
H. - Military leave
