(1)  Full-time service: Any full-time employee who is ordered to active duty with a component of the U.S. Armed Forces during military conflict, civil disorder or natural disaster shall be granted a military leave of absence. 
(a)  Employees shall sign their military checks over to the city upon receipt of payment, or keep this payment and forfeit their city pay. 
(b)  Health insurance for the employee and dependents will remain in effect for the same period. 
(c)  Upon release from the military, the employee shall notify the department head as soon as is reasonably possible. 
(d)  For ninety (90) days upon release from the military, the employee may be reinstated with the city without loss of seniority and will have accrued other benefits as though city service was uninterrupted. The employee's return to work will be governed by the provisions of federal law. 
(2)  Reserve service: When necessary, an employee will be granted up to two (2) weeks' military leave to serve on annual active duty for training with a reserve component of the U.S. Armed Forces, including the National Guard and Coast Guard, upon presentation of a copy of orders indicating the compensation received during a training period. 
(a)  Employees shall sign their military checks over to the city upon receipt of payment, or keep this payment and forfeit their city pay. 
(b)  Monthly reserve training component meetings shall be the responsibility and obligation of the employee. Department heads may accommodate employees by permitting requests for vacation or requests for accrued time off. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
I. - Jury duty leave 
Employees will be eligible for jury duty leave, with full straight-time pay, upon receipt of a notice to appear in court for such purpose. Employees are not eligible for travel expenses under the city policy, however, any monies received from the court may be retained to cover these expenses. Upon returning from jury leave, employees must present documentation (e.g. pay stub or identification badge) showing how long they were retained for jury service. This section does not apply to court duty where an employee is testifying either for the city or some other party, which would be in accordance with their job duties. This section also applies to part-time employees, assuming that jury duty falls on a regularly scheduled day of work. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
J. - Unpaid leave of absence 
(1)  An employee who has exhausted all earned vacation leave, sick leave (if applicable), floating holidays, personal days and compensatory time may request, in writing, an unpaid leave of absence. A request for an unpaid leave of absence requires the approval of the department head and the city administrator. 
(2)  An unpaid leave of absence totaling less than thirty (30) calendar days will have no effect on longevity, sick or vacation leave accrual. An employee may continue in the health and life insurance programs provided arrangements are made by the employee to pay the full premium cost for the period the employee is absent from work. 
(3)  An unpaid leave of absence longer than thirty (30) calendar days may result in the termination of all benefits. If an employee does not return from an unpaid leave of absence as scheduled, the employee may be deemed to have resigned. 
(4)  In addition to the foregoing, unpaid leaves of absence shall also be granted to employees who have been injured either on the job or off the job and who are unable to return to work. Said leave shall be granted for a period of one (1) year from and after the date of the injury, except as otherwise required by law or contract; provided, however, that said leave shall terminate sooner upon the occurrence of any of the following: (a) the employee resigns; (2) the employee takes employment elsewhere; or (c) the employee applies for and receives either a retirement or disability pension. The one year period shall be tolled if the employee temporarily returns to work. 
(5)  An unpaid leave of absence will also be granted under the terms and conditions of the Family and Medical Leave Act (see section E). 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
K. - Disability leave—On duty injury/illness 
If an employee is injured on the job, no matter how slightly, he must promptly report the injury to his immediate supervisor and file a written accident report possibly entitling him to workers' compensation benefits. 
(1)  The workers' compensation benefit will pay for all related and reasonable medical and hospital expenses incurred due to injuries received. 
(2)  In the event an employee is off work in order to recover from an injury caused by the employee's work, the city's workers' compensation program provides payment of sixty-six and two-third (66 2/3 ) percent of gross wages subject to certain conditions. 
(3)  Temporary total disability (TTD) benefits are not paid for the first three (3) work days following the accident unless the disability continues for fourteen (14) calendar days. In cases where the disability does not continue for fourteen (14) calendar days, the employee, if eligible, could use sick, vacation and personal days to cover time off from work. 
(4)  Employees participating in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund (IMRF) and on a job related disability leave are encouraged to apply to IMRF in order to continue to receive service credits while on the disability. 
(5)  The city will continue to pay the city portion of the disabled employee's employee and family health, dental and life insurance programs for a period of one (1) year from and after the date of injury, except as otherwise required by law or contract, and except to the extent the employee otherwise has accrued but unused vacation, sick leave and personal days (including holidays) in excess of one year. Said payments shall terminate sooner upon the occurrence of any of the following: (a) the employee resigns; (b) the employee takes employment elsewhere; or (c) the employee applies for and receives either a retirement or disability pension. The leave provisions provided for in other sections of the City Code shall run concurrently with the leave provisions provided for under this section. Upon expiration of this period, the employee may continue under the city plans for health, dental and life insurance programs, but must pay both the employee and city portions. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
L. - Disability leave—Off duty injury/illness 
Benefits for non-occupational injury or disability that exceed the benefits periods provided under sick leave may be available through the applicable pension fund. Employees should make application directly to these funds for consideration. 
The city will, subject to the limitations noted below, continue to pay the city portion of the disabled employee's and family's health, dental and life insurance programs during the period of disability for a period of time equal to all accrued but unused vacation, sick leave and personal days (including holidays), up to a maximum of one (1) year, except as otherwise required by law or contract. Said payments shall terminate sooner upon the occurrence of any of the following: (a) the employee resigns; (b) the employee takes employment elsewhere; or (c) the employee applies for and receives either a retirement or disability pension. The leave provisions provided for in other sections of the City Code shall run concurrently with the leave provisions provided for under this section. Upon expiration of this period, the employee may continue under the city plans for health, dental and life insurance programs, but must pay both the employee and city portions. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
M. - Compensatory leave 
Immediate supervisors may grant department heads and other appointed employees who are exempt from the provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act compensatory time off in consideration of extra time worked. 
(Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
ARTICLE VI. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS 
In addition to leave benefits outlined in Article V, there are many other fringe benefits available to employees that are described below. Unless otherwise noted, the benefits noted in this manual apply only to full-time employees. For detailed information about any of these benefits, the employee may contact the department head or the administration department. 
 
A. - Health and dental insurance 
Employees and dependents may be eligible for health and dental insurance coverage under a plan (or plans) then in effect. 
(1)  If more than one (1) health plan is in effect and the employee desires to switch plans, this is possible only during the annual open enrollment period. 
(2)  Employees are required to contribute to the cost of the health insurance premium in an amount required by the city. 
(3)  Employees will be covered on the first day of the first month following thirty (30) days of employment. 
(4)  Full-time employees who elect to waive health coverage under any of the city's group health plans are eligible to receive a one-time lump sum payment each plan year they elect to waive health coverage, providing the incentive program is in effect and that they can provide proof of coverage through a spouse or other family member. This incentive program and related payment amounts are subject to change or elimination as deemed appropriate by the city administrator. 
(a)  Eligibility: Full-time employees become eligible to participate in the incentive program on their first day of hire. 
(b)  New employees: New employees who elect to participate in the incentive program receive a prorated a amount of the one-time lump sum payment according to their date of hire, payable only after the completion of their probationary period. 
(c)  Current employees: Program participants receive payment of the one-time lump sum amount during the month of May in the year for which insurance coverage is waived. 
(d)  Re-enrollment: If an employee who has waived the city's group insurance requests re-enrollment prior to the open-enrollment period, the following conditions must be met: 
A written request for re-enrollment must be sent to the finance department and explain the reason for the request; 
The city's insurance providers may require that evidence of insurability be satisfied at the employee's expense; 
The employee will be responsible for reimbursing the city a portion of the incentive payment, prorated according to the length of time the employee was reinsured under the city's insurance plan. 
(5)  Part-time employees may choose to be insured and to insure their dependents for group health and dental insurance at their own cost. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
B. - Life insurance 
(1)  The city provides life insurance to all full-time employees, at no cost to the employee. The amount of insurance is equivalent to the employee's yearly salary rounded up to the nearest one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), and is adjusted as the employee's yearly salary increases up to the maximum amount provided in the policy. It is the employee's obligation to keep the city informed with respect to beneficiary information. 
(2)  The city is a member of the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund Volunteer Life Insurance Program. Participation is optional and open to full-time employees. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
C. - Health insurance for retirees 
The city makes available health insurance for retired city employees under the State of Illinois Municipal Insurance Continuation Act (215 ILCS 5/3/367j). Employees who leave employment due to a disability or retirement as defined by the Illinois Pension Code will be eligible to participate in the city's heath insurance at their own cost, so long as the current group insurance carrier(s) for the city allows this participation and that the employee is a current participant in the insurance program at the time of disability or retirement. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 07-O-0032, § 3, 4-16-2007; Ord. No. 11-O-0067, § 5, 12-19-2011)  
D. - Workers' compensation insurance 
(1)  If an employee is injured in the course of work, he is eligible for benefits under the Workers' Compensation Act. 
(2)  In the event an employee dies as a result of an accident sustained during the course of employment, the employee's survivors must claim with the Illinois Industrial Commission. Any amount of recovery will vary as dictated by law. 
(3)  When an employee has sustained a work-related injury/illness, workers' compensation will pay for all costs associated with such injury/illness as required by law. 
(4)  In the event an employee suffers permanent disability from a work-related injury, the employee must file a claim with the Illinois Industrial Commission. This claim will be reviewed by the commission in an effort to determine its validity and the city's responsibility for such claim. 
(5)  If the employee is injured during the course of employment by a third party, a claim may be filed with the Illinois Industrial Commission and the employee may sue the [responsible] party. Although the commission will decide the matter without reference to the third party, the employee must, if successful in the suit against the third party, indemnify the city for all expenses and claims it paid up to the extent of its loss or to the employee's recovery, whichever amount is smaller. In the event the city recovers under such circumstances, the city must give the employee all monies in excess of the Actual loss it sustained in expenses, claims and court costs. 
(6)  It is to be especially noted that neither the employee nor his survivors have any further recourse against the city beyond the provisions of the Illinois Workers' Compensation Act. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
E. - Retirement programs 
(1)  Depending on the employee's affiliation with a particular department and job responsibility, the city participates in and pays a varying share towards the employee's retirement and disability program. 
(a)  Sworn police officers participate in and the city contributes a share to the West Chicago Police Pension Fund. The city also contributes a share to social security. 
(b)  All other full-time employees participate in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund and Social Security. 
(c)  All other city employees participate in social security. The city contributes a share to social security for these employees. 
(2)  All employees are eligible to participate in the deferred compensation plan, as offered by the international city/county management association's retirement corporation or other plan approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
F. - Disability programs 
For nonwork related injuries and illnesses, the employees should refer to the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund (IMRF) and West Chicago Police Pension Fund respectively and contact those funds' representatives for further information. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
G. - Death benefits 
Upon the death of a regular full-time employee, the city shall give one (1) month's pay in addition to vacation pay. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
H. - Tuition reimbursement program 
The city recognizes the mutual benefit in the employee pursuing continued education. Therefore, the city has established a tuition reimbursement policy to encourage continued education. This policy is contingent upon funds being included in the budget. 
(1)  Eligibility 
(a)  Employees must have completed their probationary period. 
(b)  Employees should seek to exhaust all other sources of assistance (veteran's benefits, scholarships and grants), with the exception of student loans. The city's share shall not exceed the difference between a tuition bill and the amount of coverage from all other sources. 
(2)  Employees may be required to furnish information about the accreditation of the particular educational institution. 
(3)  Eligible courses 
(a)  The program is available for high school, college, vocational or degree programs that are job-related (either current or a foreseeable future position within the organization). 
(b)  Courses are to be taken on the employee's own time, unless otherwise approved by the department head and the city administrator or his designee. 
(c)  The number of courses in which an employee can enroll in a given semester or quarter shall be reviewed during the approval process and shall in no way interfere with the employee's job duties and responsibilities. 
(4)  Reimbursement 
(a)  The city will reimburse the employee for the appropriate tuition cost upon submission of an approved reimbursement request with proof of payment and satisfactory completion of each course. 
(b)  The city will reimburse on a sliding scale of one hundred (100) percent for an "A" or "B" and seventy-five (75) percent for a "C". Employees who receive a grade lower than a "C" shall not be reimbursed any amount. 
(c)  Reimbursement for tuition to attend a private school will be limited to the tuition cost at a comparable state school. 
(5)  At the time a request for reimbursement is made, the employee must sign an agreement for repayment of all reimbursed tuition to the city if, for any reason, their employment with the city is terminated within one (1) year after the completion of their course of study. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
I. - Uniform 
If a uniform is required of an employee as a condition of employment, it shall be provided at the city's expense. Issuance, use and maintenance of the uniform shall be subject to department rules. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
J. - Vehicle use 
(1)  Vehicles may be assigned as approved by the city administrator to individual employees or departments. 
(2)  Employees who wish to use their city vehicle for personal reasons while commuting to and from work, must sign a waiver indemnifying the city. 
(3)  Employees driving city vehicles are responsible for any fines resulting from parking or driving violations. 
(4)  No employee shall operate a vehicle while physically or mentally impaired. 
(5)  City vehicles are to be used for city purposes only, except as specifically approved by the city administrator. 
(6)  Employees using their own vehicle on city business will be reimbursed at the current Internal Revenue Service rate. 
(7)  Employees using their own vehicle for city business are covered only for amount above one's personal individual primary coverage auto liability policy which meets the minimum limits set the city's self insurance pool. 
(8)  Employees using city vehicles are responsible for reporting any malfunction or maintenance requirement as soon as such condition is known. 
(9)  Employees must report any accident, regardless of how small, as soon as possible. Employees involved in accidents must cooperate fully with all lawful authorities and anyone investigating the matter on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
K. - DuPage Credit Union 
All city employees are eligible to use the DuPage Credit Union. Information on the credit union is available from the administration department. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4334, § 7, 8-21-2000; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
L. - Direct deposit of pay checks 
All employees may elect to participate in the payroll direct deposit program. To do so, the employee designates their full net bi-weekly paycheck for direct deposit. The direct deposit may be made into any savings or checking account at financial institutions that are members of the ACH system. The city has no liability in this transaction other than the transmittal of the net amount of the paycheck to the designated financial institution. The employee should consult their financial institution regarding participating in the ACH system and their rules for direct deposit. Forms for participation in the city's payroll direct deposit program are available from the finance department. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
M. - Employee assistance program (EAP) 
The city offers an assistance program for all employees. The program offers a confidential means for seeking help for personal problems (e.g. family, financial, or substance abuse). This program is a free voluntary way for employees to get confidential professional help for personal problems. Assistance may be requested by either contacting the administration department or by directly calling an EAP counselor. This program is available twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
N. - COBRA extended insurance coverage 
The Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA) provides that participation in group medical or dental plans may continue beyond a plan's eligibility limits as follows: 
(1)  If an employee dies, becomes eligible for medicare or becomes legally separated or divorced, the employee's spouse and dependent children, if they are then also receiving coverage under the plan, can elect to purchase continued health coverage under the plan for up to thirty-six (36) months. 
(2)  If an employee's employment is terminated (for any reason other than gross misconduct) or is reduced to part-time status, the employee or the employee's spouse and dependent children, if they are then covered under the plan, can elect to purchase continued health coverage under the plan for up to eighteen (18) months. 
(3)  If the employee has a covered dependent child who ceases to be eligible for dependent coverage under the plan, the employee's child can elect to purchase continued health coverage for up to thirty-six (36) months. 
(4)  Continued coverage may cease prior to the times set forth above under certain circumstances as permitted under COBRA. 
(5)  The eligible individual electing continued participation in a group medical plan is responsible for the prepayment of one hundred two (102) percent of the applicable monthly insurance premium. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
ARTICLE VII. - EMPLOYEE CONDUCT AND DISCIPLINARY PROCEDURE 
 
A. - Disciplinary action 
The steps listed below will serve to guide disciplinary actions. The steps are progressive in nature, increasing the penalty each time an employee is disciplined. The steps emphasize continual interaction between the employee and the supervisor and/or department head and should provide sufficient opportunity for correction of the inappropriate conduct while making the employee aware of the consequences of the violations. 
In general, any action or attitude which adversely affects job performance or the reputation of the city may result in disciplinary action. This procedure neither precludes a department head from by-passing a step when disciplining an employee nor does it prohibit a department head from dismissing an employee after consultation with the city administrator. The nature, extent and seriousness of the offense will determine the appropriate disciplinary action, in addition to the general work record and disciplinary record of the employee. 
(1)  Employee counseling: When a less formal means of handling a disciplinary incident is warranted, the supervisor may consider an employee counseling session. This session will take the form of a meeting between the supervisor and employee, and is intended to make the employee aware of a situation or trend in performance or conduct which is unacceptable and which could result in further disciplinary action if continued or repeated. The supervisor shall make a record of the counseling session. 
(2)  Counseling and written reprimand: When an increasing level of discipline is warranted, a written reprimand shall be issued. The reprimand should specifically state the nature of the problem and what it takes to correct it, with a comment stating that failure to correct the situation will result in more severe discipline. Copies of the written reprimand (which should have a date for review) and supervisor's note from step one should go the department head and the city administrator or his designee. Both copies shall be placed in the employee's personnel file. 
(3)  Suspension: Violations which are serious in nature, but not serious enough to warrant dismissal, will be disciplined by suspension. An employee's refusal to adequately correct previously disciplined action may also result in suspension. Civil service employees are subject to the provisions listed in Appendix D of the City Code. 
(a)  The department head has the authority to suspend an employee upon consultation with the city administrator or his designee. If a situation arises that, in the opinion of the supervisor, necessitates immediate disciplinary action and the department head is not available, the supervisor should notify the city administrator or his designee. 
(b)  The department head will present a memorandum to the employee documenting the rationale for the suspension and its duration. A copy of the letter will be placed in the employee's personnel file. 
(4)  Dismissal: The department head, after consultation with the city administrator or his designee, may dismiss any employee with or without notice. The department head shall prepare a written dismissal notice enumerating the reasons for the dismissal action. The notice will be discussed with the employee during a dismissal conference with the department head. In the event dismissal is for continued unsatisfactory performance, a written report stating the details of the unsatisfactory performance must be filed by the department head with the city administrator or his designee prior to the issuance of a dismissal notice. Evidence of the following, though not all inclusive, may be cause for dismissal: 
(a)  Unsatisfactory work performance as determined by the employee's supervisor through formal and informal evaluations. 
(b)  Incompetence, negligence or inefficiency in the performance of assigned duties. 
(c)  Abusive attitude and language to another employee or the public, or abusive conduct resulting in harm or injury to another employee or the public, including, but not limited to, sexual harassment. 
(d)  Violation of any lawful or official regulation, order or rule, or failure to obey any lawful and reasonable direction given by an employee's superior, provided that such violation or failure to obey amounts to insubordination or a serious breach of discipline which may reasonably be expected to result in lower morale in the organization or to result in loss, inconvenience or injury to the city or public. 
(e)  Taking for personal use a fee, gift or other valuable item during the course of the employee's work or in connection with it, without reporting its receipt to the supervisor or department head and complying with Article XIII, section B. 
(f)  Illegal, immoral or indecent conduct. 
(g)  Gross negligence or willful or wanton misconduct causing damage to public or private property or waste of public supplies. 
(h)  Absence without an authorized leave or failure to report after an authorized leave of absence has expired or has been disapproved, revoked or canceled by the employee's superior. 
(i)  Feigning illness or injury. 
(j)  Direct or indirect solicitation and/or receipt during working hours of any assessment, subscription or contribution for the purpose of electing any candidate to any public office. 
(k)  Engaging in any act which endangered the safety, health or well being of another person, or which is of sufficient magnitude that the consequences cause or act to cause disruption of work or gross discredit to the city. 
(l)  Violation of any rule, procedure or regulation pertaining to conduct of a city employee. 
(m)  Theft or unauthorized possession of City of West Chicago property, or property of a city employee or resident. 
(n)  Falsification of personnel records. 
(o)  Possession (unless possession is otherwise authorized by virtue of the responsibilities of the employee's position), use or being under the influence of alcohol, controlled substance or narcotics of any kind while performing duties for the City of West Chicago. 
(p)  Possession (unless possession is otherwise authorized by virtue of the responsibilities of the employee's position), use or being under the influence of alcohol, controlled substance or narcotics of any kind while driving a city vehicle or operating city equipment. 
(q)  Disclosure of a positive result from any required drug or alcohol test. 
(r)  Excessive absenteeism or tardiness. 
(s)  Display of other misconduct comparable in seriousness to the offenses enumerated above. 
(t)  False statements, either verbal or written; false statements in an employment application will result in immediate discharge. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
B. - Appeal of disciplinary action 
Any nonprobationary employee may appeal a disciplinary action taken by a supervisor or department head. The review of an appeal resulting from disciplinary action shall be limited to the facts used in determining whether an incident occurred requiring disciplinary action; and the process used in disciplining the employee once the Act occurred. 
(1)  The employee, within five (5) business days after being notified of the disciplinary action, shall request a meeting with the department head or designee and shall submit at such meeting a written statement of appeal outlining the reasons for appealing the Action. The department head or designee shall then discuss the statement of appeal with the employee. 
(2)  The department head or designee, within five (5) business days of receipt of the appeal, shall meet with the employee and supervisor (if applicable) and resolve the issue, if possible. If no resolution can be reached, the department head shall forward all related documentation together with a written recommendation to the city administrator or his designee during the next working day following the meeting. 
(3)  The city administrator or his designee shall review all related documents and make a decision within ten (10) business days of receipt of the appeal. Written notice of the final decision shall be given to the employee and the city administrator's or his designee's decision shall be final. 
(4)  The above disciplinary policy is illustrative of guidelines to encourage proper employee behavior and job performance. It is neither all inclusive nor is it meant as an absolute procedure, and it does not grant any absolute contractual or procedural rights to an employee. 
(5)  Civil service employees are subject to the provisions detailed in Appendix D of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
C. - Grievance procedure 
A grievance is defined as a complaint arising out of an alleged violation or misinterpretation of the provisions contained in this personnel manual, except that any action relating to discipline shall be covered under section (B) of this article. 
(1)  Any nonprobationary employees wishing to file a grievance must adhere to the following procedures, using the grievance form, provided by the city, which must accompany each step: 
Step one: Within five (5) business days from the date the employee has knowledge of the condition that gives rise to the grievance, he must ask, in writing, for a meeting with his immediate supervisor. The purpose of the meeting is to attempt to resolve the problem without further review. The supervisor will arrange a grievance meeting as soon as possible after receiving notice of the employee's concern. The supervisor shall respond, in writing, within five (5) business days of the meeting. 
Step two: If the employee is dissatisfied with the results of the meeting with his immediate supervisor, he must submit the grievance in writing to the department head within five (5) business days from the decision of the immediate supervisor. The department head will schedule a meeting with the employee within a reasonable time period, and review the initial written appeal and the step one response. The department head shall respond, in writing, within five (5) business days of the meeting. 
Step three: The employee may, within ten (10) working days of receipt of the written response from the department head, appeal the decision of the department head, in writing, to the city administrator or his designee. The city administrator or his designee will schedule a meeting with the employee within a reasonable time period, and review the initial written appeal and the step one and step two responses. The city administrator or his designee shall respond, in writing, within ten (10) business days of the meeting. 
(2)  The decision of the city administrator or his designee is final. 
(3)  An employee should be aware that circumstances which give rise to a grievance shall not exempt the employee from the responsibility of completing the assigned order, task or project, or other assigned work. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
ARTICLE VIII. - ADMINISTRATIVE POLICIES 
 
A. - Absence from work 
(1)  Absence of an employee from duty, including the absence for a day or portion thereof that is not authorized or approved shall be deemed to be absence without leave. 
(2)  Any absence without leave shall be without pay and may be subject to disciplinary action. 
(3)  Any employee who absents herself/himself for three (3) consecutive days without leave shall automatically be considered to have resigned. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
B. - Acceptance of gifts 
(1)  City employees are prohibited from accepting any gratuities, gifts or other remuneration of more than a nominal amount (established at twenty-five dollars ($25.00)) due to their position with the city from: 
(a)  Persons or firms which transact, or may transact, business with the city or; 
(b)  Persons or organizations that the city is associated with in any professional or service manner. 
(2)  The offering of any gratuity, gift or other remuneration of more than a nominal amount (including any gift of liquor) must be returned to the sender with a courteous note expressing appreciation for the gesture. 
(3)  Perishable gifts, such as food, fruit, etc. may be set out for general consumption by department employees or donated to a charitable organization. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
C. - Bulletin boards 
Only materials approved by the city administrator or the department head responsible for the city facility or department may be posted on city bulletin boards. The police department will have one (1) bulletin board specifically designated for union information. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
D. - Catastrophic illness 
(1)  Employees diagnosed with a catastrophic illness such as, but not limited to, cancer, heart disease, acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) and/or human immunodeficiency virus positive (HIV) are subject to the city's personnel policies and the benefit plans in effect at that time. 
(2)  An employee who is diagnosed as having a catastrophic illness and who desires to continue to work is requested to inform the department head, assistant city administrator, or city administrator of the diagnosis. 
All medical information pertaining to an employee's health will be regarded as privileged, private and confidential. In most cases, no one outside of the positions noted above shall know of the diagnosis and it will only be shared with the positions listed above after consultation with the employee and as permitted by law. 
(3)  It is the city's intent to permit an employee with a catastrophic illness to continue to work as long as is reasonable. All employment decisions will be based on the merits of the situation in accordance with defined criteria. The city will make reasonable accommodations to the employee. 
(4)  The city's management staff will be available for private consultation in the event any employee has a concern regarding a contagious catastrophic illness. 
(5)  If it becomes generally known that an employee of the city has become infected with a contagious catastrophic illness, the city's management staff and a professional consultant, if appropriate, will provide immediate intervention, as necessary through work-site counseling, sharing current information and informal meetings with coworkers to encourage questions and provide a means to discuss concerns. 
(6)  The city administrator or designated representative will handle all external inquiries concerning a contagious catastrophic illness. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
E. - Drug and alcohol testing 
(1)  Employees shall undergo an alcohol and/or drug analysis when requested by the employee's supervisor, department head, assistant city administrator or city administrator. Such requests may be made if one (1) of the following is present: 
(a)  Employee is involved in an incident involving personal injury or property damage in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00). An exception would be in a situation where the employee is obviously not a factor in the incident, such as the vehicle the employee was driving is struck while not in motion. 
(b)  Employee appears, based on objective and reasonable criteria, to be impaired from the performance of his duties due to the use of alcohol and/or drugs. Two (2) management employees will complete a condition of employee report in order to determine if the employee displays any characteristics of being impaired. If a second management employee cannot be found, another individual, such as a police officer, may be used. 
(2)  Employees working in city departments who are subject to drug and alcohol testing policies under a collective bargaining agreement, will be covered by the agreement. 
(3)  Some city departments may develop their own approved separate drug and alcohol testing policies that impose more rigorous standards than the policy stated herein. In the event this occurs and there exist two (2) apparent conflicting policies, the more stringent of the policies will control. 
(4)  Employees holding a CDL are subject to provisions of the Omnibus Transportation Employee Testing Act of 1991. 
(5)  Refusal to submit to testing will result in disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment. 
(6)  Applicants who refuse to cooperate in or fail to pass a post-offer, pre-employment drug test will not be hired. 
(7)  Employees who refuse to cooperate in a required test, who test positive more than once, or who use, possess, distribute, purchase, sell, manufacture or dispense illegal drugs on city premises or work sites will be disciplined up to, and including, termination. 
(8)  Employees who possess or consume illegal drug paraphernalia or alcoholic beverages on city premises or work sites will be disciplined up to, and including, termination. 
(9)  Employees who have been convicted of, sentenced for, or pled no contest to, a drug crime committed on city premises or work sites will be disciplined up to, and including, termination. 
(10)  For the purpose of determining whether the employee is under the influence of alcohol in violation of this policy, test results showing an alcohol concentration of .01 or more based upon the grams of alcohol per one hundred (100) millimeters of blood will be considered positive, and results showing an alcohol concentration of .0099 or less shall be considered negative. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
F. - Drug/alcohol free workplace 
(1)  The manufacture, distribution, possession or use of any drug while on duty is strictly prohibited. For purposes of this policy, drugs shall be defined as: 
(a)  Any alcohol product; 
(b)  Any drug which is not legally obtainable; 
(c)  Any drug which is legally obtainable, such as a prescription drug, but which is not legally obtained, is not being used for prescribed purposes, and/or is not being taken according to prescribed dosages. 
(2)  It shall be the responsibility of each employee to inform the supervisor, department head, assistant city administrator, or city administrator in the event the employee sees, or has reason to believe, another employee is in violation of this section. 
(3)  This policy does not apply to the lawful use of prescription drugs under the supervision of a licensed health care professional and within the limits of a valid prescription. An employee who has been prescribed drugs is required, however, to consult with his doctor or pharmacist about the prescribed medication's effect on the employee's ability to perform his job safely, and to immediately disclose any medication related work restrictions. While employees are required to disclose any medication related work restrictions, employees are not required to disclose the type of drugs they have been prescribed or the underlying medical conditions or disabilities unless directed to do so by their doctors or pharmacist or asked to do so by the city. 
(4)  Compliance with this policy is a condition of employment. As a condition of initial or continued employment, employees shall abide by the terms of this policy and shall notify the administration department of the City of West Chicago of any criminal drug statute conviction, guilty or nolo contendere plea for a violation occurring in the workplace no later than five (5) days after such conviction or plea. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
G. - Employee conduct harassment prohibited 
(1)  Employees have an obligation to maintain a consistently high standard of conduct in relationships with fellow employees. It is city policy that the workplace be free of all forms of harassment. 
(a)  Harassment shall mean physical or verbal conduct that denigrates or shows hostility towards an individual because of race, color, religion, gender, national origin, age or disability. 
(b)  Harassment conduct includes, but is not limited to, the following: epithets, slurs, negative stereotyping, or threatening intimidating or hostile acts, that relate to race, color, religion, gender, national origin, age or disability. 
(2)  In the event that an employee is confronted by or witnesses an act of harassing conduct, the employee in question should immediately report the incident to the employee's supervisor. The employee may, if desired, bypass the supervisor and report the incident directly to the department head, assistant city administrator, or city administrator. 
(3)  Violations of this policy will not be permitted and may result in discipline up to and including discharge. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
H. - Employee identification cards 
All employees will be issued an identification card and shall display the card, if requested, to provide identification to a citizen or company in connection with the employee's job duties. The administration department is responsible for collecting and destroying identification cards upon an employee's separation from city employment. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
I. - Financial separation 
No employee of the city shall have a financial interest in any contract with the city, or be financially interested in the sale to or by the city of land, materials, supplies or services. Personal stock interest and other indirect interests must be reported to the administration department upon employment with the city. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
J. - Fitness and appearance for work 
Employees shall arrive at work free from the influence of drugs or intoxicants and free from the influence and odor of alcohol. Any employee who is found under the influence of drugs or is intoxicated shall be subject to disciplinary action, including the possibility of termination. 
Employees are expected to be well groomed and dressed in a manner that is suitable to their responsibilities and position. An employee's appearance must be businesslike and reflect good taste. When uniforms are furnished or required, they must be kept clean and neat, and must be worn while performing the duties for the city. When safety equipment is issued to employees, it is mandatory that it be worn when performing tasks for which such equipment is provided. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
K. - Honorarium 
The city is honored to have employees recognized professionally by being asked to present at a workshop, seminar, conference or any other type of presentation. Employees may be allowed on regular time to make the presentation with prior approval from the department head, however, any honorarium must be donated to a charitable cause. Employees will be allowed to pick the charitable organization and donate the honorarium in their name. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
L. - Loss of driving privileges 
(1)  An employee who, as an essential function of the employee's job duties, operates a motorized vehicle and whose driving privileges have been suspended by the state is required to notify the supervisor or department head immediately. The employee may be required to take time off work without pay during the time driving privileges are suspended. 
(2)  If the suspended driving privileges exceed ninety (90) days in length, the employee may be discharged. In the event the suspended driving privileges exceed thirty (30) days, but do not exceed ninety (90) days, the employee may still be discharged. This determination will be made by the department head upon consultation with the city administrator or his designee. 
(3)  If the loss of driving privileges becomes permanent resulting in revocation of the employee's driver's license, this will be cause for immediate discharge. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
M. - Notification of major life changes 
In order to ensure continuation of health insurance and other benefits, employees are required to notify their supervisor and the finance department of major life changes within ten (10) business days. Examples of major life changes are marriage, divorce or legal separation, change in dependent status, birth or adoption of a child and change of address. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
N. - Payroll withholding 
Unless ordered by the courts as a wage garnishment, the withholding of salary and payment to employees' debtors shall not be provided by the city. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
O. - Personal and city property 
(1)  The city accepts no responsibility for loss or theft of personal belongings. Employees are advised to limit their exposure. 
(2)  The city reserves the right to have access to lockers provided for the use of employees at any time. Generally, the employee who has use of the locker should be present, if possible, during any such inspection. 
(3)  The use of any city property for personal use, without permission from the department head, is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
P. - Personal mail 
(1)  Employees shall not use the address of a city facility for the receipt of personal mail, without prior approval from the department head. 
(2)  Employees may use the city mail system to mail items not associated with their official duties when the employee provides the required postage. Use of city letterhead and envelopes for personal use is prohibited. 
(3)  If requesting a personal order be shipped to the city hall for convenience, for example, if it is too difficult to receive orders at home when an employee is working, the proper and only acceptable method is the following: 
Ship to: John/Jane Doe 
C/O City of West Chicago 
All billing for personal orders must be sent directly to the employee's home address. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
Q. - Personnel file 
(1)  The employee's main personnel file is located in the administration department and is maintained by the assistant city administrator. The employee's medical file is located in the finance department. 
(2)  Employees can inspect their main personnel file or medical file upon request to the assistant city administrator. 
(a)  The assistant city administrator will determine an acceptable place and time when access to the employee's personnel file will take place, subject to applicable law. 
(b)  In the event the employee does not agree with the contents of a document in his personnel file, the employee may attach a letter to the document which will then be placed in the personnel file. 
(3)  Except as otherwise required by law, the city will only release the following information from the employee's personnel file: position title, salary confirmation, and dates of employment, except under the following circumstances: 
(a)  When the employee has specifically authorized the written release of information; or 
(b)  When the city is legally obligated to provide the information; or 
(c)  When information is needed to provide information to agencies which are or may be providing health benefits to employees. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
R. - Physical fitness 
(1)  Each employee must maintain the standards of physical fitness required for performing the job. Whenever a department head suspects the physical condition of an employee is endangering the employee's own health or the safety of other workers, the city may require the employee to submit to a medical examination by a physician, without expense to the employee, to determine the employee's continued ability to perform the job. 
(2)  When recommendations shall be made by such examining physician, the employee must follow all directives and recommendations concerning the employee's physical condition, or be subject to disciplinary action, including termination. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
S. - Political activity 
Employees of the city shall be entitled to exercise their political rights; provided, however, no employee may (a) use her or his official position of employment to coerce or inhibit others in the free exercise of their political rights; or (b) engage in political activities while at work or on duty. For purposes of this section, the term "political rights" includes without limitation the following rights to: petition to make public speeches, to campaign for or against political candidates, to speak out on questions of public policy, to distribute political literature, to make campaign contributions and to seek public office. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
T. - Representation 
Employees are prohibited from representing a private person, other than themselves or members of their immediate household, before the city council or any city board or commission. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
U. - Restricted duty 
Employees who have suffered an illness or injury on or off duty and cannot perform all the required and normal tasks of their position may be placed on restricted duty. The city may require an employee who is on sick leave or workers' compensation leave to return to work in an available restricted duty assignment. 
(1)  Determination shall be made by the department head upon consultation with the assistant city administrator. In the event the restricted duty assignment is for ten (10) working days or more, written approval of the city administrator is required. 
(2)  Under no circumstances will an employee perform restricted duty without a written medical opinion from a physician stating that the employee is able to return to work and perform restricted duty without significant risk that such return to work will aggravate the employee's condition. 
(3)  Under no circumstances will an employee perform restricted duty longer than a sixty (60) day period. 
(4)  Nothing in this policy shall be construed to require the city to create restricted duty assignments for an employee. Employees will only be assigned to restricted duty assignments when the city determines that operations may permit it. 
(5)  If an injured employee is offered restricted duty during the initial twelve (12) weeks of disability, he may reject the temporary assignment as provided by the Family and Medical Leave Act without loss of benefits. Refusals to accept restricted duty assignments that comply with the treating physician's work restrictions after twelve (12) weeks will result in a loss of workers' compensation benefits, if the injury was sustained on the job, as permitted under that law. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
V. - Secondary employment 
(1)  Full-time employees are not permitted to engage in any outside work without the written approval of the department head and city administrator or his designee. The city may prohibit any secondary employment request if it is determined that such employment may be detrimental to the best interests of the city. 
(2)  A secondary employment request may not be approved: 
(a)  Where employment would extend beyond twenty (20) hours per week. 
(b)  Where the nature of the work or place of employment might result or encourage a reasonable belief of conflict of interest on the part of the general public. 
(c)  Where secondary employment would involve the employee's appearance in city uniform, or use of city equipment, or would foreseeably create liability exposure for the city. 
(d)  Where the secondary employment may have an adverse effect on the employee's sick leave record or subject them to an unreasonable risk of an injury. 
(e)  Where employment involves the use of official information not available to the public. 
(f)  Where employment would tend to influence the exercise of impartial judgment on any matter coming before the employee in the course of the performance of the employee's duties. 
(g)  Where employment involves management of a business closely related to the official work of the employee (in these cases the department head and city administrator or his designee may apply restrictions). 
(h)  Where it appears that secondary employment impairs the ability to discharge the duties and responsibilities of his city job. 
(i)  Where employment is such that the employee would be expected to perform the tasks as part of the employee's regular job duties. 
(3)  Employees who desire secondary employment must complete a secondary employment request form. 
(4)  Employees who are granted approval for secondary employment do so with the understanding and acceptance that their primary duty, obligation and responsibility is to the city. Employees who are granted approval realize they are subject to call at any time for emergencies, special assignment, or overtime duty. A secondary employment request may be rescinded if, in the judgment of the department head and city administrator or his designee, the secondary employment is adversely affecting the employee's job performance. Upon termination of the secondary employment, the employee shall notify the department head. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
W. - Sexual harassment 
We are proud of the working environment that has developed at the City of West Chicago and it is the purpose of this policy to stress the City of West Chicago's strong opposition to sexual harassment and identify the complaint procedures available to employees, as well as the disciplinary penalties that could be imposed for sexually harassing conduct or behavior. Sexual harassment is strictly prohibited by title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended in 1991, and the Illinois Human Rights Act. 
(1)  This policy applies to each and every employee, officer, appointed official, agent, volunteer, vendor and contractor of the city as well as anyone using the city's facilities. 
(2)  Each supervisor/manager is responsible for maintaining the workplace free from sexual harassment. This is accomplished by promoting a professional working environment and by dealing with sexual harassment as well as with all other forms of employee misconduct. 
(3)  Sexual harassment can take several forms. Sexual harassment is defined as any unwelcome sexual advance or request for sexual favors or any conduct of a sexual nature when: 
(a)  Submission to such conduct is made, either explicitly or implicitly, a term or condition of an individual's employment; 
(b)  Submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis for employment decisions affecting such individual; or 
(c)  Such conduct has the purpose or effect of substantially interfering with an individual's work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile or offensive working environment. 
(4)  The courts have determined that sexual harassment is a form of discrimination under title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended. One (1) example of sexual harassment is where a qualified individual is denied employment opportunities and benefits that are, instead, awarded to an individual who submits (voluntarily or under coercion) to sexual advances or sexual favors. Another example is when an individual must submit to unwelcome sexual conduct in order to receive an employment opportunity. 
Conduct commonly considered to be sexual harassment includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
(a)  Verbal—Sexual innuendos, suggestive comments, sexual propositions, or statements about other employees, even outside their presence, of a sexual nature, suggesting or demanding sexual involvement of another employee whether or not such suggestions or demand is accompanied by implicit or explicit threats concerning one's employment status. 
(b)  Nonverbal—Suggestive or insulting sounds (e.g. whistling), leering, obscene gestures, sexually suggestive bodily gestures, "catcalls", "smacking" or "kissing" noises. 
(c)  Visual—Displaying sexually explicit posters, signs, pin-ups, or slogans of a sexual nature. 
(d)  Physical—Unwelcome touching, hugging, or kissing, pinching, brushing the body in a sexual manner, coerced sexual activity, or actual sexual assault. 
(5)  Sexual harassment may involve: (a) a man harassing a woman; (b) a woman harassing a man; and (c) harassment between members of the same gender. 
The most severe and overt forms of sexual harassment are easier to determine. On the other end of the spectrum, some sexual harassment is more subtle and depends to some extent on individual perception and interpretation. 
An example of the most subtle form of sexual harassment is the use of endearments. The use of terms such as "honey", "darling", and "sweetheart" is objectionable to many women who believe that these terms undermine their authority and their ability to deal with men on an equal and professional level. 
(6)  Each individual employee has the responsibility to refrain from sexual harassment in the workplace. It is important that employees be sensitive to other employees' feelings. What may seem like innocent behavior or a joke may not be perceived the same way by another employee. It must be understood, employees are to conduct themselves in appropriate fashion. Any employee who sexually harasses a fellow worker can be liable for their actions. All employees are expected to become familiar with the contents of this policy and to abide by the requirements it establishes. 
(7)  Complaint procedure: If an employee feels he or she is a victim of sexual harassment, it is in the employee's best interest to tell the offending person that the behavior is not welcome and must be stopped. All incidents of sexual harassment must be reported. 
(a)  Report the incident: An employee should contact any of the following individuals to report incidents of sexual harassment: their department head or the assistant city administrator. The report may be made initially either orally or in writing, but reports made orally must be placed in writing before an investigation can be initiated. 
(b)  Investigation of complaint: All complaints of sexual harassment will be handled confidentially and will be thoroughly investigated. When a complaint has been submitted in writing, the assistant city administrator will initiate an investigation of the suspected sexual harassment within five (5) working days of notification. The assistant city administrator may request that another supervisory or management employee of the opposite sex assist in the investigation. The investigation will include an interview with the employee(s) who made the initial report, the person(s) towards whom the suspected harassment was directed, and the individual(s) accused of the harassment. Any other person(s) who may have information regarding the alleged sexual harassment may also be interviewed. 
(c)  Report: The assistant city administrator, and if applicable the supervisory or management employee of the opposite sex who assisted in the investigation, shall prepare a written report within fifteen (15) working days from written notification of the suspected harassment, unless extenuating circumstances prevent him/them from doing so. The report shall include a finding that sexual harassment occurred, sexual harassment has not occurred, or there is inconclusive evidence as to whether sexual harassment occurred at the time of the issuance of this report. A copy of the report will be given to the employee(s) who made the initial report, the employee(s) to whom the suspected harassment was directed, and the employee(s) suspected of the harassment. 
(8)  Any employee who retaliates (e.g. verbal threats, intimidation, etc.) against any complaining employee or other person who cooperates with an investigation under this policy, shall be subject to discipline, up to and including discharge. 
(9)  Disciplinary and corrective action will be taken against any employee found to have engaged in sexual harassment of any other employee. The extent of sanctions may depend in part upon the length and conditions of employment of the particular employee and the nature of the offense. The city reserves the right to impose any sanction or combination of sanctions to deal with unreasonable conduct or discrimination. 
(10)  Corrective action will be taken against any officer, official (appointed and elected), agent, volunteer, vendor and contractor of the city found to have engaged in sexual harassment of any other employee. The city reserves the right to impose any sanction or combination of sanctions to deal with unreasonable conduct or discrimination, up to and including termination of any and all working relationships. 
(11)  Legal rights under the law: The city hopes that any incident of sexual harassment can be resolved through the internal process as outlined above. However, any employee who believes he has been subjected to sexual harassment has the right to file a complaint with the Illinois Department of Human Rights, 100 West Randolph Street, Chicago, Illinois 60601 (312-814-6245) and/or the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, 500 West Madison, Suite 2800, Chicago, Illinois 60661 (312-353-2713). The Illinois Human Rights Act provides that complaints of harassment must be filed within one hundred eighty (180) days of the alleged incident. A complaint with the EEOC must be filed within three hundred (300) days of the alleged incident. It is also a violation of section 6-101 of the Illinois Human Rights Act to retaliate against an employee for opposing or complaining about conduct believed to be in violation of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
X. - Smoke free workplace 
Employees are prohibited from smoking inside any city facility. Each applicable department shall have at least one vehicle that is designated as smoke free. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
Y. - Solicitation by employees and distribution of printed materials 
(1)  Unless otherwise authorized by the city administrator, all activities such as solicitations, distribution of materials, requests for contributions or selling of merchandise of any kind by employees shall not be permitted during work time or in work areas. The following exception shall apply: 
Requests for contributions for gifts or receptions to recognize employees on their retirement, resignation from the city, or other events of personal significance 
The City's United Way Campaign 
(2)  The following restrictions shall apply to the solicitation by city employees after work hours: 
(a)  Any solicitation or fund raising program which involves employees seeking to solicit at city facilities must be reviewed and approved by the city administrator before it is initiated. 
(b)  The use of the "City of West Chicago" name, either directly or by inference, is prohibited. 
(c)  Any representation, either directly or by inference, that the city is encouraging or supporting the Activity is prohibited. 
(3)  The solicitation or the distribution of materials to employees by non-employees is prohibited on city property, including areas open to the general public, unless approved by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
Z. - Suggestion program 
Employees who have suggestions for the improvement of safety or training, or other related plans or programs, are encouraged to submit in writing their suggestions to their immediate supervisor who, in all cases, shall submit it to the department head and the city administrator. It shall be the responsibility of the department head to consider and, when warranted, implement the suggestion. The city will make a reasonable attempt to notify the employee in writing of the disposition of the suggestion and a copy sent to the administration department for the individual's personnel file. Particularly meritorious suggestions shall be recognized by special awards to be recommended to the city administrator for final consideration. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
AA. - Travel and training 
Employees authorized to attend required training sessions, conferences, seminars, technical meetings or luncheons will have associated expenses covered. This coverage is in the form of a prepayment (if there is sufficient advance time for processing), an advancement (where there is only an estimate of costs) or a reimbursement. Any sessions involving either a plane flight, an overnight stay or the total cost exceeds two hundred dollars ($200.00) must receive prior authorization from the department head. A city "travel and training approval" form is to be submitted and approved before incurring any expenses. A final accounting of expenses occurs upon the completion of the authorized session. Any excess of advanced monies is to be returned to the city. Authorized expenses are those for the employee only and cannot cover the expenses of a spouse or other person accompanying the employee. 
(1)  Registration fees—Are paid in full with the employee making every reasonable effort to qualify for early registration discounts. 
(2)  Transportation—Is by the most direct coach airfare and includes the employee's cost for baggage handling and airport/hotel transportation. Mileage reimbursement for use of a private vehicle will be at the current mileage rate (contact the finance department). Multiple participants driving to a meeting shall car pool. 
(3)  Lodging—Is for the cost of the single room, including tax, that is not a deluxe accommodation. 
(4)  Meal allowance—The meal allowance is based on the current per diem schedule (contact finance department), excluding those meals provided as part of the program. 
(5)  Incidental expenses—Items such as official telephone calls, faxes, parking fees, conference materials, etc. are eligible for reimbursement. 
(6)  Nonreimbursable expenses—Such expenses as, but not limited to, first-class travel, alcoholic beverages, tobacco, entertainment, personal phone calls, valet service, magazines, newspapers and other personal items are ineligible for reimbursement by the city. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
BB. - Use of city telephones 
Employees shall limit their use of city telephones for personal reasons to within reasonable limits, as determined by the department head. 
(1)  This privilege may be withdrawn by the department head if abused through excessive use or if it causes interference with work duties. 
(2)  Long distance personal telephone calls or facsimile transmissions, defined as calls outside the Chicago metropolitan area in area codes other than 847, 773, 815, 312, 630 and 708, may be made only with prior approval of the department head. Employees making a long distance personal telephone call must inform the finance department and pay for the call, unless the employee uses a telephone calling card. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
CC. - Use of city vehicles, equipment, supplies or tools 
(1)  Unless otherwise approved, city vehicles, equipment, supplies and tools shall not be used for an employee's personal use. 
(2)  Employees are responsible for the care and conservation of city vehicles, equipment, supplies and tools. 
(3)  City vehicles may be taken home by employees when approved by the department head and the city administrator. Employees shall be free from the odor and influence of alcohol, and the influence of drugs, when driving a city vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
DD. - Workplace violence 
It is the objective of the city to ensure the safety and well being of its workforce and the persons with whom the city does business. Therefore, the city has established a zero tolerance policy for any violent acts or threats by or towards any city employee. 
(1)  Violence in the workplace includes, but is not limited to: 
(a)  Any physical behavior that involves aggressive physical contact with any other person, including pushing, hitting, fighting, throwing objects or otherwise intentionally injuring another person or attempting to injure another person; 
(b)  Any physical behavior that would place a reasonable person in fear of receiving imminent physical injury or other aggressive physical contact of the sort described above; 
(c)  Verbal behavior which involves threatening physical harm, either directly or implicitly, against any person; and 
(d)  Any act of vandalism or other intentional damage or destruction of city or private property. 
Workplace violence also includes instances where such acts or threats are made against an employee by a nonemployee. 
Workplace violence does not include activities covered by police department regulations concerning the use of force by members in the performance of their law enforcement duties, which are treated separately under the department's policies and procedures. 
(2)  Employees who become aware of any threat of workplace violence, whether by an employee or nonemployee, are obligated to immediately report such action to the employee's supervisor (e.g. court order against spouse, relative or acquaintance). The employee may bypass the supervisor and make a complaint directly to the department head, assistant city administrator, or city administrator. Employees should not confront the person against whom their complaint is lodged. 
(a)  If the supervisor or department head receives a complaint, it shall be their responsibility to notify their supervisor and/or the administration department as soon as reasonably possible. 
(b)  All complaints will be given high priority. The city administrator may request an investigation of the incident. 
(3)  Violations of this policy may result in discipline up to and including immediate discharge. Employees should also understand that such behavior may be criminal and could result in criminal prosecution. 
(4)  Where an employee reasonably and in good faith opposes or reports any workplace violence, or testifies, assists or participates in an investigation of or hearing concerning allegations of threats of violence, no person or group of persons may retaliate against the employee. Retaliation includes any act of harassment, verbal abuse, verbal threats, or any other or additional act of workplace violence. Retaliation will also be considered a violation of this policy, and may result in discipline up to and including immediate discharge. 
(Ord. No. 4192, § 1, 6-21-99; Ord. No. 4415, § 1, 3-19-2001)  
EE. - Possession of firearms by employees 
(1)  Purpose. These regulations are applicable to the possession of concealed firearms by licensed employees whenever they are on duty with the city. The regulations apply the general restrictions "Firearms Concealed Carry Act," 430 ILCS 66/1, et seq. ("act"), to specific requirements and conditions related to a licensed employee's performance of his or her city duties. As set forth in the findings below, a licensed employee's possession of a concealed firearm in the performance of certain aspects of his or her duties would violate the Act or certain private property rights, and, accordingly, these regulations are intended to prevent such violations and liability to the city therefrom. The regulations are not intended to restrict or deny the rights of a licensed employee under the Act or under the Second Amendment of the United States Constitution, or Article I, Section 22, of the Illinois Constitution and law pursuant thereto. 
(2)  Findings. The City Council of the City of the West Chicago hereby finds and determines that: 
(a)  In the event of an emergency or claimed violation of the Act involving possession by a licensed employee, it is important that the city be able to readily ascertain that the licensed employee is duly licensed under the Act. Accordingly, it is proper that the Licensed employee provide and the city maintain information on the licensed employee's issuance of a license under the Act and the renewal, suspension, and revocation thereof. 
(b)  Employees' use of city vehicles in carrying out their duties includes driving them onto private property. Section 65(a-10) of the Act, 430 ILCS 66/65(a-10), expressly authorizes an owner of private real property of any kind to prohibit the possession of concealed firearms on property under his or her control and does not require owners of private residential property to post a sign or otherwise provide notice of such. While Section 65 (b) of the Act, 430 ILCS 66/65(b), allows a concealed firearm to be stored in a locked vehicle or in a locked container out of plain view in a vehicle in the parking area of most "prohibited areas", a private property owner has a constitutionally protected common law right to prohibit firearms anywhere on his or her property, and this right is not overridden or limited by the Second Amendment's right to bear arms. GeorgiaCarry.Org., Inc., v. Georgia , 687 F2d. 1244, 1265-1266 (11th Cir. 2012). Also, some city vehicles, such as motorized carts and construction equipment, are not lockable and do not have compartments or other areas where a concealed firearm can be stowed as required by Section 65 (b) of the Act. Additionally, a licensed employee in many cases has to share a vehicle with a person in the course of his or her duties. If the licensed employee has a concealed firearm in the vehicle shared with a person who does not have a concealed carry license, and the licensed employee must leave the vehicle and leave the firearm in it, a concealed firearm would be left in the possession of a non-licensed person, in violation of the Act. Accordingly, it is proper that concealed firearms be prohibited in all city vehicles at all times. 
(3)  Definitions. The following terms in these regulations shall have the meanings stated below: 
Act : The "Firearms Concealed Carry Act", 430 ILCS 66/1, et seq., and all amendments thereto enacted and effective after the adoption of these regulations. 
Concealed firearm : A concealed firearm as defined in Section 5 of the Act, 430 ILCS 66/5. 
Employee : 1) Any person employed full-time or part-time or on a temporary basis by the city; 2) any volunteer or person volunteering services or labor to the city full-time or part-time or on a temporary basis; and 3) any independent contractor of the city or representative of such contractor when performing contractual duties for the city whether on city property or in the field. An "employee" shall not include a police or other peace officer of the city or of another governmental entity when performing duties on behalf of the city. 
Licensed employee : An employee having a current, valid license under the Act. 
City property : Any real estate owned, leased, or licensed to the city or under possession and control of the city except public rights-of-way. 
City vehicle : A vehicle of any kind owned, leased, or in the possession and control of the city, or a personal or other vehicle used by a licensed employee for his or her city duties for which use the employee receives, or is entitled to receive, mileage, or other compensation. 
On duty : The time each day that an employee reports for or otherwise begins the performance his or her city duties until the time he or she permanently concludes those duties for the day, regardless of whether such duties are begun or concluded on city property. However, an employee shall not be deemed on duty when on a meal at the times and for the duration provided for in these personnel rules, a collective bargaining agreement, or other applicable city regulations. 
(4)  Restrictions on concealed firearms. 
(a)  Licensed employee's possession of concealed firearms. 
No licensed employee shall possess a concealed firearm when on duty or on city property except in compliance with the Act and these regulations. 
Further, no licensed employee shall possess a concealed firearm while on duty or on city property where allowed by the Act, unless the licensed employee shall have first notified the city in writing on a form provided by the city that he or she is duly licensed under the Act and shall have furnished the city with a photocopy of his or her concealed firearm license. Such a licensed employee shall also notify the city in writing on a form provided by the city each time his or her concealed firearm license is renewed and shall furnish the city with a photocopy of the renewed license. 
A licensed employee who has notified the city of a concealed firearms license under this subsection shall also notify the city in writing if his or her concealed firearm license is suspended or revoked.
