If, subsequently, such telephone and electric utility facilities are placed underground, the company's facilities in such area shall be placed underground. 
(b)  In case of any disturbance of pavement, sidewalk, driveway, or to other surfacing, the company shall, at its own expense, and in the manner required by the city ordinances or policies, replace and restore all paving, sidewalk, driveway or other surface of any street or alley disturbed. In case of any disturbance on either private or public property, the land surface, including plantings and trees, shall be restored by the company at its cost to substantially its previous condition. 
(c)  If at any time during the period of the franchise, the city shall lawfully elect to alter, or change the grade or location of any street, alley or other public way, the company shall upon reasonable notice by the city, remove, relay and relocate affected system facilities at its own expense, and in each instance comply with the requirements of the city. 
(d)  The company shall not place system facilities below ground where the same will cause service interruption with any gas, electric, telephone fixtures, water hydrants or other utility, and all such conduits or other fixtures placed in any street shall be so placed as to comply with all ordinances of the city. 
(e)  The company may be required by the city to permit joint use of its system facilities located in the streets, alleys or other public right-of-way of the city by utilities insofar as such joint use may be reasonably practicable and upon payment of reasonable rental therefore; provided that in the absence of agreement regarding such use, the corporate authorities consistent with law shall provide for arbitration of the terms and conditions of such joint use and the compensation to be paid therefrom, which award shall be final. 
(f)  The company shall hold the city harmless for any removal or damage to company facilities which results from a fire or other disaster necessitating city action. 
(g)  [Reserved.] 
(h)  If the company seeks to construct and maintain its cables and other system facilities on public or private property, and an easement for such use has already been granted to a telephone company, electric or other public utility, said easement shall, if at all possible, be interpreted so as to grant the company the same rights and privileges as have been granted to the telephone and electric companies and other public utilities. In such easements, the words "telephone" or "telephone company," "electric company" and the like shall be interpreted to include the company. The company shall not be required to install cable to service areas where the required easements are not reasonably obtainable. 
(i)  If the company abandons or unreasonably delays its work on the city's streets, the city has a right to have such work completed and to bill the company the expenses of such completion. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 24, 7-6-1982; Ord. No. 4025, § 2(BB, CC), 9-2-1997)  
Section 25. - Timing of construction and operation. 
(a)  Within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this ordinance, the company shall file with the appropriate governmental authorities and with the necessary utility companies all initial papers, applications, contracts and other documents necessary to permit the commencement of construction and operation of the cable television system and shall thereafter make diligent efforts to obtain the proper execution and delivery of such documents. The company shall provide the city with a copy of each application and document and shall report bimonthly to the city its progress in obtaining necessary permits, contracts and other necessary documents as contemplated above. 
(b)  Within ninety (90) days after the effective date of this ordinance, the company shall furnish the city a construction schedule and map setting forth target dates by areas for commencement of services to subscribers. The schedule and map shall be updated whenever substantial changes become necessary. 
(c)  Construction of the system shall commence within thirty (30) days after all required utility company licenses have been obtained by the company, and service shall be available to all potential subscribers within twelve (12) months thereafter. 
(d)  If construction is not commenced within three (3) months of receipt of all necessary utility permits, the company shall be deemed in default and the franchise terminated. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 25, 7-6-1982)  
Section 26. - Company's obligation to the community for local programming. 
(a)  In order to provide for local community programming activities, the company shall, within six (6) months of its acceptance of this grant, cause a charitable not-for-profit Illinois corporation (hereinafter the "foundation") to be formed in accordance with the following parameters: 
(1)  Name. West Chicago Cable Communications Foundation; 
(2)  Board of directors. Initial board of directors to be constituted of five (5) persons to be appointed by the mayor, with the advise and consent of the city council, plus an ex officio member designated by the company. 
(3)  Purpose. To foster the use of the public, educational, arts, and government access channels by promoting local programming, communication skills, and technology training among West Chicago residents of all ages, and to raise such funds as deemed necessary; 
(4)  Studios and facilities. In cooperation with the company, establish rules and regulations for scheduling the use of local access programming in the studio and other facilities, as well as channel access for local access programming; 
(5)  Investments. Establish an annual budget, receive and authorize the expenditure of revenues and manage the investments provided by the company for the financial support of local origination programming. 
(b)  The company shall provide the following financial support by direct funding, equipment, staff and services which shall be made available to the city and to the foundation for development of local programming activities. 
(1)  An initial cash grant of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) to the foundation upon its incorporation, and an annual grant of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) on the first anniversary of the date of this ordinance becoming effective and each anniversary date thereafter until this franchise is terminated, and an additional cash grant of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) on or before September 30, 1997; 
(2)  Conveyance, by appropriate bill(s) of sale, of all furnishings and equipment installed on or before September 30, 1997, in the local origination and access studio and/or city hall by the company and/or its predecessors in interest, including, but not limited to video and audio equipment, control equipment, teleprompters, racks, drapes, lights and cabinets, and the following additional items of equipment: 
A.  A three-quarter inch (¾?) video recorder; 
B.  A three-quarter inch (¾?) video player; and 
C.  A three-quarter inch (¾?) video editor-controller. 
Upon the request of the foundation, the company shall so convey the following playback equipment located at company's Wheaton facilities: A GVG 10x1 video-audio line switcher, two (2) three-quarter inch (¾?) video players, three (3) black and white monitors, a character generator, a time based corrector and a rack to house same. The company shall promptly move said playback equipment to the local origination and access studio and thereafter, the foundation shall be responsible for programming playback on the access channels. 
(3)  Local origination and access staff support over the life of the franchise, specifically including labor for installation, set up. maintenance and minor repair of all of the foundation's local origination and access equipment and provision of one (1) programming director to assist in local origination and access programming and training. 
(4)  Five (5) one-thousand-dollar-scholarships per year during the life of the franchise to students residing within the West Chicago School District 94 boundaries, with the award of the scholarships to be made by the foundation with the cooperation of the school district administration or equivalent. 
(5)  The company's intern program (CIP) to train local students in television technology and production in cooperation with area schools and institutions. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 26, 7-6-1982; Ord. No. 1809, §§ 1—3, 5-6-1985; Ord. No. 2641, § 1, 5-3-1993; Ord. No. 4025, § 2(EE—GG, 9-2-1997)  
Section 27. - Performance guarantee. 
(a)  In addition to any construction guarantee, the company shall furnish the city an annual performance guaranty in the form of either case, irrevocable letter of credit, or surety bond in the amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) as further guarantee for the faithful performance by the company of the provisions, terms and conditions of this ordinance. In case of any breach, the city shall be entitled to recover on said surety bond in the amount of any damages, and all costs and attorneys' fees incurred by the city, proximately resulting from the failure of the company to faithfully observe and perform under any and all provisions, terms, and conditions which this ordinance requires. 
(b)  No recovery by the city of any sum by reason of the surety bond required by this section shall be any limitation upon the liability of the company to the city, except that any sum received by the city by reason of said surety bond shall be deducted from any recovery which the city might have against the company. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 27, 7-6-1982; Ord. No. 4025, § 2(HH), 9-2-1997)  
Section 28. - Minimum damages upon franchise revocation. 
In the event the company fails to perform in accordance with any of the provisions of this ordinance and a forfeiture is declared, then it is understood and agreed that the city shall be entitled to the sum of fifty thousand ($50,000.00) as and for minimum damages, which sum shall be in addition to any other remedies the city may have and which sum shall be covered by the performance guarantee bond posted by the company at the time of execution of the franchise. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 28, 7-6-1982)  
Section 29. - Compliance with local, state and federal law. 
(a)  The company shall establish, construct, operate and maintain the system subject to the reasonable supervision of the city and in strict compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(b)  If at any time the powers of the city, state or federal government or any agency or official thereof in connection with the system are duly transferred to or later reside in any other board, authority, agency or official, such board, authority, agency or official shall have the power, rights and duties previously vested in addition to any other which they may acquire. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this ordinance, the company shall at all times comply with all state and federal laws, rules and regulations, or any administrative agency thereof; provided, however, if any such ordinance, law, rule or regulation shall require the company to perform any service or shall permit the company to perform any service in conflict with the provisions and terms of this ordinance or of any law, rule or regulation, then as soon as possible following knowledge thereof the company shall notify the city of the point of conflict believed to exist. If the city determines that a material provision of this ordinance is affected by such action, the city shall have the right to modify or amend any of the provisions herein to such reasonable extent as may be necessary to carry out the full intent and purpose of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 29, 7-6-1982)  
Section 30. - City's reservation of rights. 
(a)  The right is hereby reserved to the city to adopt and enforce in addition to the terms, conditions and provisions contained in this ordinance and in otherwise existing applicable ordinances, such additional ordinances, rules and regulations as it shall find necessary in the exercise of the police powers; provided that such ordinances, rules and regulations shall be reasonable and not in material or substantial conflict with the rights herein granted. 
(b)  In addition to the specific rights of inspection otherwise provided for in this ordinance, the city shall also have the right to make such inspections as it shall find necessary to ensure compliance with the terms, provisions and conditions of this ordinance and other relevant provisions of law. 
(c)  Nothing in this ordinance shall limit the right of the city to acquire all or any part of the system through the exercise of eminent domain in the manner provided by law. 
(d)  From time to time the city may by ordinance amend this ordinance. No such amendment shall be effective as to the company until the company files with the city its acceptance, with specific reference to the ordinance amending this ordinance, substantially in the form set forth in Section 37. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 30, 7-6-1982)  
Section 31. - Supervision of the company. 
(a)  Unless specifically otherwise provided in this ordinance, or unless the corporate authorities shall otherwise specify, all administrative actions required to be taken or which shall or may be taken by the city in connection with the system, shall be taken by the mayor or such other person designated by the mayor. 
(b)  Unless specifically otherwise provided in this ordinance, or unless the corporate authorities shall otherwise provide, all filings with the municipality required by this ordinance shall be made with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 31, 7-6-1982)  
Section 32. - City cable television committee. 
The city reserves the right to establish a cable television committee. If established, the committee shall constitute and shall exercise such powers and perform such functions in connection with the system and this ordinance as the corporate authorities shall from time to time provide, including but not limited to the following: 
(a)  The committee shall advise the corporate authorities with respect to all aspects of the company's actions in connection with the system in the city. 
(b)  The committee shall review all aspects of the company's actions in connection with the system. 
(c)  The committee, if it deems it necessary and according to such procedural rules as it may decide which affords the company and a subscriber a fair hearing, may conduct hearings in review of company decisions and actions with respect to this franchise ordinance. Decisions by the committee with respect to such hearings shall be binding upon the company, provided, however, nothing contained in this ordinance shall be construed to prohibit the company or the city from seeking or obtaining judicial relief for any resulting controversy. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 32, 7-6-1982)  
Section 33. - Notices. 
All notices herein provided for shall be sent prepaid by registered or certified mail addressed to the parties, as follows:

Section 35. - Limits on company's recourse. 
Except as expressly provided otherwise in this ordinance, the company herein shall have no recourse whatsoever against the city for any loss, cost or expense or damages arising out of the terms, conditions and provisions or requirements of this ordinance or because of the city's enforcement of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 35, 7-6-1982)  
Section 36. - Number of potential subscribers. 
The city and company shall identify and mutually agree upon a specific number of potential subscribers. Said agreement shall be in writing and made a part of this ordinance. The agreement shall be mutually executed at the time of acceptance by the company of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 36, 7-6-1982)  
Section 37. - Acceptance of franchise.[4] 
(a)  The provisions, terms and conditions of the grant of the franchise or any amendment, extension or renewal thereof shall be accepted by the company by written instrument filed with the city clerk within thirty (30) days after the passage and approval of the ordinance providing for such grant, amendment, extension or renewal, unless said time period is extended by the city at its sole discretion. 
(b)  The company expressly acknowledges that upon accepting the right, privilege and franchise granted by this ordinance, it did so relying upon its own investigation and understanding of the power and authority of the city in connection with the system and the grant, or any amendment, extension or renewal thereof. 
(c)  The company by acceptance of the right, privilege and franchise under the grant, or any amendment, extension or renewal thereof, acknowledges that it has not been induced to act by any understanding or proviso or other statement whether verbal or written by or on behalf of the city concerning any term or condition of the franchise not expressed herein. 
(d)  The company further acknowledges by such acceptance that it has carefully read the terms and conditions of this ordinance and is willing and does accept all reasonable risks of the meaning of the provisions, terms and conditions herein. 
(e)  In the event the company shall accept the grant of the franchise, or any amendment, extension or renewal thereof, in accordance with and pursuant to the provisions, terms and conditions of this ordinance, the company shall execute an acceptance in substantially the form as follows:

Section 38. - Delegation of powers. 
Any right, power or duty of the city, the corporate authorities of the city and cable television committee or any other official of the city under this ordinance may be transferred or delegated by ordinance, resolution, or other appropriate action of the corporate authorities to an appropriate officer, employee, department, or committee of the city or any legal authority, including any governmental agency created for the purpose of regulating the operation and development of an intercommunity cable communications system. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 38, 7-6-1982)  
Section. 39. - Severability. 
If any section, paragraph or provision of this ordinance is held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction or administrative agency, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof, except as otherwise provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 39, 7-6-1982)

This ordinance shall become effective ten (10) days after its passage and publication as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 1591, § 40, 7-6-1982)

APPENDIX F - ANNEXATIONS AGREEMENTS[1] 
The corporate authorities of the city may, in accordance with the procedures set forth in 65 ILCS 5/11-15.1-1, with the agreement of the owner, extend the term of any annexation agreement and/or amendment thereto previously entered into by the city for a term that may not exceed 40 years from the original date of the agreement and/or the amendment thereto entered into involving the territory affected by the extension. The extension of the original agreement and/or amendment thereto can be entered into any time after 5 years after passage of the original annexation agreement and may be entered into at any other time within that 40-year period, even after the termination of the original annexation agreement or any amendments thereto, provided that the total term of the annexation agreement or amendments thereto may not exceed 40 years. The city intends to fully exercise its home rule powers through the passage of this section and finds that it will benefit the citizens of the community and will assist in the appropriate planning and development of the city to provide an option for property owners and the corporate authorities of the city to mutually benefit from the terms of an extended annexation agreement or amendment thereto. 
(Ord. No. 08-O-0024, § 1, 5-19-2008)

--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Formerly App. J, see editor's note at the beginning of App. E.

In addition to the application fee, a five hundred dollar ($500.00) deposit shall be required. Upon notification by the city, the deposit shall be replenished if the fees incurred near the initial deposit amount, and review shall cease until such time as the deposit is replenished. Any remaining balance on a deposit will be refunded in a timely manner once all fees have been paid.

Sec. 8.2 The initial application fee for a license shall be accompanied by a non-refundable deposit of four hundred ten dollars ($410.00), except in the case of a Class D license. Application fees are in addition to the annual license fee.

Sec. 9.1 Miscellaneous Planning and Zoning Fees. 
In addition to the application fee, a five hundred dollar ($500.00) deposit shall be required for an amendment to the comprehensive plan or a local landmark or historic district designation. In the event that multiple applications requiring a deposit are being requested simultaneously, only one (1) deposit, equal to largest deposit required, shall be paid with the application fees. Upon notification by the city, the deposit shall be replenished if the fees incurred near the initial deposit amount, and review shall cease until such time as the deposit is replenished. Any remaining balance on a deposit will be refunded in a timely manner once all fees have been paid. 
Amendment to comprehensive plan ..... $2,200.00 
Local landmark or historic district designation ..... $200.00 
Temporary use fee ..... $100.00 
Zoning verification letter, per zoning lot ..... $60.00 
_____
Sec. 10.1 Occupancy Permit Fees. 
(1)  Fees for occupancy permits for any newly constructed, moved, remodeled or reconstructed building or structure or addition thereto for which a building permit is required shall be included in the fee of the building permit, therefore, as provided for in this section. 
(2)  Fees for occupancy permits issued pursuant to changes of occupancy are as follows: 
(a)  For unimproved real estate, there will be a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) charged for one (1) inspection. There shall be no fee assessed for the first re-inspection. A fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be charged for each re-inspection thereafter, payable prior to such re-inspection. 
(b)  For real estate improved only with a mechanical vault, transmission tower, sign, or other structure not intended for human habitation, there shall be a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) charged for one (1) inspection. There shall be no fee assessed for the first re-inspection. A fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be charged for each re-inspection thereafter, payable prior to such re-inspection. 
(c)  For all other units or structures, there shall be a base fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus twelve cents ($0.12) per square foot charged for one (1) inspection. In no case shall the fee exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). There shall be no fee assessed for the first re-inspection. A fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be charged for each re-inspection thereafter, payable prior to such re-inspection. 
(d)  A person, firm or corporation shall be exempt from the inspection fees provided above if that person's, firm's, or corporation's change of occupancy is from premises located within the city's limits, but shall be subject to all other provisions of section 4-1 (I). 
(e)  Temporary occupancy permit fees as subject to section 4-1 (I) are as follows: 
During allowable dates ..... $500.00 
Outside allowable dates ..... $1,000.00 
(f)  All fees contained listed in section 10.1 are not refundable.

Sec. 19.1 In addition to the fees set in this Appendix (except those designated with an "*"), each petitioner/applicant and property owner shall reimburse the city for such professional fees and costs as shall actually be incurred by the city, plus an additional twenty-five (25) percent administrative fee, in the event that the city, in its sole and exclusive discretion, determines that it is necessary or desirable to obtain professional services, including, but not limited to, attorneys, engineers, planners, architects, surveyors, traffic, drainage or other consultants, and/or to incur costs related to any required notices or recordations, in connection with the application or petition, and/or any related application or petition filed by the petitioner/applicant.

Sec. 20.1 Small Wireless Facility Fees and Penalties 
Permit Fees—All applications for permits pursuant to this Ordinance shall be accompanied by a non-refundable application fee according to the following schedule: 
Single wireless telecommunications facility on an existing structure ..... $650.00 
Multiple wireless telecommunication facilities (maximum 25) included in a single application to collocate 
on existing structures ..... $350.00 per each facility 
Wireless telecommunication facility that includes the replacement or installation of a new structure or tower ..... $1,000.00 
Annual Recurring Rate—The wireless services provider shall pay to the City an annual recurring rate for each permitted location of two hundred ($200.00) dollars per year or an amount equal to the City's direct costs, whichever is greater, to collocate telecommunication facilities on City-owned infrastructure. Initial payment shall be received prior to permit issuance by the City. Thereafter, payment shall be received annually beginning on the second January 1 following the initial payment. 
Penalties—Any person who violates any provision of this Ordinance or fails to comply with the requirements thereof, or who constructs, alters, repairs, disconnects, removes any facility within the City rights-of-way in violation of an approved plan or directive of the Director of Public works or his designee, or fails to apply for or obtain a permit issued under the provisions of this Ordinance shall be guilty of an offense punishable by a fine equal to the greater of: 
Seven hundred fifty ($750.00); or 
Twice the assessment application fees under this Ordinance; or 
An amount sufficient to correct any deficiencies or maintain the proper movement and safety of the City rights-of-way users. 
Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. The imposition of ay fine shall not exempt the offer from compliance with the requirements of this Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-0045, § 1, 7-16-2018)
